Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Liberty Aviation Museum, Inc. v. JRM Marine Consulting, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach assets of father of contractor's sole owner was not warranted with regard to museum's fraud and civil conspiracy claims as to contractor's failure to repair a historical boat, for purposes of determining whether museum's pursuit of such claims was frivolous, even though father had sole authority and exclusive control over contractor for two months after owner suffered a stroke; there was no evidence that father exercised control in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against museum, such as by depleting assets, or evidence that father acted fraudulently or illegally in deciding to close business and allowing another individual to take it over without compensation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach the assets of owner's father who took control after owner suffered a stroke was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Liberty Aviation Museum, Inc. v. JRM Marine Consulting, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach assets of sister corporations was not warranted with regard to museum's fraud and civil conspiracy claims, for purposes of determining whether pursuit of such claims was frivolous in its action regarding contractor's failure to repair a historical boat, where contractor and sister corporations had common individual shareholders but neither entity had ownership interest in the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach the assets of owner's father who took control after owner suffered a stroke was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Liberty Aviation Museum, Inc. v. JRM Marine Consulting, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach assets of a lender and former co-owner was not warranted with regard to museum's fraud and civil conspiracy claims, for purposes of determining whether museum's pursuit of such claims was frivolous in its action regarding contractor's failure to repair a historical boat, where lender and former co-owner had no involvement in running contractor's business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach the assets of owner's father who took control after owner suffered a stroke was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Pierre Investments, Inc. v. CLS Capital Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Loan broker did not owe duty to disclose any material information to prospective corporate borrower regarding loan agreement, and thus, piercing corporate veil to hold corporate owner liable for fraudulent inducement based on alleged false statements was not warranted in borrower's action arising out of damages it allegedly sustained due to failure to close on loan; loan agreement was arm's-length transaction and there were no special circumstances upon which to transform ordinary debtor-creditor business transaction into fiduciary relationship.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Parties. Broker that dissolved before it entered loan agreement that was subject of borrower's breach-of-contract action was not entity capable of being sued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Flooring Depot FTL, Inc., v. Wurtzebach
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Customers' allegations against president of retail corporation were insufficient to show that president engaged in any improper conduct, and thus trial court could not pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability on president for corporation's breach of contract and fraud; customers merely alleged that president commingled his business and personal assets and used business monies to make personal purchases, president did not use corporation for improper purpose, and trial court specifically found that president's actions were not fraudulent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Customers' allegations against president of retail corporation were insufficient to show that president engaged in any improper conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: MGF Healthcare Partners, Inc. v. Blue Ridge Healthcare Birmingham, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: There was no evidence that healthcare management company financed healthcare provider, that provider only did business with company, that company used provider's property as its own, or that provider failed to observe legal requirements of a corporation, and thus healthcare contractor which entered contract with provider could not prevail on claims against company for breach of contract, subterfuge/instrumentality, and fraud pursuant to alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing under Alabama law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Healthcare contractor could not prevail against company for breach of contract and other claims under the alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: MGF Healthcare Partners, Inc. v. Blue Ridge Healthcare Birmingham, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Fact that healthcare provider and healthcare management company were owned by the same five persons did not support healthcare contractor's claims against company for breach of contract, subterfuge/instrumentality, and fraud under alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing under Alabama law, absent showing that company itself was a shareholder, officer, or director of provider.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Healthcare contractor could not prevail against company for breach of contract and other claims under the alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: MGF Healthcare Partners, Inc. v. Blue Ridge Healthcare Birmingham, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: There was no evidence that healthcare management company financed healthcare provider, that provider only did business with company, that company used provider's property as its own, or that provider failed to observe legal requirements of a corporation, and thus healthcare contractor could not prevail on claims against company for breach of contract, subterfuge/instrumentality, and fraud pursuant to "totality-of-the-circumstances" theory in action alleging that company and healthcare provider operated as a single corporate entity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Healthcare contractor could not prevail against company for breach of contract and other claims under the alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United States v. Dynamic Visions Inc
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: It would be unjust to allow home healthcare provider's sole owner, who was also its chief executive officer (CEO), to retain funds wrongfully taken from, and now owed to, the government, and thus piercing the corporate veil was warranted to hold owner liable under False Claims Act (FCA) for false reimbursement claims submitted to District of Columbia Medicaid program, even if he had history of running provider in manner satisfactory to regulatory overseers, since he failed to maintain corporate formalities when he transferred large sums of money from provider's accounts, which contained reimbursements from the program, to his own personal accounts. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3729 et seq.; Social Security Act § 1801, 42 U.S.C.A. § 1395 et seq.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Medical Assistance. Home health care provider knowingly submitted false Medicaid reimbursement claims and also did so with reckless disregard for their falsity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United States v. Kindred Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Relator's allegations of undercapitalization and siphoning of funds were sufficient to allege alter ego liability between nursing home operators and their nursing facilities, in relator's qui tam action under the False Claims Act (FCA) against nursing home operators; relator alleged that operators exerted pervasive and continual control over nursing homes such that homes were mere agents, instrumentalities and conduits through which operators did business, and that operators treated funds of one entity as the funds of another, collected, distributed and shared revenues, profits, and assets of its homes, and continually siphoned all revenues from each of individual homes, rendering homes entirely dependent on operators for continued existence and operations.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator sufficiently alleged that nursing home operators knew staffing levels they mandated made it impossible to provide for their residents' needs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Avery v. Schneider as Next Friend of Schneider
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Allegations supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil to find officer for corporate entity hired to oversee safety, maintenance, and supervision of pool liable in action by parents and next friend of minor child, who nearly died from drowning and sustained brain injury, for negligence and fraud, despite claim that entity owed no duty or damages; officer and entity held entity out as qualified pool management company with properly trained and qualified lifeguards to protect members of community, lifeguard failed to employ proper post-drowning lifesaving techniques after she became aware of incident because she was improperly trained and supervised by entity, and since incident, and child had regular seizures requiring constant medication, migraine headaches, processing difficulties, poor memory, social difficulties, and other neurological and academic issues. (Per Hodges, J., with one judge concurring in the result.)
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Allegations supported finding that officer for corporate entity that supervised pool breached duty to child who nearly drowned by inadequately training lifeguard.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Digirolamo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, Chapter 13 debtor did not defraud homeowner by failing to disclose, before his wholly owned company performed stucco work on custom-built home, that the company was not a licensed contractor, and so homeowner could not pierce the corporate veil to hold debtor personally liable for company's debt based on alleged fraud; whether or not debtor, an unsophisticated business person who did not finish high school, misread the law and was required to hold a license, there was no evidence that he had the intent to deceive, or the equivalent thereof, which was an essential element of fraud, there was no proof that company was required to have a license, so debtor's conduct in performing stucco work without a license was not a crime, and debtor's work was done in furtherance of a contract between contractor and his company, and in his capacity as a company employee. La. Civ. Code Ann. art. 1953; La. Rev. Stat. Ann. §§ 12:95, 37:2150, 37:2150.1(11).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Debtor did not defraud homeowner by failing to disclose that his company was not a licensed contractor, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Binsara, LLC v. Bolog
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fifth District, Stark County.
Headnote: Corporate officers of bus repair corporation engaged in fraud by entering into contract for repair of passenger bus at a time when corporation was not legal entity, and thus corporate veil could be pierced, although no pending cause of action for constructive fraud was present, where valid and enforceable judgment existed against corporation, and officers failed to challenge any facts supporting fraud finding by trial court.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate officers engaged in fraud by entering into contract when corporation was not legal entity, and thus corporate veil could be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: ETC Texas Pipeline, Ltd. v. Addison Exploration & Development, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Mere fact that subsidiary pipeline companies and parent energy company shared officers did not establish agency liability on part of parent company for subsidiaries' actions with respect to alleged fraud and breach of contract with oil and gas lease development company absent evidence subsidiaries were acting on behalf of parent, as opposed to on their own behalf.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Energy company and subsidiary pipeline companies did not owe duty to development company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: R&M Mixed Beverage Consultants, Inc. v. Safe Harbor Benefits, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Purchaser of an insurance agency's assets did not utilize the agency entity or an entity which took over the agency's liabilities to perpetuate fraud, as required to pierce the corporate veil and hold purchaser liable, in an insured bar-and-grill owner's action after its liquor liability insurer, that the agency helped procure, went insolvent; there was no indication that purchaser was aware of the liability insurer's financial instability, the liability insurer had retained a high rating, and had remedied capitalization concerns raised by regulators and rating agency.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Liability. Insurance entities that helped procure liquor liability insurance were not liable for damages resulting from the insurer's subsequent insolvency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Gannon
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil did not shield Chapter 7 debtor from personal liability to homeowners who contracted either with him or with his wholly-owned construction company for addition to their home to the extent that debtor, in personally negotiating contract with homeowners and performing work, made false representations or engaged in other fraud with respect to construction project, especially where debtor had personally received $ 81,246 in payments from homeowners for work, and where debtor, in completing his bankruptcy schedules, had listed debt to homeowners without indicating that it was disputed or owed by third party like his construction company; thus, debtor owed debt to homeowners, of kind that could be subject of nondischargeability proceeding. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Misrepresentations by debtor-contractor were either not shown to be fraudulent or could not be justifiably relied on.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: DeWeese v. Pribyla
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Shareholders were shielded from personal liability for deceptive acts by improvement supplier for failing to provide a written contract to senior homeowner for improvements to her residential property; senior homeowner's argument to pierce the corporate veil in order to determine shareholders' personal liability was simply a request to reweigh the evidence.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Consumer Protection. Senior homeowner was entitled to treble damages for improvement supplier's failure to provide written contract for residential property improvements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Technicool Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Statutory exemption from individual liability in matters relating to or arising from contractual obligations of corporation applied to fraud claims against founder of Chapter 7 corporate debtor asserted by purchaser of heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) units, absent evidence founder received a direct, personal benefit from the purported fraud he perpetrated. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Allegations were adequate to support cause of action for common law fraud under Texas law against founder of Chapter 7 corporate debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Riley v. Barringer
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Virginia, Abingdon Division.
Headnote: Former employee did not allege facts sufficient for district court to infer that the separate personalities of employer and its sole shareholder no longer existed or that employer was shareholder's alter ego, as required, under Virginia law, to state claims, including unjust enrichment and fraud, against shareholder personally, arising from, inter alia, employer's alleged failure to reimburse funds that employee purportedly deposited in employer's bank account from her own retirement account and personal funds; allegations did not suggest that shareholder personally guaranteed the alleged loan that employee made, allegations did not suggest shareholder personally benefited from loan, there was no evidence shareholder treated employer's funds as his own, and employee's remaining causes of action only mentioned shareholder's name.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Former employee did not allege facts sufficient for district court to infer, under Virginia law, that employer was shareholder's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Garcia v. Peterson
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Moving truck drivers adequately pleaded fraud claim against employer's creditor under alter ego theory, where drivers alleged that creditor exercised total control over employer's moving business and induced drivers to continue working under false promise that wages would be paid. Fed. R. Civ. P. 9(b).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Unfair Labor Practices. Venue for FLSA action involving interstate moving services would be proper in Texas pursuant to fallback provision of federal venue statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: P & S & Co. LLC v. SJ Mak, LLC
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil and holding a corporate director of each of two companies personally liable for the judgment against the companies for fraud and breach of contract was warranted, where the companies were the alter egos of the directors, who were a couple, and the directors used the companies to sell mortgages and notes that they did not own to defraud judgment creditor and others.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. Stay from judgment debtor's bankruptcy case did not preclude impleading third-party defendants in judgment creditor's supplementary proceedings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Hong v. Havey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to prove that any fraud by corporation with respect to its exclusive listing agreement with real estate broker was primarily for the direct personal benefit of corporation's owner, as required to render owner individually liable as corporation's alter ego, in broker's action alleging fraud and breach of contract based on corporation's sale of land with the help of another real estate agent; owner did not pocket unpaid commission owed to broker, and whether the commission was paid to broker did not affect owner's liability on her guarantee of loans that financed corporation's acquisition of the land. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient to render corporation's owner liable to real estate broker for unpaid commission under exclusive listing agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United States Stepe v. RS Compounding LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: There was a significant unity of interest and ownership between compounding pharmacy and its owner, as required to hold owner liable for company's alleged violations of False Claims Act (FCA), under veil piercing theory, where owner was sole shareholder and officer of the company who received a high salary and took shareholder distributions from the company whenever he pleased, which had significantly impaired compounding pharmacy's ability to pay its obligations to government under the FCA. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3729 et seq.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Complaint stated claim against compounding pharmacy for violation of FCA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: G v. Fay School, Inc. by and through its Board of Trustees
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: There was no evidence that private school headmaster benefited from his alleged participation in any misrepresentations in student handbook about the school's commitment to treat students with empathy, kindness, and civility, and therefore the corporate veil could not be pierced to hold the headmaster liable under Massachusetts law based on the school's treatment of student in regards to his alleged Electromagnetic Hypersensitivity Syndrome (EHS) purportedly caused by wireless internet at the school.
Document Preview: EDUCATION  Disabled Students. Student established a prima facie case of ADA retaliation based on private school's refusal to allow student to participate in after-school athletics.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Zak
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing the corporate veil is not limited to those circumstances in which there is a confused intermingling of activities of corporate entities, but can be employed to thwart the perpetration of fraudulent or other reprehensible conduct by an alter ego or to hold corporate officers responsible for their personal torts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's breached duties as partner to account for profits were fiduciary defalcations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Cevdet Asküt Ve Oğullari Koll, STI v. Cavusoglu
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Proof at trial of importer's fraud on Turkish food exporter, related to exporter's shipment of $1.1 million worth of goods on open account basis and importer's failure to pay, and of importer's use of his corporate form to perpetrate that fraud, supported jury's decision to pierce the corporate veil, and therefore, that decision rendered importer personally liable for exporter's judgment against import corporation; fact that exporter could pursue relief from importer's alleged efforts to frustrate collection of that judgment did not preclude his liability for judgment itself.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. It was not unreasonable for exporter to rely on importer's representations about ability and intent to pay for shipments, for purposes of fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Conde v. Sensa
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Allegations that corporation that marketed weight loss product and its sister companies were operated as a single enterprise, and that corporation strategically transferred money between sister companies in order to safeguard proceeds obtained from deceiving consumers into purchasing ineffective product, were sufficient, under California law, to state a claim of alter ego liability against sister companies under "single enterprise" rule.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Pleading. A plaintiff may not rely on unsubstantiated state-court allegations to defeat a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Conde v. Sensa
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Allegations that president of entities that included corporation that marketed fraudulent weight loss product had day-to-day management duties and continued marketing the product even after stipulated judgment against corporation did not plausibly demonstrate that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer existed, as required to state a claim of alter ego liability under California law.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Pleading. A plaintiff may not rely on unsubstantiated state-court allegations to defeat a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Conde v. Sensa
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Allegations that owners and managers of entities that included corporation that marketed fraudulent weight loss product necessarily took actions on behalf of the corporation were insufficient to plausibly demonstrate that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individuals no longer existed, as required to state a claim of alter ego liability under California law.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Pleading. A plaintiff may not rely on unsubstantiated state-court allegations to defeat a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Landress v. Tier One Solar LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, investor sufficiently pled plausible claim for piercing corporate veil to hold parent company and its principals liable for subsidiary's purported fraud by alleging that subsidiary was undercapitalized, that parent and subsidiary disregarded corporate formalities by holding themselves out as joint entity when they obtained additional investment funds from another investor and commingling funds, that subsidiary and parent blurred lines of their corporate forms by agreeing that parent would provide additional inducements to investor in exchange for his investment in subsidiary, and that money was funneled from subsidiary to parent and served as conduit for principals to unjustly enrich themselves and render subsidiary insolvent.
Document Preview: TORTS  Parties. Company's former CFO was indispensable party in investor's action against company, its parent, and other executives.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Chico Auto Parts & Service, Inc. v. Crockett
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: A plaintiff may sue a corporation's affiliate for his torts, including fraud, without the need to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Managing member for operator of well could not be held personally liable as part owner of well in breach of contract action by remediation services provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United States v. Dynamic Visions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: There was sufficient degree of unity of interest between corporation and its sole owner to warrant piercing the corporate veil, as would support holding owner liable under False Claims Act for corporation's submissions of false claims to Medicaid for reimbursement; owner was registered agent, president, and chief corporate officer of corporation, corporate formalities were not followed, funds were commingled and diverted for non-corporate uses, owner was sole signatory on all of corporation's bank accounts, and business address provided for corporation at registration was the same as owner's personal home address. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3729 et seq.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Piercing the corporate veil was warranted to hold sole owner liable for corporation's submissions of false claims to Medicaid for reimbursement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United States v. Dynamic Visions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Inequitable result would have followed if district court did not pierce corporate veil of corporation, a home health care provider, to hold corporation's sole owner liable under the False Claims Act for corporation's submissions of false claims to Medicaid for reimbursement; owner withdrew or transferred large sums of corporate funds, owner refused to provide court-ordered discovery that would have allowed government to trace funds or effectively litigate its claims against owner individually, and without piercing the corporate veil, government may not have been able to reach funds and owner would have been rewarded for obstruction and stonewalling. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3729 et seq.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Piercing the corporate veil was warranted to hold sole owner liable for corporation's submissions of false claims to Medicaid for reimbursement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Matter of Ritz
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: If seller could show that the individual who was in financial control of corporate buyer perpetrated an actual fraud for his direct personal benefit, individual was liable for buyer's debt to seller under the Texas veil-piercing statute. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Establishing that a transfer is fraudulent under TUFTA's actual fraud prong is sufficient to satisfy the actual fraud requirement for veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United States v. Executive Health Resources, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Integration of physician advisor company into parent company's corporate structure was not sufficient basis to pierce corporate veil to hold parent company and subsidiaries liable for advisor company's allegedly fraudulent scheme in violation of False Claims Act; although parent placed trusted employees in management positions at advisor company, promoted company's products on corporate website, and promised to investigate allegations of abuse at company, advisor company was not facade for parent or any of its subsidiaries because company's alleged fraudulent scheme began years before its acquisition, and advisor was not insolvent and otherwise was able to satisfy judgment. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3729.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator alleged nationwide scope of scheme with sufficient particularity in FCA action against physician advisor company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Hawes v. Kabani & Company, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington.
Headnote: Claim that managing principal of an auditing corporation participated in the audit of a Washington company, and that principal approved the use of the audit in the company's securities filings, sufficiently alleged that principal participated in an audit challenged as factually inaccurate, as required to pierce the corporate veil and state claims of negligent and intentional misrepresentation, violation of Washington state securities laws, and unjust enrichment against principal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Corporation purposefully directed its activities toward forum state, as required for specific personal jurisdiction, by auditing company in forum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: U.S. v. Badger
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Utah law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, government's reverse-piercing alter-ego theory of recovery was available, allowing government to pursue action, seeking declaration that corporation, limited liability companies (LLC), and trust were debtor's alter egos so that their assets could be pursued to satisfy consent judgment, under which debtor agreed to disgorgement of $5.8 million of profits from his securities fraud scheme; Utah Supreme Court expressed sympathy for reverse piercing, and Utah Court of Appeals applied alter-ego theory in reverse-piercing context twice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse-piercing alter-ego theory was available under Utah law allowing pursuit of alter ego's assets to satisfy consent judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Houri v. Boaziz
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Part owner of corporation that acted as sole managing member of limited liability company (LLC) created to purchase, develop, operate, manage, market, and resell apartment complex was not subject to personal liability for fraudulently inducing developer to reduce what was to be his one third interest in project by half, where developer and corporation executed operating agreements governing project, and developer did not allege basis on which corporation's corporate identity could be disregarded.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of corporation that acted as LLC's managing member was not personally liable for corporation's breach of duties of loyalty and care.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Edward Tyler Nahem Fine Art, L.L.C. v. Barral
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted in fraud suit related to purchase of artwork, where defendant did not improperly use company funds for personal expenses, did not fail to adhere to corporate formalities, did not significantly undercapitalize company during its operation, and did not make withdrawals for purpose of leaving his corporation judgment-proof or to perpetrate wrong against plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted in suit alleging fraud related to purchase of artwork.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Lomas v. Kravitz
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Trial court properly pierced the corporate veil of developer's corporations in action by flooring contractor against developer and his corporations, alleging fraud and fraudulent transfers, where one corporation was undercapitalized, developer failed to adhere to corporate formalities, there was extensive intermingling of the various corporations' funds, and developer had used the corporate form to perpetuate a fraud, specifically, to remove assets from the reach of creditors such as contractor.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judges. Recusal of court of common pleas judge who presided over action by contractor against developer was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Securities and Exchange Commission v. Cooper
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey, Camden Vicinage.
Headnote: Seller of fictitious investments, who was sole managing member, general partner, principal, and director, acted as alter egos of corporation, limited liability companies, and limited partnership, allowing court to pierce the corporate veil in securities fraud action; companies did not maintain formalities of incorporation, never held board or executive meetings, did not have any employees, directors, officers, or principals besides seller, and investor funds were transferred between multiple bank accounts before being depleted to pay for seller's personal expenses. Securities Act of 1933 § 17, 15 U.S.C.A. § 77q(a); Securities Exchange Act of 1934 § 10, 15 U.S.C.A. § 78j(b); 17 C.F.R. § 240.10b-5.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Seller of fictitious investments acted with scienter while employing fraudulent scheme, as required to establish securities fraud violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Janvey v. Libyan Investment Authority
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, Libyan Foreign Investment Company (LFICO) was not Libyan Investment Authority's (LIA) alter ego, and thus LIA was not liable to receiver for assets related to Ponzi scheme for proceeds of LFICO's investments in scheme, even though LIA held LFICO's shares, where LFICO and LIA had separate boards of directors, there were no interlocks in boards of directors of LIA and LFICO, LIA was not responsible for controlling or managing specific activities or transactions at subsidiary level, and LIA did not play any role in connection with LFICO's investment in Ponzi scheme.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW  Foreign Sovereigns. District court had subject matter jurisdiction over receiver's action against Libyan Foreign Investment Company to recover Ponzi scheme proceeds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Matthys v. Narconon Fresh Start
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Allegations of patient at substance abuse treatment facility operated by corporation stated a claim under Colorado law for piercing the corporate veil of two other corporations under alter ego theory, in action for breach of contract and fraud, alleging that treatment facility was not non-religious as promised, and that it did not offer treatment by qualified professionals and instead attempted to recruit patient into a church; patient alleged that corporate operator was subsidiary of second corporation which, in turn, was subsidiary of third corporation, and that third corporation oversaw church's drug rehabilitation activities and governed and controlled nearly every aspect of corporate operator's and second corporation's business activities.
Document Preview: TORTS  Emotional Distress. Alleged conduct of operator of substance abuse treatment facility was outrageous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: Fact that title insurer was aware, before entry of consent judgments against home builder arising out of its misrepresentation that all subcontractors had been paid, that builder had no assets and no intention of paying the subcontractors, and that builder's principal had disclosed the existence his new homebuilding corporations, did not preclude finding that principal used his dominion and control of builder and the new corporations to perpetrate a fraud or wrong, as necessary to support piercing the corporate veil; principal's entry into the consent judgments while builder was assetless was actually evidence that the fraud or wrong element was met.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: AngioScore, Inc. v. TriReme Medical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, alter ego liability was not available with respect to three entities on corporation's claims related to development of competing angioplasty balloon catheter product; corporation made no colorable argument that defendants engaged in fraud in corporate restructuring, and it instead contended only that, in absence of piercing corporate veil, injustice would result because it could not recover all proceeds from sales of competing catheter.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. In suit for patent infringement and state-law claims related to development of competing device, court properly exercised supplemental jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Rossetti v. Ambulatory Surgery Center of Brooklyn, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegation that corporate shareholders had commingled and misused corporate funds, and had used their domination and control of corporation to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiffs, stated claim for piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations stated plausible veil-piercing claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: William L. Thorp Revocable Trust v. Ameritas Inv. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: There was no evidence that either a grandparent or a parent corporation exercised actual control over subsidiary brokerage firms with regard to transactions allegedly constituting securities fraud or that the subsidiary brokerage firms were mere instrumentalities of the grandparent or parent corporations, precluding securities fraud claims against the grandparent or parent corporations.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investor failed to establish independent sales agent acted with scienter required for state and federal securities fraud claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: John Knox Village v. Fortis Const. Co., LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Substantial evidence supported piercing of corporate veil to hold owners of general contractor individually liable for fraudulent misrepresentation stemming from contractor's distribution of client payments to the owners rather than to subcontractors; evidence indicated that owners controlled the contractor as its officers and only shareholders, that contractor falsely represented that it would timely pay all subcontractors and that the property would not be subject to liens, and that client had to negotiate directly with the subcontractors and make additional payments to avoid liens being filed against the property as a result of the owners' misrepresentations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Substantial evidence supported piercing corporate veil to hold general contractor's owners individually liable for fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Takiguchi v. MRI Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Japanese investors stated a claim to hold corporation's chief executive officer (CEO) individually liable under alter ego theory, under Nevada law, for corporation's alleged operation of a massive Ponzi scheme, where they alleged that CEO had exclusive control over corporation's funds, and thus had control over investors' funds, which he used for his own personal expenses, and that corporation did not have sufficient funds to repay its existing investors.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investors sufficiently pled that they made domestic transactions in securities not listed on a domestic exchange.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United States ex rel. Landis v. Tailwind Sports Corporation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil to hold officer and his separate investment company liable was unwarranted in relator's qui tam action against company that owned and managed professional cycling team, under False Claims Act, seeking to recover damages and penalties based on alleged fraudulent claims and statements made in connection with two sponsorship agreements with United States Postal Service (USPS); while allegations that officer used personal funds to pay corporate bills tended to show that there may have been some commingling of funds, this did not establish significant commingling required to show that there was such unity of interest and ownership to pierce corporate veil, and, even if relator had satisfied formalities prong of two-pronged test for determining whether to pierce corporate veil, he failed to show that company was undercapitalized, and thus did not satisfy fairness prong of that test. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3730(b)(1).
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator and government stated claim against former lead rider of professional cycling team under reverse false claims provision of False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, there was a lack of corporate separateness between subsidiary propane company, its parent, which was not-for-profit limited liability company (LLC), and its grandparent, which was electric cooperative, as required to pierce corporate veil in breach of contract and fraud action of buyer of propane company, although propane company paid its own salaries and other expenses, propane company purchased its own assets and did business with third parties separate from cooperative, propane company was never referred to as a division of cooperative or LLC, cooperative did not use propane company's assets in its business, and formal legal requirements of propane company were observed, where cooperative was sole owner of LLC, which in turn was sole owner of propane company, entities had at least one common officer, cooperative guaranteed loans and donated capital to propane company, proceeds from sale of propane company to buyer went directly into cooperative's financial account, cooperative permitted propane company to use its real estate, and cooperative's board of directors served as LLC's ownership group, which governed propane company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was a lack of corporate separateness between propane company, its parent, and its grandparent, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, continued recognition of subsidiary propane company would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce corporate veil in breach of contract and fraud action of buyer of propane company against parent and grandparent companies, where proceeds from buyer's purchase of propane company were transferred to grandparent company for nothing in return, such that if buyer was successful in its claims, it could not recover anything from propane company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was a lack of corporate separateness between propane company, its parent, and its grandparent, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Aguirre v. Best Care Agency, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations of Filipino national who came to the United States to work, that employers allegedly misrepresented their capability of sponsoring her for her green card, were sufficient to state a claim against employers for state law tort claims of fraudulent inducement and negligent misrepresentation, as required to pierce the corporate veil and hold the employers individually liable.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Migrant Workers. A fact issue existed as to whether employers abused the law or legal process in hiring a Filipino national to work for them.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: FutureSelect Portfolio Management, Inc. v. Tremont Group Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Investor's complaint adequately stated a claim against investment firm's parent and grandparent based upon agency, where investor alleged that firm came under their control, which included the manner by which firm offered investments, including the funds that were alleged to be feeder funds for Ponzi scheme, alleged that parent and grandparent learned of firm's enormous exposure with perpetrator of Ponzi scheme and firm's representations to the feeder funds' investors regarding its oversight and monitoring of perpetrator of scheme were false or, at a minimum, highly suspect, and investor's complaint and hypothetical facts supported the claim that parent and grandparent controlled investment firm and retained the right to direct the manner in which firm's work was performed.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Pleading. Investor's complaint adequately stated a claim against investment firm's parent and grandparent based upon agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: FutureSelect Portfolio Management, Inc. v. Tremont Group Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Investor's contentions in complaint that investment firm's parent and grandparent marketed firm as a member of grandparent's family of companies and listed firm in its annual reports as one of its general agencies and other offices, which led investor to believe that firm had the authority to offer and sell funds, which were allegedly feeder funds for Ponzi scheme, were sufficient to state a claim on the basis of apparent agency.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Pleading. Investor's complaint adequately stated a claim against investment firm's parent and grandparent based upon agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Living Hope Southwest Medical Services, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Insufficient evidence existed that lender, whose postpetition short-term bridge loans to Chapter 11 debtor were repaid through use of blank checks that had been pre-signed by debtor and given to lender's president, committed fraud or conversion, as required to enable piercing of the corporate veil under New York law; lender observed corporate formalities, its president had never mingled personal funds, and debtor maintained dominion over the funds, as it had the power to stop payment at any time.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Lender's postpetition loans to debtor were not in the ordinary course of business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Damon v. Groteboer
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, corporation which sold commercial real estate was sufficiently capitalized at time of its incorporation, as weighed against piercing corporate veil and exposing corporation's individual members to liability in purchasers' action for breach of fiduciary duties and fraud; even if corporation's right to purchase underlying land in commercial development was worth only $3.7 million, as purchasers contended, rather than $8.3 million, as corporation contended, corporation's assets were more than three times greater than its debts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced to subject corporation's members to liability for fraud and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Damon v. Groteboer
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Corporation which sold commercial real estate observed corporate formalities, as weighed against piercing corporate veil and exposing corporation's individual members to liability in purchasers' action for breach of fiduciary duties and fraud; although corporation did not hold regular board meetings, corporation maintained corporate bank account, filed tax returns, and maintained financial records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced to subject corporation's members to liability for fraud and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Damon v. Groteboer
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, nonpayment of dividends by corporation which sold commercial real estate did not support piercing corporate veil and exposing corporation's individual members to liability in purchasers' action for breach of fiduciary duties and fraud, since corporation used its profits, when it had them, to satisfy its obligations and fund construction.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced to subject corporation's members to liability for fraud and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Damon v. Groteboer
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, net income of corporation which sold commercial real estate was positive for years during which allegedly fraudulent real estate transaction occurred, as weighed against piercing corporate veil and exposing corporation's individual members to liability in purchasers' action for breach of fiduciary duties and fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced to subject corporation's members to liability for fraud and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Damon v. Groteboer
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Fact that chief financial officer (CFO) and secretary of close corporation which sold commercial real estate did nothing other than sign documents did not establish that corporation was merely instrumentality of its individual members, as would support piercing corporate veil and exposing members to liability in purchasers' action for breach of fiduciary duties and fraud; passive role of CFO was typical for close corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced to subject corporation's members to liability for fraud and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Damon v. Groteboer
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, corporation which sold commercial real estate maintained sufficient corporate records, as weighed against piercing corporate veil and exposing corporation's individual members to liability in purchasers' action for breach of fiduciary duties and fraud; although corporation kept no minutes of its meetings and passed no resolutions for any business other than financing, corporation maintained check register, tax records, financial records, documents relating to sales and loans, and organizational documents.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced to subject corporation's members to liability for fraud and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Damon v. Groteboer
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, corporation which sold commercial real estate did not serve as facade for its individual members, as would support piercing corporate veil and exposing members to liability in purchasers' action for breach of fiduciary duties and fraud; corporation maintained corporate bank account that was distinct from members' bank accounts and no members used corporate property or assets for personal financial gain.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced to subject corporation's members to liability for fraud and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Cancel v. Sewell
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Successor professional anesthesiology group that was formed several months after prior group, from which anesthesiologist resigned, was dissolved, was not liable on anesthesiologist's claims for conspiracy to defraud anesthesiologist of contractual rights, absent showing that successor group was alter ego of former group.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS - Free Speech. Plaintiff did not show that termination was state action, as required to support claim for violation of right of free speech under Georgia Constitution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Gieseke ex rel. Diversified Water Diversion, Inc. v. IDCA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Proof of strict common law fraud is not required to establish whether piercing the corporate veil is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness, but, rather, evidence that the corporate entity has been operated as a constructive fraud or in an unjust manner must be presented.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. A claim of tortious interference with prospective advantage is a valid tort claim under Minnesota law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: SMS Assist L.L.C. v. East Coast Lot & Pavement Maintenance Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, snow removal subcontractors' sole owner was not their alter ego, as would justify piercing corporate veil and holding owner liable in contractor's action alleging fraud and breach of contract; although owner asserted complete control and intermingled funds between subcontractors, subcontractors observed corporate formalities, did not comingle assets with those of owner, and were capitalized with significant assets.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Snow removal contractor could not prevail on its fraud claim against subcontractor under Illinois law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Dynacorp Ltd. v. Aramtel Ltd.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Corporate owner's false representation to investors regarding his intent to transfer ownership of corporation to investors constituted actual fraud warranting piercing of the corporate veil for purposes of fraudulent inducement claim against owner stemming from failed joint venture to provide wireless telecommunications network in Iraq.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Exercise of personal jurisdiction over non-resident defendants was warranted in action stemming from failed joint venture.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Juve
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Managerial employee who, at time he first approached salesman at car dealership about loaning funds to dealership, ostensibly for purpose of purchasing additional vehicles for sale on lot, did not yet have ownership interest in dealership and had salesman write checks to dealership as means of concealing his misconduct while manipulating corporate form to facilitate his individual scheming, was individually liable for the more than $350,000 in funds which salesman was duped into loaning by false assurances that loans were secured by vehicles that he saw on lot; piercing corporate veil was appropriate and necessary, even assuming that there was a veil to pierce, given that, if corporation had functioning officers and directors, they were not functioning with respect to salesman's purported loans to dealership, and given that manager/owner had used corporate facade to facilitate and conceal his fraudulent activity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's false representations and omissions rendered debt nondischargeable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: 904 Tower Apartment LLC v. Mark Hotel LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Purchasers of luxury apartments in mixed hotel and cooperative apartment development stated claim against developers, under New York law, for alter ego liability for breach of contract and fraud by alleging that defendants either owned or were principals and controlling members of developer, had used available cash for the most pressing needs of any one of their several hotels or related operations, used common office space and employees to run their numerous operations, and generally operated all of their affiliates as a unified enterprise without heeding corporate formalities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Sales of luxury apartments did not fall within scope of New York's Deceptive Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Barkley v. United Homes, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, evidence was sufficient to support a finding of liability as to all of the related home renovation entities involved in fraudulent property-flipping conspiracy, even though not all of the entities were directly involved in the sales transactions with all of the purchasers; entities failed to observe corporate formalities, such that one or more entities financed the operations of the other entities, entities' corporate lines were totally blurred, all of the entities were involved in advertising real estate development services, and all of the entities shared a single trade name.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Rescission of mortgage was not warranted based on fraudulent property-flipping conspiracy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Heisz v. Galt Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Evidence did not support trial court's finding that buyer's president misused his control over buyer, related companies, and president's investment company as required for seller to pierce the corporate veil in action alleging breach of contract and fraud, although president negotiated the terms of transactions between investment company and companies that were related to buyer, and an entity related to buyer made a $52,000 payment to the investment company, where evidence that president directed transfers between the companies was not itself evidence of misuse, but, related to the first element of the alter ego analysis, namely, whether he controlled the companies, and president testified that the payments were for consulting services performed by the investment company, and there was no evidence that such services were not performed or that they were billed at an excessive rate.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Circumstantial evidence regarding intent to deceive as required for fraud claim is not limited to events after misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Olson v. Hunter's Point Homes, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Subdivision vendor's agents and employees were potentially liable, under a piercing the corporate veil theory, for any fraudulent statement which corporate vendor made to purchasers regarding existence of any utility easements and building code violations on the subject properties.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Economic loss doctrine did not bar fraud claims against vendor regarding existence of easements and code compliance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: S.E.C. v. Woolf
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Promotional speakers who traveled across the country inducing inexperienced investors into buying seminar packages and trading stocks using their respective companies' investment strategies, and who also served as presidents of their respective corporations, were not personally liable for their corporations' alleged securities fraud, based on theory of alter ego under either Utah or Virginia law, since there was no evidence that either president dominated or controlled their corporations to evade personal obligation or to perpetuate the fraud. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, § 10(b), 15 U.S.C.A. § 78j(b); 17 C.F.R. § 240.10b–5.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Complaint stated claim for securities fraud against promotional speakers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Carroll
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: No piercing of corporate veil was required in order to permit prospective franchisee of corporate franchisor controlled by Chapter 13 debtor to assert claim in debtor's bankruptcy case for injury that he sustained as result of being fraudulently induced to pursue restaurant franchisee due to intentional misrepresentations made by debtor as agent for franchisor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Court had authority to finally resolve dischargeability issue, though it first had to liquidate claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Moll Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Alleged conduct of secured lenders, in repeatedly failing to declare corporate debtor in default, in easing terms of secured loan agreements, and in writing down some of debt, and in using control that they allegedly possessed over corporate borrower to compel borrower to purchase assets which were not alleged to have resulted in loss to borrower, would not rise to level of fraudulent misconduct needed for alter ego claim under Delaware law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Lenders' secured claims could not be recharacterized as equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Investor in real estate rehabilitation corporation and limited liability company (LLC) established actual fraud requirement under Texas statute imposing additional requirements for piercing the corporate veil in cases based on claims for breach of contract in seeking to hold principal for corporation and LLC personally liable for damages awarded against corporation and LLC where company and LLC, through principal, made material misrepresentations to investor from outset of their relationship, principal knew that investments worked only if funds loaned by investor for property repairs were used solely for that purpose but did not disclose his belief that he could use loan funds for other purposes, and corporation and LLC, acting through principal, never intended to comply with terms of agreements with investor. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Real estate rehabilitation businesses perpetrated actual fraud against investor primarily for their principal's direct personal benefit, as required for investor to satisfy additional requirements under Texas statute for piercing the corporate veil in cases based on claims for breach of contract, so as to hold principal personally liable for damages awarded against businesses; businesses, organized as corporation and limited liability company (LLC), were wholly owned and controlled by principal, who was only one who stood to benefit from their continued operations, principal knew that he would lose his livelihood if businesses failed, and principal used investor's loan proceeds to make distributions and advances to himself, enabling him to continue to support his family and lifestyle. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.
