Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, investor in real estate rehabilitation companies, one organized as corporation and other as limited liability company (LLC), could not use "sham to perpetrate a fraud" theory to pierce the corporate veil and hold companies' principal liable for companies' fraud, since companies were not resorted to as means of evading existing legal obligation, and principal did not transfer assets among companies to use corporate form to shield assets from creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Expert South Tulsa, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: A finding of fact of alter ego, standing alone, creates no cause of action under Oklahoma law; it merely imposes liability against a second corporation or individual upon an underlying cause of action, such as fraud or breach of contract, brought against the first corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. Postpetition actions taken against debtor's principals in state court violated automatic stay, and were void.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Wuliger v. Swiss Re Life & Health America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Receiver's allegations that the insurer accepted premiums on policies it thought were void was sufficient to plead a claim for piercing the corporate veil. The insurer wholly owned other insurance companies which allegedly accepted premiums on policies they thought were void. The receiver would have to present evidence that the insurer directed the underlying fraud of accepting undeserved premiums.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Receiver's allegations that the insurer accepted undeserved premiums was sufficient to plead a claim for piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Antone's Records, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Claims asserted by probate estate of deceased musician against recording companies for which he recorded two albums, for fraudulent misrepresentations allegedly made to musician regarding payment of royalties to which he was entitled under recording agreement, for fiduciary breaches arising from failure to provide royalty statements or delay in payment of royalties, and for imposition of constructive trust on proceeds generated from sale of albums, were all claims "relating to or arising from" musician's recording agreement with companies, such that corporate veil could not be pierced to hold companies' principals personally liable on such claims absent showing of actual fraudulent conduct on their part, a showing that estate representatives failed to make. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Showing of actual fraud was necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Atateks Foreign Trade, Ltd. v. Private Label Sourcing, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Transfer of commission payments to dominating corporation, which should have been paid to dominated corporation, was wrong resulting in injury to creditor, as required for claim of constructive fraud under New York law, favoring piercing corporate veil, even if commissions had been paid before parties' business relationship broke down, since transfer exacerbated insolvency of dominated corporation and rendered it less able to pay damages.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego could be jointly and severally liable for all damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Atateks Foreign Trade, Ltd. v. Private Label Sourcing, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Liability in amount of $1.5 million could be imposed on dominating corporation under New York law for being dominated corporation's alter ego, although only $306,000 in commissions that should have been paid to dominated corporation had been paid to dominating corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego could be jointly and severally liable for all damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: TechTarget, Inc. v. Spark Design, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a corporate veil may be pierced when the parent exercises some form of pervasive control of the activities of the subsidiary and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Advertising firm could not pierce the corporate veil of client.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Vanderbilt Mortg. and Finance, Inc. v. Flores
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Corpus Christi Division.
Headnote: Under alter ego doctrine, pursuant to Texas law, parent company can be found liable if: (1) parent exercised complete control over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such control was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Manufactured home purchasers had standing to sue under Texas fraudulent lien statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Dana v. Shopping Time Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Allegations that owner of corporate defendants in fraud action exercised complete domination over the corporate defendants, abusing the privilege of operating in a corporate form, and thereby perpetrating a wrong which harmed the appellants justified piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Plaintiffs sufficiently alleged fraud claim against owner of defendant corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Kriegel v. Bank of America, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Banking corporation could not be held directly liable for alleged fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, negligent misrepresentation, and violations of Washington's Consumer Protection Act (WCPA) that purportedly arose from automatic renewal of certificate of deposit (CD) by corporation's subsidiary. While corporation and subsidiary clearly had similar names, the deposit agreement governing the CD specifically defined the name of the bank as referring to the subsidiary. Customer's relationship was solely with the subsidiary. West's RCWA 19.86.020.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Banking corporation could not be held directly liable regarding automatic renewal of certificate of deposit by subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Robinson v. Weymer
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut, Judicial District of Ansonia-Milford.
Headnote: Home buyers sufficiently stated a fraud claim against a homebuilder corporation under the instrumentality rule. The buyers alleged that the homebuilder owned the property upon which the home was built and that the homebuilder accepted payments despite the fact that its manager had no intention of constructing the portion of the home which the buyers sought to live in. The buyers also alleged that the lone member and manager of the homebuilder ignored the formalities of corporate procedure in operating the homebuilder and operated the homebuilder from his home.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Home buyers sufficiently stated a fraud claim against a homebuilder corporation under the instrumentality rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Pacific Rollforming, LLC v. Trakloc North America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: An investment company was not the alter ego of a financial manager for purposes of liability in a building supply manufacturer's claim against the company and manager for breach of contract, fraud and other business torts under California law. The manager allegedly failed to perform his promise of funding the capital contribution from the company to the manufacturer. A pre-incorporation agreement, which was expressly referenced in the operative complaint, contained a provision which negated this allegation. It stated that should the manager fail to make either of two investment payments in the time prescribed, he would forfeit his entire interest in the company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. An investment company was not the alter ego of a financial manager.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Campagnolo S.R.L. v. Full Speed Ahead, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Parent company did not exercise total domination over subsidiary sufficient to be vicariously liable in a false advertising action. While parent company was able to exercise some control over subsidiary and is nearly the sole-supplier to subsidiary, parent company did not exercise any control of the day-to-day operations of subsidiary. There was no overlap between parent and subsidiary employees, and no subsidiary employees reported to any employees of the parent company. Further, no evidence existed that parent company had any oversight over the content of subsidiary company's advertising.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent company did not exercise total domination over subsidiary sufficient to be vicariously liable in a false advertising action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Jones & Trevor Marketing, Inc. v. Lowry
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Two sole shareholders and officers of marketing corporation and sales fulfillment corporation did not use corporations as a facade for officers' operations, and therefore officers could not be held to be the alter egos of corporations absent evidence of other alter ego factors, in case involving allegations of breach of contract and various torts including fraudulent misrepresentation; although officers took money from one corporation when it was struggling to meet its other financial obligations, the money was accounted for, and there was no evidence that the accounting was done improperly. Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 56(c).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Two sole shareholders and officers of corporation did not use corporation as facade.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Ireland v. Dodson
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, substantive fraud claims were subject to higher standard of proof than alter ego claims, and thus jury's rejection of buyers' claim that seller corporation had engaged in fraud was not inconsistent with its decision to pierce corporate veil to hold seller's principal's father personally liable for breach of contract to sell aircraft and radio equipment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Brokerage agreement between aircraft sales corporation and its principal's father did not justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Colorado Coffee Bean, LLC v. Peaberry Coffee Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. IV.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish, in trial of fraudulent nondisclosure action that franchisees brought against franchisor and franchisor's parent company for failing to disclose that parent company suffered significant losses every year, that parent company was not the alter ego of the franchisor; there was no evidence that franchisor was formed for fraudulent purposes, there was evidence that corporate formalities were not disregarded, and there was no expert testimony concerning the appropriate level of capital for franchisor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Exculpatory clauses did not preclude franchisees from reasonably relying on the nondisclosure of parent company's losses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: U.S. S.E.C. v. Levine
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Defendants, who acted through privately held corporate entities that they used to perpetrate their fraud against investors, were the alter egos of those entities under Nevada law; defendants were either the sole officers and directors of corporate entities or equitable owners of those corporations which their daughter was listed as sole officer and director, each corporation paid for all manner of defendants' personal expenses, continually transferred funds among each other, and were all run out of the defendants' home, sharing the same computer. West's NRSA 78.747.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Appointment of receiver over defendants' corporate entities was appropriate contempt sanction for violation of injunction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Stone
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, in action against investor who purchased the assets of seller's business through a fraudulent scheme, it was appropriate to pierce the corporate veil of investor's companies; investor used the companies as mere instruments in order to defraud seller and his business, the business's assets were transferred from seller to investor's companies by design to defraud seller and the old company's creditors, and investor controlled these entities and disregarded their corporate form, all to the detriment of seller and his old company.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. Attorney's participation in fraudulent scheme warranted his permanent disbarment from practice before the bankruptcy court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: JNS Aviation, Inc. v. Nick Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, a claimant may use either actual fraud or constructive fraud to pierce the corporate veil in tort claims.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Bankruptcy court properly pierced debtor's corporate veil to hold nondebtor owners liable for judgment debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: GEM Advisors, Inc. v. Corporacion Sidenor, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Consulting firm adequately pled that Spanish parent corporation exercised its dominance over subsidiary to commit fraud or wrong that injured firm as required to pierce subsidiary's corporate veil under New York law for purpose of parent's liability on claims alleging that subsidiary breached letter agreement with firm by selling Mexican steel mills without paying required fees for New York firm's services in finding buyer and that subsidiary fraudulently misrepresented mills' ownership structure; defendants allegedly fraudulently and repeatedly represented that parent had no direct ownership in mills, thus causing firm to enter into and perform under the letter agreements without requiring parent to bind itself to a separate agreement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiary acted as corporation's agent for purposes of personal jurisdiction over corporation in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: J. Criss Builder, Inc. v. White
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: Owner of building company, which was a corporation, was subject to individual liability to homeowners in their suit against owner and company alleging breach of warranty, negligence, and failure to disclose regarding construction of homeowners' home, which allegedly had foundation defects, as owner was a licensed residential builder, company did not have builder's license, such that it was prohibited from performing residential construction, and, thus, owner, in her individual capacity, was the licensed builder of home. West's A.M.C. §§ 73-59-1(b), 73-59-3(1), 73-59-9(3).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Trial court's grant of additur absent required statutory findings was abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Longhi v. Mazzoni
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's finding that manager of development company used the company to support fraud, warranting decision to pierce the corporate veil and hold manager of company personally liable for a $50,000 down payment that purchasers gave the company toward the purchase of a subdivision lot and construction of home, which construction never began and the deed to which lot was never transferred; purchasers relied on manager's assurances that they were going to receive a home in the development, manager did not tell purchasers he was using their down payment as capital for the project or that home construction was contingent on more purchasers, the half-price manager offered was an attempt to induce purchasers, who were life-long friends, into giving him a large deposit, and the down payment was not held as earnest money but was used to finance the development project.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil and treble damages were warranted where manager of development company used down payment on home as investment capital.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Marlyn Nutraceuticals, Inc. v. Improvita Health Products
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Corporate veil need not have been pierced, under Arizona law, to assert fraud or negligence claims against corporate officers.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Arizona court had specific jurisdiction over Ohio buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Equity Trust Co. Custodian ex rel. Eisenmenger IRA v. Cole
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Principals were personally involved in the ownership, management, and operation of corporate entities involved in a large-scale real estate fraud scheme, and principals were alter egos of the entities, and thus corporate veil could be pierced so as to make principals personally liable for default judgment entered against entities; principals had oral agreement dividing ownership shares in the entities, were treated as officers or directors of the entities with equal authority to act on behalf of the entities, were actively involved in managing the entities and marketing entities' investment schemes, principals did not observe corporate formalities, entities were undercapitalized and not financially independent, and principals transferred and withdrew large sums of money between and from entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of entities involved in real estate fraud could be pierced under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Sole shareholder's use of corporation to commit securities fraud upon investors in pooled investment fund managed by corporation did not satisfy element of Connecticut's instrumentality rule requiring that principal's domination of corporation be used to commit wrongful act for purposes of reverse veil piercing defense asserted by shareholder's former wife and her former business to fraudulent transfer claim in corporation's Chapter 7 case, given that investors were not defendants in fraudulent transfer action. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544(b); C.G.S.A. § 52-552e(a)(2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There was no basis for finding that the corporate forms of affiliated corporate entities could be disregarded such that they could be liable for commodities fraud under a theory of common enterprise liability; complaint included nothing more than conclusory allegations that corporate defendants were "a tightly knit association-in-fact" and that they shared common ownership and offices.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Commodity Futures. Market manipulation claim under Commodity Exchange Act was not stated against CEO of investment advisory company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under statute allowing piercing of the corporate veil when shareholder engaged in fraud, receiver of insolvent health maintenance organization (HMO) could not bring negligent misrepresentation claim against seller of HMO; cause of action for negligent misrepresentation was not same as that for fraud, which required specific intent. LSA–R.S. 12:93(B), 12:95.
Document Preview: HEALTH - HMOs. Seller and buyer of health maintenance organization did not operate as single business enterprise prior to or after sale.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Indest-Guidry, Ltd. v. Key Office Equipment, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to find president of office equipment corporation personally liable was proper in suit by printing company against equipment corporation for fraud, conversion, and breach of contract, even though there was no evidence introduced at trial to dispute the distinction between the equipment corporation and the president as a natural person; printing company alleged fraud and deceit against president and named him individually in its petition, and president breached the duty of care through personal fault by his negotiations and personal representations. LSA–R.S. 12:93(B), 12:95.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Printing company was a consumer within meaning of the Louisiana Unfair Trade Practices Act (LUTPA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: There was no basis for finding that the corporate forms of family of hedge funds could be disregarded under New York law so as to subject those funds which did not directly manipulate the commodities market to liability for alleged market manipulations by other related funds; there were no allegations of the disregard of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of funds or property, reduced discretion by any entity, failure to deal at arms' length, or payment of the debts of one entity by another and plaintiff investors failed to plead commingling of funds or any shared use of resources that would permit the application of common enterprise doctrine. Commodity Exchange Act, § 22(a)(1), 7 U.S.C.A. § 25(a)(1).
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Commodity Futures. Repeatedly sale of futures before close of settlement period gave rise to commodities manipulation claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Olzens v. Lapuh
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: President and shareholder of moving corporation did not exercise control over corporation in such a way as to commit fraud or an illegal act against customers who used the corporation's services to move to a different state, and thus president and shareholder did not incur personal liability, on a theory of piercing the corporate veil, for losses suffered by customers when their personal belongings were damaged or lost during move.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Purported agent of non-existing moving corporation could be personally liable for losses from lost and damaged belongings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Carp v. Dunn
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiffs failed to establish a prima facie case for piercing corporate veil of defendant's corporation, and thus defendant was entitled to judgment as a matter of law, in plaintiffs' action for breach of contract and fraud; although defendant conceded that he exercised complete dominion and control over corporation, there was no evidence that he used corporate vehicle to commit fraud or perpetrate a wrong that caused plaintiffs' injury. McKinney's CPLR 4401.
Document Preview: TORTS - Trial. Defendant was entitled to judgment as a matter of law, in action for breach of contract and fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: DeWitt v. Sealtex Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Limited liability company (LLC), which had as its two members two of three shareholders of insolvent corporation, did not use the corporation to commit a fraud, as was required to permit corporation's unsecured creditors to recover on claim that the corporation was the LLC's alter ego, and to thereby attach liability to the LLC; the creditors' losses were caused by the corporation's economic collapse, and were not due to a relationship between the corporation and the LLC.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Creditor of insolvent corporation could not prevail on claim of successor liability in commercial credit protection context.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: GIW Industries, Inc. v. JerPeg Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: There was no evidence that corporation's two officers and shareholders conducted their private and corporate business on interchangeable or joint basis as if they were one, and therefore, under Georgia law, corporate veil could not be pierced under excessive commingling theory to hold one officer-shareholder personally liable on customer's fraud claim against corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Officer-shareholder was protected by corporate veil under Georgia law from individual liability on fraud claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Axtmann v. Chillemi
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish a basis to pierce the corporate veil, in action brought against corporation/judgment debtor and corporation's shareholder and officers by judgment creditors, who had obtained their judgment in part on a jury finding that corporation/judgment debtor committed fraud; corporation was structured to meet the statutory requirements for a real estate brokerage firm and trust accounts, other than the funds that corporation's sole shareholder used to purchase predecessor business corporation's principals did not provide any further capital infusion into the corporation, and there was evidence that corporation did not make any provisions for assets to cover foreseeable liabilities, that corporation never made a profit, that corporation was merely a vehicle to pass commissions through to real estate agents, and that corporation was undercapitalized.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Judgment debtor's assignment of listing services contracts to new corporation did not constitute a fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: General Retail Services, Inc. v. Wireless Toyz Franchise, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Alleged misrepresentations identified in corporate franchisor's marketing materials and offering circular could not be attributed under Texas law to officers of affiliated corporation in absence of alter ego claim, where officers of affiliate did not make any representations, much less misrepresentations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction existed over franchisor's non-resident officer with regard to pre-contract misrepresentations claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Solutioneers Consulting, Ltd. v. Gulf Greyhound Partners, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Advertising business, a corporation that solicited corporate sponsorship for clients, was not its owner's "alter ego," as required by the Texas Business Corporation Act in order for owner to be held personally liable for business's fraudulent conduct in failing to forward corporate sponsorship funds to a client, absent evidence that owner enjoyed direct personal benefits resulting from the fraud. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A).
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Evidence supported jury finding that advertising company and its owner committed fraud by misrepresentation and omission.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Country Village Homes, Inc. v. Patterson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Actual fraud was not an independent ground of recovery when home purchasers tried to pierce the corporate veil under the Single Business Enterprise and Alter Ego theories, in their breach of contract and fraud action against builder, developer, related businesses and common owner, and thus a separate question on and a jury finding of actual fraud was not required in order to pierce the corporate veil. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21; Vernon's Ann.Texas Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 279.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Error in failing to instruct actual fraud was an element of Single Business Enterprise theory was not preserved for appeal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Injustice or inequity stemming from alleged fraud of title insurance company agents was not caused by or did not stem from the alleged disregard of the separate corporate identity between title insurance company and its majority stockholder, as to support the second prong of alter ego test requiring piercing the corporate veil, absent evidence that stockholder became a majority stockholder with the fraudulent intent of shielding itself from liability or that stockholder depleted the resources of the title insurance company in order to make it judgment proof.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Berglund v. Cynosure, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, franchisor was not mere agent or instrumentality of 40% shareholder, and, thus, shareholder was not liable for franchisor's alleged fraudulent representations to potential franchisees on theory of piercing corporate veil, even though shareholder guaranteed some leases of franchisor and had supply contract with franchisor for laser hair removal machines manufactured by shareholder and shareholder's founder served on franchisor's board of directors.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Franchisor's shareholder was not liable for franchisor's alleged misrepresentations to franchisees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Corestar Intern. Pte. Ltd. v. LPB Communications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, failure to show that any executives of seller of radio transmitters had acted other than in their capacities as officers precluded claim of individual liability through piercing corporate veil, on grounds that corporate form had been used as vehicle for committing equitable or legal fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Seller of radio transmitters violated delivery requirements of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Kalin v. Xanboo, Inc
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, privately held corporation's principals' alleged scheme to fraudulently induce employee to exchange his stock for incentive stock options (ISO) that principals knew employee would never be able to exercise could not be attributed to another company that principals controlled, even if employee was also employed by other company, and companies were interrelated, where there was no indication that corporation's recovery of employee's stock benefited second company, that principals purported to represent second company during meeting at which they made misrepresentations, or that second company dominated corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Corporation's principals' alleged scheme to fraudulently induce employee could not be attributed to related company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Formosa Plastics Corp., USA v. Kajima Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: A showing that corporate project owner used its wholly-owned subsidiary to perpetuate an actual fraud on contractor was not required to find that project owner and subsidiary constituted a single business enterprise that could be held liable to contractor for fraud arising from contracts, where project owner, and not subsidiary, signed contracts, and jury found project owner guilty of its own fraud. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A)(2).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Experts. Expert was not disqualified in fraud action on basis of colleague's prior consultation with opposing party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Formosa Plastics Corp., USA v. Kajima Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Corporate project owner and its wholly-owned subsidiary constituted a "single business enterprise" that could be held liable to contractor for fraud, where companies had common employees during relevant time period, companies shared common offices, companies had a centralized or coordinated accounting system to the extent they related to approval of construction change orders with regard to project, companies shared a common business name, and employees of one company rendered services on behalf of the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Experts. Expert was not disqualified in fraud action on basis of colleague's prior consultation with opposing party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Williams v. Younginer
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that vendor, individually, was liable to purchasers for constructive fraud in failing to disclose the leaky condition of basement in home sold to purchasers, given that vendor signed purchase agreement in his individual, rather than in his capacity as agent of the corporation.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Deeds. Implied warranties of habitability and workmanship did not merge into the deed conveying the property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Prymas v. Kassai
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Business owner failed to show that corporate contractor's vice-president exercised such control over corporation or that vice-president committed fraud, to warrant piercing of the corporate veil to hold vice-president personally liable on business owner's claims of trespass and fraud relating to contractor's installation of sewer line across owner's property.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Trial. Refusal to instruct the jury on an easement by estoppel defense to a trespass claim was an abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Tamko Roofing Products, Inc. v. Smith Engineering Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, an inequitable result would not occur based on failure to hold parent corporation liable for judgment obtained against wholly owned subsidiary, in action for fraudulent misrepresentation, breach of contract, and breach of warranty, and thus, alter ego doctrine would not be invoked against parent corporation; there was no showing that parent corporation was involved with any fraud against judgment creditor, or that parent corporation knew what representations that subsidiary made to judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Alter ego doctrine would not be invoked against parent corporation for conduct of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Widlar v. Young
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Customer of dating referral company failed to present evidence that company's principal exercised control over company in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against customer, and thus corporate veil could not be pierced to hold principal personally liable for company's acts; customer did not even allege that principal committed outright fraud, but rather sought to pierce the corporate veil on the basis of unfairness and inequity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Customer of dating referral company failed to present evidence that principal used his control of company to commit fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Upperman v. Grange Indemn. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Common Pleas of Ohio, Franklin County.
Headnote: Insureds stated claim to pierce the corporate veil and hold parent corporation liable for automobile insurers' alleged fraud and violation of statutory requirement to file rate increase with Department of Insurance; vice president's letter showing awareness of decision not to refund the illegally charged premiums was unclear as to his position with regard to parent or subsidiaries. R.C. § 3937.03(A, H).
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Premiums. Insureds had implied private right of action against automobile insurers for charging unfiled rates.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Olympic Forest Products, Ltd. v. Cooper
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil, in order to hold corporations' former principal personally liable for alleged fraud and conversion based on failure to repay creditor at time of sale of corporations' assets, was not warranted under Michigan law by principal's decision to pay other creditors first, leaving insufficient funds to satisfy creditor; regardless of reasonableness of principal's decision, there was no showing of concealment of funds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted by principal's decision to pay some creditors, not repay another.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Parmalat Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Class of shareholders in Italian company, which was audited by Italian affiliate of global accounting firm prior to company's collapse upon the discovery of a massive fraud that reportedly involved the understatement of its debt and the overstatement of its net assets, did not adequately alleged an alter ego relationship under New York law between global firm and its United States affiliate such that United States affiliate could be vicariously liable for the alleged securities fraud committed by Italian affiliate; without pleading any facts that would tend to show that United States affiliate used the close relationship to dominate global firm, an alter ego relationship could not be inferred from the close relationship and overlap in executives.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Global accounting firm was subject to liability for alleged securities fraud committed by Italian member firm.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Aoki
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the First Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was appropriate under Massachusetts law, where principals siphoned money from corporation and used corporation and their other corporations to perpetrate frauds; principals exercised pervasive control over corporation and were sole shareholders, officers, and directors, and financial records that principals did maintain were permeated with confused intermingling of corporate funds, undocumented loans between corporations, unexplained and undocumented cash withdrawals from each of the corporations for personal use of principals, use of corporate funds for personal expenses of principals, and unexplained payments to daughters of principals.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced where principals siphoned money from corporation and used corporation to perpetrate frauds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Aoki
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the First Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced under Massachusetts law to hold wife of corporate principal liable to investor for fraud, where husband consulted with wife from time to time at their home during negotiations with fraud victim, wife was involved in drafting or editing agreement which was used to perpetrate fraud, she signed various agreements on behalf of corporation, including one of addendums to agreement, and she handled companies' accounts, signed checks, and authorized transfers of money.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced where principals siphoned money from corporation and used corporation to perpetrate frauds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Robert A. Saurber General Contractor, Inc. v. McAndrews
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Twelfth District, Butler County.
Headnote: Sufficient evidence supported trial court's decision to pierce the corporate veil and hold subcontractor's sole officer and shareholder personally liable to general contractor in action for breach of contract, fraud, and conversion; officer completely dominated and controlled subcontractor, which was undercapitalized, officer, who received overpayments for labor and materials, defrauded general contractor through his control of subcontractor, and officer's conduct caused general contractor to incur additional project costs from hiring another subcontractor and paying material suppliers that subcontractor failed to pay.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sufficient evidence supported piercing corporate veil to hold subcontractor's sole officer personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Cass v. Stephens
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish, in breach of contract, conversion and fraud action brought by owners of working interests in oil and gas wells against well operator, that operator used his corporation to commit an actual fraud upon working interest owners and thus that corporation was the alter ego of operator; there was evidence that the wells in question were billed by the corporation for goods and services provided to wells owned only by operator and his family, that delivery tickets and invoices were modified by operator to divert expenses from operator's wells to wells in question, and that operator personally benefited from the misallocation of expenses to wells in question. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Damages. Award of $7.5 million in punitive damages for General's widow in action against well operator was excessive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Hyundai Motors America, Inc. v. Ace A Dent, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, shareholders were not alter egos of corporation and, therefore, were not liable for its alleged fraud on theory of piercing the corporate veil, even though the shareholders had obtained credit cards for the corporation and had signed its tax returns; they did not make decisions on behalf of the corporation, and accountant testified that the shareholders never directed her to pay kickbacks.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholders were not alter egos of corporation in connection with its alleged fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Unique Envelope Corp. v. GS America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Although he lacked official control over buyer during the relevant period, individual defendant, who had actual control, was the alter ego of buyer and therefore was liable under Illinois law for buyer's breach of contract with envelope supplier and fraud against supplier; the ever domineering presence and authoritarian hand of individual defendant in every business dealing resulted in supplier not getting paid for goods shipped to buyer at the same time that buyer's assets were being transferred to another corporation controlled by defendant for inadequate consideration in violation supplier's rights as buyer's creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual defendant was alter ego of buyer despite lack of official control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Rutherford v. Atwood
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Absent any evidence that sole shareholder's draws from remodelling corporation's account related to the remodeling contract between homeowners and corporation or were primarily for shareholder's direct personal benefit, homeowners could not pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder liable for corporation's fraudulent conduct, even though some draws were for personal and family use, where some draws were also used to pay personnel and suppliers on other jobs. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21A(2) of the Business Corporation Act.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Though corporate veil could not be pierced, sole shareholder was personally liable for his own fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Moran v. Schurger
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil was not warranted, where shareholder did not intend to defraud or mislead anyone and the corporation was not organized or used by shareholder to mislead creditors or to perpetrate a fraud upon them.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing was not warranted in absence of intentional fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Evergreen Security, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court could not pierce corporate veil in order to hold investment broker's president and shareholder personally liable for fraudulent transfers that broker received, in form of commission payments for soliciting "investors" to put money in Ponzi scheme operated by Chapter 11 debtor, where broker was not set up to perpetrate fraud and was not operated or used as its president's alter ego, but was a legitimate, long-term family business, that was eventually destroyed by conduct of its president in deciding, without even minimal due diligence, that broker should solicit investors for debtor. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 548(c).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Commissions paid for soliciting investors in Ponzi scheme were made with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: RNF Media, Inc. v. Lee
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Marketing company's principal could be personally liable to media company under alter ego doctrine for fraud; media company alleged that principal misappropriated money client paid to marketing company for advertising space and time scheduled and paid for by media company and alleged that principal dominated marketing company and intermingled assets.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal could be personally liable under alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Xytest Corp. v. Somerset Capital Corp.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Defunct corporation and its former shareholders after revocation of corporate charter were alter egos of each other making shareholder responsible for fraud in representing existence and viability of the corporation to assist in a corporate merger; she was corporation's senior vice president and had worked full time for it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Mergers and Acquisition. Evidence established fraud by shareholders of defunct corporation in connection with merger attempt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Tubos de Acero de Mexico, S.A. v. American Intern. Inv. Corp., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, an action seeking to hold a corporate officer personally liable for fraud was separate from and did not require disregard of the corporate entity under the alter ego doctrine. LSA–R.S. 12:95.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Equipment lessor was a competitor of lessee and thus had standing to sue lessee under LUTPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Harwood v. International Estate Planners
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, investment corporation was the alter ego of its principals, and thus, corporate veil could be pierced to hold principals liable for defrauding elderly widow out of her investment funds, where corporation engaged in no required formalities, and principal-wife used corporate funds for her personal use.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Widow's apparent double recovery for fraudulent investment had to be reconsidered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Robbins Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under the doctrine of "reverse piercing," a corporation may be held liable if a dominant shareholder uses his position to commit a fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Creditor had no subrogation claim against debtor for rent payments made to stores' landlords.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Cooper Industries, Inc., Cooper Tools Div. v. Lagrand Tire Chains
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Allegedly defrauded seller of tire chains would not be allowed to pierce the corporate veil to reach the personal assets of a former company president, absent proof that she controlled any of the companies through which mail and wire communications were allegedly used to order tire chains for which payment was never intended.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Trustee was not shown to have exercised sufficient control of any enterprise to violate RICO.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Shelton v. Clements
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Builder's corporation was operated as alter ego of builder, allowing trial court to pierce builder's corporate veil in homeowner's action against builder for fraud and breach of contract associated with builder's failure to complete construction of home; corporation had no assets, builder used construction loan account to pay some of his own minor personal expenses, had billed owner for certain equipment and labor related to projects for other customers, purchased certain materials for the construction of owner's house on his personal credit cards, and, when he did not pay those debts, he later instructed those creditors to place liens on owner's house.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Evidence was sufficient to support finding that builder breached contract to construct log cabin.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Shanghai Automation Instrument Co., Ltd. v. Kuei
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, individual participants in joint venture and their corporations possessed sufficient unity of interest to warrant piercing of corporate veil, in fraud action by victimized joint venture partner; participants controlled corporations, comingled funds, and held themselves out as personally liable for corporate debts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Default judgment was entered against fewer than all defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Valley Regional Medical Center v. Wright
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Brownsville Division.
Headnote: Hospital, and company acquiring hospital, were not single entity, under Texas law, for purpose of piercing corporate veil and holding acquiring company liable for hospital's alleged misrepresentation of intent to hire physician as director of cardiovascular surgery; there was no showing of centralized accounting, payment of wages by one corporation to other corporation's employees, common business names, services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of other corporation, undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, or unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Mergers and Acquisition. Acquiring company did not assume contractual obligation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Valley Regional Medical Center v. Wright
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Brownsville Division.
Headnote: Company that had acquired hospital had not used it for fraudulent purposes, as required by Texas statute holding parent liable for contractual obligations of subsidiary, when representatives of hospital allegedly fraudulently represented that he would be considered for appointed director of cardiovascular surgery; there was no showing that representatives did not intend to select some physician as director, before decision was made to terminate search and make other arrangements. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Mergers and Acquisition. Acquiring company did not assume contractual obligation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Paul v. Destito
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Businesses were liable for punitive damages verdict in action brought by shareholder against other shareholders of corporation and other businesses owned by them, in which shareholder alleged fraud, negligent misrepresentation, conspiracy to breach fiduciary duty, negligent breach of fiduciary duty, and other claims, under theory of alter ego liability, where jury concluded that all corporate and individual defendants were alter egos of each other and should be treated as same personality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Status as shareholder and former director did not bar claim of alter eqo liability against other shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: McClellan v. Northridge Park Townhome Owners Ass'n, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: When a corporation is used by an individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, a court may disregard the corporate entity and treat the acts as if they were done by the individuals themselves or by the controlling corporation; the court will disregard the fiction of corporate entity.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Condominiums. Evidence supported finding that homeowners association was mere continuation of predecessor association.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Greater Hammond Community Services, Inc. v. Mutka
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Distinct corporations, even parent and subsidiary corporations, are presumed separate; to overcome this presumption, plaintiff must show that one corporation dominated another to the extent that the subordinate was the mere instrumentality of the dominant corporation, that the dominant corporation employed the subordinate to perpetrate a fraud, or that the capital placed in the subordinate was illusory or trifling compared to the business to be done and the risks of loss, and also must demonstrate that the defalcation of the corporations, for example, fraud, was the proximate cause of the injury sustained.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Immunity. Regional community services organization was not protected by Tort Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Texas-Ohio Gas, Inc. v. Mecom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Corporate creditor's claims against shareholders for fraud, fraudulent inducement, negligent misrepresentation, and tortious interference with a contract, based on alleged misrepresentations regarding nature of corporate acquisition to induce sale of natural gas to insolvent corporations on credit, were based on contractual obligation of the corporations and thus were governed exclusively by the shareholder liability provision of the Texas Business Corporation Act, which limited recovery to certain fraud-based claims, where there was no allegation that shareholders agreed to be personally liable or were liable under another statute. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Sanctions. Rule 13 sanctions were not warranted in corporate creditor's suit against shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Texas-Ohio Gas, Inc. v. Mecom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Corporate creditor's claim against shareholders for negligent misrepresentation, for allegedly misrepresenting nature of corporate acquisition to induce sale of natural gas to insolvent corporations on credit, was precluded by the shareholder liability provision of the Texas Business Corporation Act, which limited recovery to certain fraud-based claims. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Sanctions. Rule 13 sanctions were not warranted in corporate creditor's suit against shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Texas-Ohio Gas, Inc. v. Mecom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Corporate creditor's claim against shareholders for tortious interference with a contract, for allegedly mischaracterizing nature of corporate acquisition of existing customer to induce sale of natural gas to insolvent corporations on credit, was not barred by the shareholder liability provision of the Texas Business Corporation Act, which limited recovery to certain fraud-based claims, where fraud was alleged as means of interference. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Sanctions. Rule 13 sanctions were not warranted in corporate creditor's suit against shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re AVN Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Tennessee, Western Division.
Headnote: Claimant-indenture trustee, who alleged that Chapter 11 debtor-corporation was liable, under a theory of fraud, for losses sustained by Nevada corporation's noteholders, failed to establish a prima facie case for fraud; based on claimant's allegations, it was debtor's president, if anyone, who defrauded claimant and the noteholders, and debtor, as the mere instrumentality of its president, could not have been a co-participant in his fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Interests of fairness required court to give claimant chance to amend claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Madison Home Equities, Inc. v. Echeverria
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff who brought fraud claim based primarily on representation in letter from corporation that certain premises would be delivered vacant at closing, which was signed by corporation's sole shareholder, director, and officer in his corporate capacity, could not pierce corporate veil so as to impose personal liability on shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fraud plaintiff could not pierce corporate veil to recover against sole shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Townsends, Inc. v. Beaupre
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Corporate veil did not have to be pierced for the principal of an incorporated poultry wholesaler to be personally liable for any misrepresentations he may have made in connection with the wholesaler's credit arrangement with a poultry producer, provided that all the elements of a misrepresentation action were shown, where he was the wholesaler's president and sole stockholder and the only person aware of its complete financial condition, he alone provided the information used by wholesaler's accountant in compiling a financial statement for the producer, and he approved the statement before it was sent to the producer.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Poultry wholesaler's principal was not liable to credit-extending producer for misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Shamis v. Ambassador Factors Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Alleged successor corporation was not liable, on alter ego theory, for allegedly fraudulent invoicing practices of its shareholder in conduct of business of alleged predecessor; even assuming that shareholder exercised complete control over successor corporation, this control could not have been used to commit any wrong that proximately caused plaintiff's injuries, as successor was not incorporated until one-and-a-half years after plaintiff purportedly learned of these fraudulent billing practices.
Document Preview: Plaintiff sued to recover for injuries that he had allegedly sustained as result of defendant's allegedly fraudulent billing practices. Plaintiff also asserted claim against successor corporate entity on alter ego theory. Following denial of individual and corporate defendant's motions for summary judgment, 34 F.Supp.2d 879, defendants moved for reargument. The District Court, Sweet, J., held that: (1) individual defendant was not entitled to reargument, but (2) alleged successor corporation was not liable, on alter ego theory, for allegedly fraudulent invoicing practices of its shareholder in conduct of business of alleged predecessor. Reargument allowed as to corporate defendant; motion for summary judgment granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Stanford University Hosp. v. Federal Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, actions payroll tax service's sole shareholder and director, in misappropriating client funds, were attributable to the service, in order to avoid injustice of having clients' innocent third-party insurer pay for the misappropriation through its crime insurance coverage.
Document Preview: Insured nonprofit corporations brought suits seeking coverage, under crime insurance policies, for misappropriations by their payroll tax service. The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, Claudia Wilken, J., 1995 WL 912346, granted summary judgment for insureds, and insurer appealed. The Court of Appeals, Keep, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) payroll tax service was authorized representative of insureds within meaning of exclusionary clause, and (2) thefts of insureds' funds by officers and employees of payroll tax service were acts of authorized representatives under the exclusion. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Mars Electronics of N.Y., Inc. v. U.S.A. Direct, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Sole shareholder's domination of corporation, with respect to two specific transactions, was used to perpetrate a fraud against judgment creditor so as to warrant piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable under New York law; however, absent evidence of fraud or wrongful conduct, there was an insufficient basis under New York law upon which to pierce corporate veil as to remaining transactions.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor of corporation sought to hold corporation's sole shareholder personally liable for the judgment. Upon creditor's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Trager, J., held that: (1) evidence established that sole shareholder dominated and controlled every aspect of corporation's business affairs such as to render corporation shareholder's alter ego under New York law, and (2) shareholder's domination of corporation, with respect to two specific transactions, was used to perpetrate a fraud against judgment creditor so as to warrant piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable under New York law. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Speir v. Krieger
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Despite defendant's claim that he had resigned from corporations, he was corporate officer liable, under veil piercing theory, for fraudulent operation of corporations; corporate registry still listed him as corporate secretary and registered agent. (Per Eldridge, J., with two Judges concurring and three Judges concurring in judgment).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Officers of automobile lessor were liable for insurance fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Olympic Financial Ltd. v. Consumer Credit Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
