Headnote: Generalized promise by automobile seller that it would properly handle proceeds from sale of vehicles repossessed by finance company was too general to support claim for fraud, as required, under Texas law, to hold other dealers liable with seller as single business entity, for seller's failure to remit sales proceeds. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21, subd. A(2).
Document Preview: Finance company sued automobile seller for breach of consignment contract under which seller sold repossessed automobiles, and also against other dealers with which finance company had master dealership agreements. On defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Atlas, J., held that: (1) seller and other dealers were not operated as single business entity; (2) there was no actual fraud by seller; and (3) there was no fiduciary duty on part of seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Huffman v. Poore
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was not required in order to hold individual who was officer and director of corporation liable for fraudulent misrepresentations made in connection with corporation's business.
Document Preview: Owner of dairy herd who had leased his cows to dairy management corporation sued corporation and three of its officers, directors, and shareholders, asserting claims for fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of fiduciary duty. After corporation was dismissed, the District Court, Red Willow County, Donald E. Rowlands, II, J., entered judgment for defendants on all theories except fraudulent misrepresentation, as to which judgment was entered against only vice-president of corporation.  Appeal was taken, and the Court of Appeals, Sievers, J., held that: (1) piercing of corporate veil was not required to hold vice-president liable for fraudulent misrepresentation; (2) evidence supported judgment for owner on fraudulent misrepresentation claim; and (3) owner, who elected to affirm contract, was entitled to recover such damages as would compensate him for loss or injury actually caused by fraud; but (4) owner could not recover as damages management fees which he paid to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Chan v. Society Expeditions, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Operator of cruise ship was not also liable for passengers' injuries as owner, although same individual was sole owner of both operator and corporation which owned ship, as piercing of corporate veil was not warranted absent evidence demonstrating shared corporate existence or common scheme to perpetrate fraud on third parties.
Document Preview: Husband, wife, and their children sued husband's employer, cruise ship, alleged operator of ship, and sole owner and president of both employer and operator, asserting claims under general maritime law for injuries sustained by husband and child while on cruise.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, Thomas S. Zilly, J., granted summary judgment for employer and dismissed as to operator.  The Court of Appeals, 39 F.3d. 1398, reversed and remanded for further proceedings.  On remand, the District Court dismissed in rem action against ship, applied Liberian law to limit plaintiffs' damages, and found both employer and operator liable for plaintiffs' injuries.  Parties appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Goodwin, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) employer was carrier and was thus liable for plaintiffs' injuries; (2) printed disclaimer did not preclude liability; (3) alleged operator was subject to liability...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Hart v. Steel Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced to find sole shareholder personally liable for fraud in inducement of contract to sell business of corporation; shareholder was alleged to have fraudulently represented to buyers that corporation had income, in most recent accounting period, of $176,301.94, while in reality corporation had lost $4,344.76, and shareholders' equity had been fraudulently represented as $129,212.36, while in fact corporation was undercapitalized at a negative $51,434.34.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Sale of business contract rescindable for fraud in inducement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Unit Owners Ass'n of Summit Vista Lot 8 Condominium v. Miller
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: Condominium Act imposes personal liability for misrepresentations in condominium offering statement, even absent evidence that trust which held title to property during construction and sale of condominium project was used to promote injustice or fraud; Act is specifically designed to allow condominium owners to pierce corporate veil and impose liability on individual participants. RSA 356-B:65, subds. 1, 3.
Document Preview: Association of condominium owners brought suit against developer, individually and as trustee, for damages caused to common areas as result of deficiently designed drainage system.  The Superior Court, Carroll County, Dickson, J., awarded plaintiffs damages and attorney fees but refused to award double or treble damages under Consumer Protection Act.  Cross-appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Johnson, J., held that: (1) developer could be personally liable for Condominium Act violation, even absent evidence required to pierce corporate veil; (2) liability under Consumer Protection Act could not be imposed absent evidence supporting corporate veil piercing; and (3) multiple damages could be awarded under Consumer Protection Act based on developer's knowing violation of Act. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: People by Koppell v. Empyre Inground Pools Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced to hold corporate officers personally liable for tortious conduct or knowing participation in fraudulent acts.
Document Preview: Consumer Protection. Respondents' business practices were properly enjoined.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Stromberg Metal Works, Inc. v. Press Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Subcontractors' efforts to pierce corporate veil and hold alleged controllers of general contractor liable for fraudulently representing to owner that subcontractors' claims had been paid was governed by law of state of general contractor's incorporation.
Document Preview: Maryland subcontractors brought action against alleged controllers of Illinois general contractor for false certification to owner and nonpayment of debts on subcontracts.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Wayne R. Andersen, J., dismissed action against first subcontractor for lack of diversity jurisdiction and entered judgment in favor of general contractor on remaining claim. Subcontractors appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Easterbrook, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court had supplemental jurisdiction over first subcontractor's claim, and (2) Illinois law applied in subcontractors' efforts to pierce corporate veil and hold alleged controllers of general contractor liable for fraudulent representations. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Stromberg Metal Works, Inc. v. Press Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Negotiated language on purchase orders between Maryland subcontractors and Illinois general contractor, that referred to "other contract documents" and "all project requirements" did not subject disputes between subcontractors and general contractor to Maryland law, as specified in contract between general contractor and project owner attached to purchase orders and, thus, Maryland Construction Trust Fund Statute could not be used to pierce corporate veil and hold alleged controllers of general contractor liable for fraudulently representing to owner that subcontractors' claims had been paid. Md.Code, Real Property, § 9–201(b)(1).
Document Preview: Maryland subcontractors brought action against alleged controllers of Illinois general contractor for false certification to owner and nonpayment of debts on subcontracts.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Wayne R. Andersen, J., dismissed action against first subcontractor for lack of diversity jurisdiction and entered judgment in favor of general contractor on remaining claim. Subcontractors appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Easterbrook, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court had supplemental jurisdiction over first subcontractor's claim, and (2) Illinois law applied in subcontractors' efforts to pierce corporate veil and hold alleged controllers of general contractor liable for fraudulent representations. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Yoder v. Honeywell Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, corporation was not alter ego of former subsidiary, and so was not liable for acts of former subsidiary; although corporation was responsible for incorporation of former subsidiary, and board of directors consisted wholly of members of board of corporation for period, and then two of three members of board of former subsidiary were members of board of corporation for subsequent period, former subsidiary maintained separate corporate existence, was fully capitalized from inception, was not used to defeat public convenience or to justify or protect wrong, fraud, or crime, and had legitimate business purpose.
Document Preview: Worker brought products liability action against corporation, and corporation's former subsidiary that manufactured computer keyboard, for injuries suffered from use of allegedly defective keyboard, corporation moved for summary judgment, and former subsidiary moved for dismissal.  The District Court, Babcock, J., held that: (1) corporation was not alter ego of former subsidiary; (2) corporation was not manufacturer of keyboard; and (3) worker's action against former subsidiary accrued when she knew she was injured and knew cause of her injury. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: U.S. v. Funds Held in Name or for Ben. of Wetterer
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Texas law, failure to observe corporate formalities is not factor in proving alter ego theory in contract claims, but must be considered in tort-based claims, and where claims asserted against corporation on which seizure of its accounts was based and on which use of alter ego theory was being premised were allegations of mail fraud and related criminal activities of individual of whom corporation was alleged to be alter ego, the claims were more akin to tort claims.
Document Preview: Guatemalan not-for-profit corporation objected to report and recommendation of United States Magistrate Judge Chrein striking, on ground that corporation was alter ego of individual who was fugitive as to indictments in United States, corporation's claim to certain bank accounts held in its name or in the name of the individual, allegedly for its use and benefit, which were seized by United States. The District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) in the Second Circuit, district court can, in the exercise of its discretion and in the appropriate circumstances, apply the disentitlement doctrine in a civil forfeiture proceeding to the claim of a corporation alleged to be the alter ego of a fugitive; (2) under federal common law choice-of-law principles, New York and Texas were the jurisdictions whose laws and policies were implicated to the greatest extent; (3) under the laws of either New York or Texas, piercing the corporate veil was warranted on alter ego theory;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Boughton v. Cotter Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, mere fact that corporate subsidiary became undercapitalized solely due to recharacterization of its assets when it ceased operations did not prove that corporation was set up to be undercapitalized, or that it was used to defeat public convenience, or to justify or protect wrong, fraud or crime, so as to support piercing of corporate veil to hold parent liable for conduct of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Residents filed action against owner of uranium mill and its parent corporation, asserting various state and federal claims arising from alleged exposure to emissions from mill.  The United States District Court for the District of Colorado, Zita L. Weinshienk, J., entered judgment in favor of bellwether plaintiffs.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, H. Dale Cook, Senior District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) district court did not abuse its discretion by refusing to certify as class action; (2) district court did not abuse its discretion by entering protective order precluding deposition of outside counsel who had represented mill owner; (3) residents' fear of contracting cancer or other disease from alleged exposure to emissions was not compensable as annoyance and discomfort damages on nuisance and trespass claims; and (4) evidence of whether subsidiary was instrumentality of parent did not warrant piercing...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: State v. Easton
Court: Supreme Court, Albany County, New York.
Headnote: Judgments obtained against physician, for committing Medicaid fraud, were enforceable against corporations of which he was president, even though reverse piercing of corporate veil was involved and physician was president rather than shareholder of corporations; ultimate objective of the piercing of corporate veil doctrine, to prevent fraud or achieve equity, was as applicable in present case involving transfer of obligation to corporation as in the traditional case where obligation of corporation was transferred to shareholder, and despite lack of formal shareholder relationship physician exercise complete domination and control over corporation, rendering corporation his alter ego.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Corporation could be held liable for judgment against nonshareholder controlling person.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Muroll Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Tennessee Tape, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Shareholder's direction causing one corporation he solely owned to transfer to another corporation $325,000 in merchandise with only pretextual consideration, thereby rendering first corporation insolvent and enabling second corporation to more than double his salary, was a dealing clearly in fraud of first corporation's creditors, and justified piercing the corporate veils and requiring shareholder and second corporation to account to creditor of first corporation for the fruits of the fraudulent conversion of assets.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Fraudulent transaction between corporations owned by one shareholder justified piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Caterpillar Inc. v. Jerryco Footwear, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Individual defendants, who were accused of having personally participated in skimming scheme that was perpetrated by individual defendants through corporate entities they owned, managed, and controlled, could not hide behind corporate veil for alleged tortious acts.
Document Preview: Licensor brought suit against licensee and related corporations and individuals, challenging alleged fraudulent scheme involving royalties.  Preliminary injunction was granted, and motion was filed to vacate or modify injunction order.  The District Court, Mihm, Chief Judge, held that: (1) licensor demonstrated high probability that defendants would engage in further acts designed to defraud licensor and frustrate enforcement of any judgment, absent preliminary injunction; (2) balancing of relative harms weighed in favor of preliminary injunction; and (3) licensor established reasonable likelihood of success on merits. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: UA Local 343 United Ass'n of Journeymen & Apprentices of Plumbing and Pipefitting Industry of U.S. and Canada, AFL-CIO v. Nor-Cal Plumbing, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether to pierce corporate veil, owner's fraudulent concealment of relationship between two corporations did not, in itself, constitute misuse of corporate forum to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Union brought action against owner of union and nonunion plumbing firms under Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA) and Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), alleging that owner breached collective bargaining agreement based on theory that agreement between union and union firm covered nonunion firm as nonunion firm was alter ego of union firm.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, Barbara A. Caulfield, District Judge, 797 F.Supp. 767, entered summary judgment for union, and owner appealed. Amending and superseding its prior opinion, 38 F.3d 1467, the Court of Appeals, William A. Norris, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court was not required to obtain determination from National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) that employees of union and nonunion firms were appropriate bargaining unit; (2) district court had jurisdiction over ERISA claim; (3) union and nonunion firms were single employer;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Washington Courte Condominium Association-Four v. Washington-Golf Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: In fraud suit by condominium association and unit owners, it was appropriate to pierce developer's corporate veil to find that developer's officers, as individuals, were liable for failure to disclose material facts relating to desirability of condominiums, in light of officers' experience in construction and real estate, their responsibility for sales program, and their monitoring of construction.
Document Preview: Fraud. Developer's corporate officers were liable for fraud for failing to disclose water infiltration problem to condominium unit purchasers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Pepper v. J.J. Welcome Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Although alter ego doctrine is most commonly invoked to impose liability upon corporate officers for fraud committed by corporation, doctrine may also be invoked to impose liability on corporation for acts of its shareholders when corporation and shareholders are one and the same.
Document Preview: Damages. Proper measure of damages for injuries to land, where the land was capable of being restored to its former condition, was restoration cost.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Johnston v. Green Mountain, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: To "pierce the corporate veil" of employer's stockholders in suit for breach of contract and fraud, employee had to show that stockholders had complete control and domination of corporation's finances, policy, and business practices and that stockholders misused that control to employee's detriment.
Document Preview: Employee sued employer for breach of contract and fraud and sought to impose personal liability on employer's stockholders.  The Madison Circuit Court, No. CV91775, Lynwood Smith, J., granted partial summary judgment for employer, and employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that: (1) liability could not be imposed on stockholders individually; (2) employer did not engage in anticipatory breach; (3) employer's conduct did not constitute promissory fraud; and (4) employer did not suppress material fact regarding employee's compensation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Johnston v. Green Mountain, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Employee could not "pierce the corporate veil" of stockholders who owned only 2% of employer corporation, in employee's suit for breach of contract and fraud, because stockholders' financial control of corporation was limited.
Document Preview: Employee sued employer for breach of contract and fraud and sought to impose personal liability on employer's stockholders.  The Madison Circuit Court, No. CV91775, Lynwood Smith, J., granted partial summary judgment for employer, and employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that: (1) liability could not be imposed on stockholders individually; (2) employer did not engage in anticipatory breach; (3) employer's conduct did not constitute promissory fraud; and (4) employer did not suppress material fact regarding employee's compensation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Bollwerk v. Susquehanna Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be found liable, under South Dakota law, for alleged acts of wholly owned subsidiary in fraudulently concealing medical information from employee during time he was employed at uranium processing mill, where subsidiary was a fully operational corporation that kept separate financial records and observed corporate formalities.
Document Preview: Former employee of subsidiary brought suit against parent and subsidiaries, alleging that one or more defendants fraudulently concealed medical information from him during time he was employed at uranium processing mill.  On parent's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Battey, J., held that parent could not be found liable for alleged acts of its subsidiaries. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Travel Committee, Inc. v. Pan American World Airways, Inc.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Trial court could not pierce corporate veil on grounds of fraud, where jury found that corporate officers and stockholders committed no fraud.
Document Preview: Airline brought action against travel agency and its corporate and individual owners seeking to recover on note executed by agency and to recover funds representing ticket sale proceeds.  The Circuit Court, Baltimore County, Joseph F. Murphy, Jr., J., entered judgment in favor of airline, and agency appealed.  The Court of Special Appeals, Alpert, J., held that: (1) jury's verdict was not hopelessly irreconcilable; (2) piercing travel agency's corporate veil was improper; (3) agency did not have fiduciary obligation to hold and preserve ticket sale proceeds for airline's benefit; (4) evidence created jury issue as to whether airline's breach of marketing cooperation agreement resulted in damages; (5) issue of whether airline's tariffs violated Federal Aviation Act could not be addressed by state court; (6) airline's statements to agency were not actionable misrepresentations; (7) airline did not breach agreement to sell...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: S.E.C. v. Great Lakes Equities Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporation's president was alter ego of corporation, in determining whether he was required to disgorge amounts obtained from investors as result of alleged securities fraud; president dominated and controlled activities of corporation so completely that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own.
Document Preview: After judgment was entered in favor of investors in securities fraud action against corporation and its president, disgorgement hearing was held. The District Court, Gadola, J., held that: (1) corporation's president was alter ego of corporation, in determining whether he was required to disgorge amounts obtained from investors as result of alleged securities fraud, and (2) corporation and president were not entitled to deduct overhead, commissions and other expenses incurred in corporation's operation. Disgorgement ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: S.E.C. v. Great Lakes Equities Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporation's president was jointly and severally liable with corporation for amounts obtained by corporation as result of alleged securities fraud, where president was corporation's alter ego and his actions were inextricably interwoven with those of corporation.
Document Preview: After judgment was entered in favor of investors in securities fraud action against corporation and its president, disgorgement hearing was held. The District Court, Gadola, J., held that: (1) corporation's president was alter ego of corporation, in determining whether he was required to disgorge amounts obtained from investors as result of alleged securities fraud, and (2) corporation and president were not entitled to deduct overhead, commissions and other expenses incurred in corporation's operation. Disgorgement ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Kilduff v. Adams, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Corporate veil did not have to be pierced in order to find that corporate lienholder's officers were personally liable for their misrepresentations to mortgagors that lienholder would not redeem property following foreclosure, since officers would be personally liable for their torts regardless of whether corporation was itself liable.
Document Preview: Mortgagors brought action against corporate lienholder and its officers, seeking damages for fraud and unjust enrichment.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Hartford-New Britain, Maloney, J., entered jury verdict in favor of mortgagors.  Subsequently, the Superior Court, Dorsey, J., denied defendants' motions to set aside verdict and for remittitur, and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court transferred matter from the Appellate Court.  The Supreme Court, Callahan, J., held that: (1) mortgagors suffered legally cognizable injury from misrepresentations that lienholder would not redeem property following foreclosure, even though law day for mortgagors' redemption of property had passed; (2) mortgagors were not barred from seeking damages in action at law for misrepresentations merely because they had not filed action in equity to obtain relief from operation of foreclosure judgment or sought to have their bankruptcy trustee void...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Transamerica Cash Reserve, Inc. v. Dixie Power and Water, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Corporation was not "alter ego" of corporate shareholder with regards to corporate shareholder's alleged defrauding of money market mutual fund, and thus corporation's assets were not subject to direct levy by shareholder's creditors, even though shareholder's ownership of stock gave him complete control over corporation, where corporation was a stranger to alleged defrauding of fund by shareholder, fund did not rely on existence of corporation in its dealings with shareholder, and money in corporation's bank account was unrelated to shareholder's activities with fund.
Document Preview: Money market mutual fund and bank brought action against, inter alia, corporation and its controlling shareholder, alleging that shareholder had obtained monies from fund by a series of fraudulent transactions.  Following remand from 723 P.2d 425, the Fifth District Court, Washington County, J. Harlan Burns, J., granted summary judgment in favor of plaintiffs. Corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Zimmerman, J., held that: (1) shareholder was not alter ego of corporation with regards to alleged fraudulent transactions of shareholder, and (2) attorney liens statute allows attorneys to attach only proceeds of a judgment obtained in his or her client's favor. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Hoffman v. Optima Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, failure of fraud and breach of contract plaintiff to demonstrate that piercing corporate veil of his employer was necessary to defeat the fraud or other alleged wrongs allegedly committed on him by employer, precluded piercing of the veil.
Document Preview: Employee filed breach of contract, fraud, deceptive trade practices, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and corporate negligence action against corporate employer and major shareholders.  On defendants' motion to dismiss, the District Court, Young, J., held that: (1) complaints stated fraud with sufficient particularity; (2) plaintiff's detrimental reliance removed breach of contract action from statute of frauds; (3) complaint failed to state deceptive trade practices action; (4) evidence was insufficient to support piercing of corporate veil; (5) plaintiff lacked standing to bring derivative corporation suits; and (6) complaints failed to state cause of action for intentional infliction of emotional distress. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United Equitable Life Ins. Co. v. Trans Global Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, comingling of funds of corporate entities by insurance agency owners, use of various corporate funds for personal purposes, and similarities between corporations' by-laws and corporate minutes over several years, demonstrated that corporations were alter egos of their owners; thus, corporate veil could be pierced to impose liability on owners for their fraudulent insurance marketing scheme.
Document Preview: Insurance company brought breach of contract, common-law fraud, and breach of fiduciary duties suit against insurance agents, upon discovery of policy marketing scheme which induced company to pay agents large advanced unearned premium commissions.  The District Court, Alesia, J., held that: (1) Illinois law was applicable under choice of law and forum agreement; (2) agents' marketing of policies as free and payment of premiums for policy holders violated agency agreement; (3) insurance agents' stopping payment on premium checks constituted breach of agency agreement; (4) marketing scheme to induce insurance company to continue to send advance unearned commissions constituted common-law fraud; (5) insurance agents violated their common-law fiduciary duty to insurance company; (6) agents' activities did not violate cited California Insurance Code provisions; (7) insurance company failed to state cause of action...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Estate of Hall
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporations formed by sole shareholder to act as general partners in two limited partnerships which owned real estate developments were not mere fictions, and corporate veils thus could not be pierced so as to preclude testimony under Dead Man's Actas to shareholder's statements made prior to his death; use of corporate general partners was essential to limited partnerships, and corporate general partners had 50% ownership interest in each of the completed buildings. 42 Pa.C.S.A. § 5930¢ R1987159454;00001;;LQ;PA42S5930;1000262;.
Document Preview: Limited partners brought action against corporate general partners in limited partnerships to recover interest on loans to partnerships, for incurrence and assessment of management fees, and for failure to maintain life insurance policy on life of sole shareholder of corporate general partners.  The Court of Common Pleas, Allegheny County, Orphans' Court Division, No. 3224 of 1973, Ross, J., allowed claims, and corporate general partners appealed.  The Superior Court, No. 148 Pittsburgh 1985, 357 Pa.Super. 641, 513 A.2d 1080 (unpublished opinion) affirmed, and corporate general partners appealed.  The Supreme Court, No. 101 W.D. Appeal Docket 1986, Papadakos, J., held that: (1) limited partners who delegated power to make all management decisions to corporate general partners could not recover management fees paid by general partners to service owned by operator of corporate general partners; (2) corporate general partners waived statute of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Baldwin v. Matthew R. White Investments, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Corporate formalities were sufficiently observed to refuse to pierce corporate veil of corporate broker-dealer and hold individual president personally liable for investment fraud of employee. Securities Act of 1933, §§ 1 et seq., 12(2), 15, 15 U.S.C.A. §§ 77a et seq., 77l (2), 77o ; U.C.A.1953, 61-1-22(1)(b).
Document Preview: Investors brought suit and recovered judgment for investment fraud by employee of corporate broker-dealer. Investors then moved to impose liability on individual president of corporate broker-dealer. The District Court, Sam, J., held that: (1) corporate formalities were sufficiently observed to refuse to pierce corporate veil, and (2) there was no reason to disregard corporate form on basis of fraud, injustice or inequitable result. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Baldwin v. Matthew R. White Investments, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: There was no reason to disregard corporate form of broker-dealer on basis of fraud, injustice or inequitable results, and thus individual president could not be held personally liable for investment fraud of employee.
Document Preview: Investors brought suit and recovered judgment for investment fraud by employee of corporate broker-dealer. Investors then moved to impose liability on individual president of corporate broker-dealer. The District Court, Sam, J., held that: (1) corporate formalities were sufficiently observed to refuse to pierce corporate veil, and (2) there was no reason to disregard corporate form on basis of fraud, injustice or inequitable result. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Lund v. Chemical Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Partner's ownership of 33% stock in corporation was insufficient, as matter of law, to establish that corporation was partner's alter ego; therefore, partner's partner was not corporation's partner, for purposes of determining whether partner's partner had authority to indorse check on behalf of corporation, in action against drawee bank for conversion based on theory that bank paid over forged indorsement. U.C.C. §§ 3-110, 3-419(1)(c); M.S.A. §§ 323.02, subd. 8, 323.06(4).
Document Preview: Indorsees brought conversion action against drawee bank to recover face amount of checks which were allegedly paid over forged indorsements.  Drawee bank commenced third-party action against customer, who deposited checks, seeking indemnity for breach of warranty of indorsement.  All parties moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Sweet, J., held that: (1) one check was not paid over forged indorsement in view of signer's authority to indorse check on behalf of partnership; (2) delivery of the checks was not condition precedent to right to bring the conversion action; (3) drawee bank could not assert contributory negligence defense against indorsees; and (4) customer was strictly liable to bank for breach of warranties that all signatures were genuine and authorized. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Orloff v. Allman
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: President of company, which was general partner in development corporation, was not liable, under California's alter ego doctrine, in action brought by development corporation's investors against development corporation and company for securities fraud; fact that president wished limited liability was not, by itself, sufficient reason to pierce the corporate veil, and investors did not claim that company was undercapitalized or otherwise incapable of satisfying judgment.
Document Preview: Investors brought action for securities fraud against development corporation, company which was general partner in development corporation, and company's president.  The United States District Court, Central District of California, David V. Kenyon, J., granted summary judgment releasing president from liability in investors' action.  Investors appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Beezer, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) president was not liable as controlling person; (2) president was not liable as aider and abettor; (3) president was not liable under California's alter ego doctrine; and (4) president was not liable as alter ego of company under federal law. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Deupree v. Ruffino
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Trial court's decision, to pierce corporate veil and hold owner of development company personally liable for misrepresentations made in connection with sale of townhouse units, was not clearly erroneous, where company neither issued stock nor adopted bylaws, had no books of account, and hired no employees, and where personal and corporate funds were commingled and expended by owner as needs arose.
Document Preview: Interpleader actions were brought to determine parties entitled to funds deposited by townhouse purchasers with escrow agent for construction of boat docks.  Townhouse purchasers cross-claimed against developer and owner of development company for their alleged breach of contract and fraud in connection with docks.  The Circuit Court, Talladega County, William C. Sullivan, J., entered judgment in favor of purchasers, and developer and owner of development company appealed.  The Supreme Court, Beatty, J., held that: (1) trial court's finding, that developer had not performed contractual obligation to construct boat docks within reasonable time, was not clearly erroneous; (2) developer stood in confidential relationship to purchasers, so as to be liable to purchasers in fraud for concealing substantial impediments to completion of boat docks; and (3) trial court's decision, to pierce corporate veil and hold owner of development...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re Coover
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Chief operating officer and shareholder of corporation which was mere shell, with no money invested, could not use corporation to shield himself from liability due to fraud perpetrated in name of corporation upon innocent third parties.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor sought exception to discharge of debt.  The Bankruptcy Court, Sidney M. Weaver, J., held that: (1) debtor, who had been chief operating officer and shareholder of corporation, had to be held personally liable upon obligations of corporation created after its dissolution and could not use corporation to shield himself from liability due to fraud perpetrated by debtor in name of corporation upon innocent third parties, and (2) judgment against debtor for damages for breach of contract, breach of fiduciary relationship, and fraud in connection with sale of insurance would be excepted from discharge as debt for money, property, services, or extension, renewal, or refinancing of credit obtained by false pretenses, false representations, or actual fraud, as debt for fraud or defalcation while acting in fiduciary capacity, embezzlement, or larceny, and as debt for willful and malicious injury. Debt excepted from discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re L & S Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: When sole shareholder utilizes corporate structure to defraud creditors for his own personal benefit, courts will treat shareholder as alter ego of corporation and hold it personally liable for corporate obligations.
Document Preview: Matter came before court on adversary complaint of secured creditor of debtor to modify automatic stay so as to enforce note and security agreement creditor held in debtor's assets pursuant to stock purchase agreement.  The Bankruptcy Court, Jack B. Schmetterer, J., held that substantial issues of material fact existed as to whether parties agreed to use book value, with accelerated depreciation method, or appraisal of actual value as basis for stock transaction, whether debtor was estopped from asserting Illinois law as bar to claims, and whether debtor was alter ego of sole remaining shareholder of corporation so as to preclude applicability of corporate law prohibiting corporation from purchasing its stocks if there is insufficient surplus, or, if purchase was made while corporation was insolvent or would render it insolvent, precluding summary judgment. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: L.B. Industries, Inc. v. Smith
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Minority shareholder and its representative on board of directors were not alter egos of corporation so as to permit liability for any of its fraudulent acts; minority shareholder and its representative did not have or take control of corporation to extent that there was such a unity of interest in ownership that their separate personalities no longer existed.
Document Preview: Action was brought against minority shareholder in corporation and its representative on the board of directors for alleged fraudulent transactions involving the purchase and development of small hydroelectric sites.  The District Court, Ryan, J., held that: (1) under Idaho law, minority shareholder and its representative would not be liable for any fraud committed by corporation, and (2) corporate entity could not be disregarded to impose personal liability on minority shareholder or its representative. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Trak Microcomputer Corp. v. Wearne Bros.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation would be liable for any fraudulent acts of subsidiary and would be subjected to Illinois jurisdiction when it was alter ego of subsidiary for fraudulent acts as well as acts in Illinois which gave rise to jurisdiction.
Document Preview: Action was brought alleging pattern of racketeering activity in violation of RICO in addition to other theories of liability stemming from alleged fraud and misrepresentation made in the course of negotiations between corporation experiencing financial difficulties and would-be investors. Plaintiffs moved for an answer by Singapore corporation and defendants and counterdefendants made motions to dismiss.  The District Court, McGarr, Chief Judge, held that: (1) service on Singapore corporation satisfied rules, and (2) complaint stated claim under RICO. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: West Bldg. Materials, Inc. v. Daley
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholder's use of building materials purchased by corporation to improve shareholder's building did not perpetrate fraud against supplier of building materials, even though corporation subsequently ceased operating and was insolvent, where refurbished property was building which housed office of corporation, absent evidence that shareholder incurred debts in anticipation of closing corporation in order to evade his obligation, particularly where corporation was never formally liquidated.
Document Preview: Supplier of building materials brought action against shareholder on open account maintained by corporation.  The Lake Charles City Court, Parish of Calcasieu, Nick Pizzolatto, Jr., J. ad hoc., entered judgment for shareholder, and supplier appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Stoker, J., held that: (1) shareholder's use of materials purchased by corporation to improve shareholder's building which housed corporation did not perpetrate fraud upon supplier; (2) shareholder's use of some of building materials purchased by corporation for shareholder's personal benefit and fact that there were no regular shareholders' meetings of corporation were insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder liable for corporation's debt; and (3) shareholder's use of building materials purchased by corporation to refurbish shareholder's building did not entitle supplier to recover against shareholder on theory of unjust enrichment. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Agristor Leasing v. Guggisberg
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Minnesota law did not allow piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation of manufacturer of animal feed storage system liable on farmers' claims against the manufacturer on claims of strict liability, negligence, breach of warranty, and misrepresentation, absent showing that the manufacturer had been operated in unjust manner or that it was alter ego of the parent corporation.
Document Preview: Farmers against whom action was brought for breach of lease and wrongful detention of property filed third-party complaint against manufacturer, marketer, and seller of animal feed storage system, alleging strict liability, negligence, breach of warranty, and misrepresentation.  Third-party defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Diana E. Murphy, J., held that: (1) Minnesota statute of limitations for actions for damages for injury arising out of defective and unsafe condition of improvement to real property did not apply; (2) Minnesota law did not allow piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation of manufacturer liable; (3) genuine issues of material fact existed to preclude summary judgment on farmers' fraud claim, seller's indemnification claim, and farmers' punitive damages claim; (4) alleged damage to farmers' feed and cows were nonrecoverable economic losses; and (5) disclaimers of warranty and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Armada Supply, Inc. v. S/T Agios Nikolas
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate status of charterer and subcharterer of vessel would be disregarded and individual liability imposed on manager and director of the corporations who, through his admitted control of vessel, embarked on course of flagrant misconduct that included conversion, extortion, fraud and sabotage of property of fuel oil cargo owner who recovered against charterers, operators and agents of the vessel under Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, 46 U.S.C.A. § 1300 et seq.
Document Preview: Fuel oil cargo owner brought action against charterers, operators and agents of vessel, alleging that these defendants were responsible for shortage, contamination and conversion of the cargo.  The District Court, William C. Conner, J., held that: (1) sanctions would be imposed against defendants' counsel for submitting fictionalized account of facts in signed posttrial memorandum; (2) defendants were liable, under Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, for shortage and contamination of the cargo; (3) cargo owner could not also assert separate claim for common-law conversion, even though conversion was shown; (4) cargo owner's measure of damages would be difference between amount it would have received under its contract and amount it ultimately realized from salvage sales; (5) prejudgment interest would be awarded; (6) assuming availability of punitive damages under Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, such damages would be appropriate; and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Musico v. Champion Credit Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: District court did not err in regarding decedent's estate as proper party rather than corporations which were owned by the estate and by decedent during his lifetime, in suit by personal representative of decedent's estate against former agents of decedent's estate for breach of fiduciary duty, constructive fraud, and conversion, since the agents had disregarded separate status of the corporations in dealing with one another and during most of the present litigation. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1332.
Document Preview: Personal representative of decedent's estate brought action against former agents of the estate to recover for breach of fiduciary duty, constructive fraud, and conversion.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Lloyd F. MacMahon, J., entered judgment holding agents liable to the estate, and agents appealed.  The Court of Appeals, George C. Pratt, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) agents waived any right to argue on appeal that estate was not alter ego of decedent's corporations, for purpose of determining whether diversity jurisdiction existed; (2) district court properly regarded decedent's estate as proper plaintiff rather than decedent's corporations; (3) agents were properly held liable for breach of fiduciary duty, constructive fraud, and conversion of funds; and (4) New York law required apportionment of compensation forfeited by agents where agents had properly performed some services separate from...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: In re D.H. Overmyer Telecasting Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Individual's control over various corporations was so pervasive that there was unity of interest between individual and those corporations and thus findings of fraud were binding upon all of parties; individual corporate entities were to be disregarded, since they were merely the alter ego of the individual and were used as a front or mere conduit by him to carry out his fraudulent scheme.
Document Preview: Lessor of broadcasting equipment filed adversary proceeding against Chapter 11 debtor, and debtor and equity security holder filed counterclaims.  The Bankruptcy Court, 23 B.R. 823, entered judgment against lessor, and appeal was brought.  The District Court, Bell, J., held that: (1) equity security holder had right to intervene in adversary proceeding; (2) it was not abuse of discretion to set discovery cutoff dates; (3) there was no right to jury trial; (4) evidence was sufficient to establish that lessor participated in conspiracy to defraud debtor and its creditors; and (5) individual's control over various corporations was so pervasive that findings of fraud were binding upon all corporations. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Minpeco S.A. v. Conticommodity Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Court would not disregard corporate existence of company which was wholly owned by the government of Peru so as to determine that, because of the profits allegedly made by the government of Peru as a result of the defendants' alleged fraudulent activity, there was no actual loss suffered, even though the corporation did suffer loss.
Document Preview: Defendants in fraud action sought order directing separate trial on the issue of loss. The District Court, Lasker, J., held that court would not disregard corporate form of company which was wholly owned by the Peruvian government so as to determine that any losses which it suffered should be offset against gains realized by the government because of the same alleged conduct of the defendants. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Cawley v. Bloch
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation formed after parent had committed alleged wrongdoing could not be held responsible for the alleged wrongful acts where plaintiffs did not allege any facts that suggested relationship between the two corporations was anything other than a legitimate parent-subsidiary relationship and where the corporate relationship could not have been designed to defraud anyone.
Document Preview: Operators of legal clinic brought action in contract and quantum meruit and for fraudulent and negligent misrepresentation and concealment against foreign parent and subsidiary corporations, parent's president, and president's assistant. On motions to dismiss filed by all except the parent corporation, the District Court, Joseph H. Young, J., held that: (1) as acts of corporate representatives were as representatives of the corporation and not in their individual capacities, there was no basis for personal jurisdiction over the individuals, and (2) subsidiary, which was formed after parent's alleged wrongful acts, could not be held liable for those acts. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Kersh v. General Council of the Assemblies of God
Court: United States District Court, N. D. California.
Headnote: Doctrine of "alter ego liability," under which a court may disregard corporate entity and treat acts of corporation as if they were done by individuals or controlling corporation lying beyond corporate shell, is not strict liability so as to be precluded, as a form of secondary liability, under section of Securities Exchange Act providing that every person who controls any person liable under federal securities law fraud section shall also be liable jointly and severally to any person to whom such controlled person is liable. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, § 20(a), 15 U.S.C.A. § 78t(a).
Document Preview: Class of all persons who deposited money in church trust fund alleged various federal securities and common-law violations in connection with operation of the fund. The District Court, Henderson, J., held that: (1) doctrine of alter ego liability, under which a court may disregard corporate entity and treat acts of corporation as if they were done by individuals or controlling corporation lying beyond corporate shell, is not strict liability so as to be precluded under section of Securities Exchange Act providing that every person who controls any person liable under federal securities law section shall also be liable jointly and severally to any person to whom such controlled person is liable, and (2) where allegations of a duty of care have been made, allegations of reckless nonfeasance are sufficient to state a claim of control person liability. Motions to dismiss denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Stoltz, Wagner & Brown v. Cimarron Exploration Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Since individual defendant was the alter ego of exploration company and since corporate existence was used to do wrong, namely, divert $225,000 paid by one plaintiff from its intended purpose to personal use of individual defendant, corporate existence of exploration company should be disregarded and alter ego should be held personally liable for any judgment in instant case against exploration company and in favor of plaintiffs.
Document Preview: Actions were brought against exploration company and individual defendant for damages sustained by plaintiffs as result of defendant's alleged breach of two separate exploration agreements.  The District Court, Daugherty, J., held that: (1) exploration company satisfied agreements as far as drilling, completing, equipping and testing of nine test wells drilled was concerned; (2) by retaining funds which were to be forwarded to one plaintiff, exploration company materially breached agreements; (3) exploration company was not entitled to enforce its elective rights under agreements due to its material breach of said agreements; and (4) individual defendant should be held personally liable for any judgment in instant case against exploration company and in favor of plaintiffs. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Murphy v. Walters
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: In order for advertising manager to go behind corporate veil and fasten personal liability on corporate officer as individual for alleged fraudulent representations in contract of employment, advertising manager was required to establish that corporation, through such officer, perpetrated fraud on him by making knowingly false statements to him, which were reasonably believed by him and acted on to his detriment.
Document Preview: Advertising manager sued corporation and two officers in three counts alleging fraudulent representations by officers, the same by the corporation and against all three based on securities law. The Circuit Court, Lake County, Robert K. McQueen, J., entered judgment for defendants. Advertising manager filed motion for rehearing, and the trial court entered judgment in favor of advertising manager on the first and third counts. One of the officers appealed. The Appellate Court, Unverzagt, J., held that: (1) advertising manager had failed to establish that the corporation, through its officer, had perpetrated a fraud upon him by knowingly making false statements to him, and therefore, personal liability of officer was improper; (2) there was no basis for finding violations of sections of securities law relating to fraud and misrepresentation; and (3) advertising manager was entitled to either refund of cash and return of notes he had given corporation in exchange for two shares of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Mobridge Community Industries, Inc. v. Toure, Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Misrepresentations by directors during negotiations for purchase of plant and equipment concerning worldwide patents owned by the corporation or pending, imminent influx of investment money, and imminence of several reputable individuals in local business community joining management of corporation were representations as to future events concerning matters which were peculiarly within the directors' knowledge, and thus such representations as to future events were actionable in suit in which "piercing of corporate veil" was sought.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against corporation and directors for loss caused by breach of contract to purchase plant and equipment. The Fifth Judicial Circuit Court, Walworth County, Leland J. Berndt, J., entered judgment in favor of seller, and two directors appealed. The Supreme Court, Dunn, J., held that: (1) where corporation at instigation of its directors contracted to pay $250,000 in five equal annual installments to purchase plant and equipment, and the corporation at time of negotiation of the contract had approximately $62.08 in its corporate account, the corporation was inadequately capitalized in view of magnitude of its undertaking embodied in the agreement, and thus the corporate entity was properly disregarded to hold the directors jointly and severally liable; (2) conduct of directors during course of negotiations for purchase of plant and equipment constituted kind of dealing which made it inequitable to recognize corporate entity and permit the individual directors to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Thermothrift Industries, Inc. v. Mono-Therm Insulation Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: In suit brought by buyer against corporate seller, and others, for breach of contract to sell an insulation-manufacturing plant, for fraud, and for conspiracy to interfere with the contract, the motions on behalf of two corporate defendants, other than the seller, to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction would be overruled, since the key individuals involved raised common denominators among the three corporations, and since the similarities between their stockholders, officers and directors led to the conclusion that there existed the unity of ownership and interest necessary to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by buyer against seller, and others, for breach of contract to sell an insulation-manufacturing plant, for fraud, and for conspiracy to interfere with the contract. On defense motions to dismiss for lack of in personam jurisdiction, the District Court, Ballantine, J., held that: (1) the exercise of long-arm jurisdiction over the corporate seller was not unreasonable, nor did maintenance of the suit offend traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice, since the seller committed numerous acts in Kentucky, all of which were freely and intentionally done, since the cause of action arose out of those acts, and since defendants' involvement with Kentucky, measured by the minimum contacts concept, clearly compelled the court to extend jurisdiction over the seller; (2) the two individual defendants, who were directors of all three corporate defendants, had sufficiently relevant contacts with Kentucky to invoke the three-prong test regarding the constitutional...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: King v. Tubb
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi.
Headnote: Where real estate businessman accused of fraud held 100 percent of stock in real estate corporation and was president of corporation, where businessman seemed to switch positions at will, sometimes acting in his individual capacity, sometimes acting through the corporation, as when he put down $10,500 for original down payment using corporation's funds, but took title to land individually, where businessman transferred earnest money back and forth stating that he held the money and then explaining that it was held in the corporate trust account, businessman used corporation to achieve inequitable results by using corporation as unfair device to prevent investor from obtaining the return of his earnest money and, thus, corporate entity would be disregarded.
Document Preview: Investor and real estate broker brought action against real estate businessman and president of real estate corporation and corporation to recover moneys advanced for purchase of a 646.74-acre tract of land. The 23rd District Court, Wharton County, T. M. Gupton, J., entered judgment in amount of $188,226.72 for broker and investor, and businessman and corporation appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Nye, C. J., held that (1) evidence supported trial court's finding that businessman had defrauded investors and broker; (2) investors and real estate broker were entitled to recover on theory of assumpsit, and (3) trial court did not abuse discretion by failing to order separate trials on cross claim. Judgment affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Byrd v. Brand
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 3.
Headnote: Sole owner of a corporation may make himself liable in various ways, such as fraud and obtaining credit on his personal assumption of responsibility, but generally corporation and person who owns all the stock may, in law, be two separate and distinct persons.
Document Preview: Seller of goods brought action against individual who was president and sole stockholder of corporation in whose business the goods were used. Following verdict on judgment for defendant in Superior Court, Houston County, Willis B. Hunt, Jr., J., plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Deen, P.J., held that charge correctly summarized the sole issue in the case, as to whether plaintiff sold products to defendant as an individual or to the corporation; that jury question was presented on such issue; that evidence as to dealing with other creditors was inadmissible as res inter alios acta; that form letters from corporation to all suppliers' were admissible for purpose of showing that plaintiff had notice that he was dealing with a corporate entity; and that rule with respect to exclusion of witnesses was not violated by defense witness having lunch with defendant following invocation of the rule. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Muttontown Pictures, Inc. v. Levine
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Alleged fact that one defendant was parent of corporation with which plaintiff had contracted was insufficient to foist liability on said parent in fraud action, in absence of any factual allegations asserting wrongdoing by the said parent.
Document Preview: Producer of motion picture brought breach of contract and fraud action against distributor and its parent corporation. The Supreme Court, New York County, Harold Baer, J., entered judgment, and appeals were taken. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that exculpatory language in the contract, granting distributor uncontrolled discretion, exercised in good faith, did not nullify distributor's specific covenant to expend at least $200,000 for advertising and preparation of the film; and that mere alleged fact that other defendant was parent corporation of distributor was insufficient to foist liability on parent for fraud. Modified and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: International Controls Corp. v. Vesco
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where plaintiff corporation had obtained default judgment against its former shareholder for violation of statute pertaining to use of deceptive or manipulative devices in the purchase or sale of securities, there was virtual identity of interest between the former shareholder and his holding company, former shareholder transferred his shares of plaintiff corporation to the holding company at a time when he was actively engaged in the allegedly fraudulent scheme and the officers of the holding company were former stockholder's wife and secretary, district court, as court of equity, had power to pierce the corporate veil and to preliminarily enjoin the holding company from disposing of the stock transferred to it. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, § 10(b), 15 U.S.C.A. § 78j(b).
Document Preview: Action by plaintiff corporation against various individuals and corporations for alleged violations of the federal securities laws and for fraud. The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Charles E. Stewart, Jr., J., enjoined the disposition of various assets and the prosecution of pending state court actions pendente lite. Defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Irving R. Kaufman, Chief Judge, held that where parent corporation disposed of its portfolio securities in wholly owned corporation by way of a dividend in kind to its shareholders, such dividend, which was induced by some directors withholding pertinent information from other directors, constituted a sale for purposes of statute relating to manipulative or deceptive devices in the sale or purchase of a security, notwithstanding that the stockholders of the parent corporation were not required to part with consideration in return for the dividend of the portfolio stock. ...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Kugler v. Koscot Interplanetary, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Chancery Division.
Headnote: Where party who held 95% of stock of corporation, with wife holding other 5%, authorized corporation to issue scripts containing false statements which formed basis for fraudulent representations made to prospective distributors of corporation's products, completely identified himself with corporation and was active in corporation's activities, corporation was his alter ego and stockholder would be held personally liable for corporation's violation of Consumer Fraud Act and violation of state Antitrust Act. N.J.S.A. 56:8-1 et seq., 56:9-1 et seq.
Document Preview: Action against manufacturer and its principal stockholder for alleged violations of Consumer Fraud Act, Antitrust Act, and Corporation Act. The Superior Court, Chancery Division, Mehler, J.S.C., held that manufacturer's multilevel distribution system based on pyramid sales violated Consumer Fraud Act and Antitrust Act and that manufacturer was subject to fine for doing business in State without qualifying. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Superintendent of Ins. of State of N. Y. v. Bankers Life & Cas. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of the United States
Headnote: Fact that creditors of defrauded corporate buyer or seller of securities may be the ultimate victims of the fraud does not warrant disregard of corporate entity in application of federal statute prohibiting fraudulent or manipulative devices in connection with purchase and sale of securities. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, § 10(b), 15 U.S.C.A. § 78j(b).
Document Preview: Action was brought by the state Superintendent of Insurance as liquidator of insurance corporation under the federal securities acts to recover damages. The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, 300 F.Supp. 1083, dismissed the action and an appeal was taken. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, 430 F.2d 355, affirmed and certiorari was granted. The Supreme Court, Mr. Justice Douglas, held that insurance corporation, whose United States Treasury bonds in the amount of almost $5,000,000 were sold through the alleged fraud of outside collaborators and corporate officer and controlling stockholder with the result that corporation was stripped of those assets, was a seller of those bonds and was protected by the federal statute and rule prohibiting fraudulent and manipulative devices in the sale or purchase of securities since there was an act or practice within meaning of rule which operated as a...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Bossier Mill Work & Supply Co. v. D. & R. Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Where defendant stockholder and third party formed construction corporation which erected house, and third party signed title insurance company's lien affidavit to effect that all charges for labor, materials and fixtures were paid and that premises were free of all claims which would give rise to a lien, which in fact was not true, defendant could not use corporate entity as a shield from personal responsibility when he had equal authority and participation in management of financial affairs of the corporate venture; willful action of defendant in participating in receipt and distribution of funds derived from the transaction rendered him equally guilty of the deceit practiced on title insurance company. LSA-R.S. 12:95; 14:202.
