Document Preview: Action by title insurance company against construction corporation's stockholder and construction corporation seeking to hold stockholder personally liable for any loss plaintiff might sustain if certain lien were held valid. The Twenty-Sixth Judicial District Court, Parish of Bossier, Enos C. McClendon, Jr., J., gave judgment for title insurance company, and defendant stockholder appealed. The Court of Appeal, Price, J., held that where defendant stockholder and third party formed construction company which erected house, and third party signed title insurance company's lien affidavit to effect that all charges for labor, materials and fixtures were paid and that premises were free of all claims which would give rise to a lien, which in fact was not true, defendant could not use corporate entity as a shield from personal responsibility when he had equal authority and participation in management of financial affairs of the corporate venture; willful action of defendant in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Coastal States Petrochemical Co. v. Cooper Petroleum Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Facts that individual, who allegedly made misrepresentation to plaintiff that defendant corporation would stand behind debts of debtor corporation to plaintiff, was vice president of both debtor and defendant, that debtor's board meetings were held in defendant's office and that the two companies shared expenses of certain telephone service did not entitle plaintiff to have corporate entity distinctions between debtor and defendant corporation disregarded, where defendant's officers knew of separate corporate existence of two companies, knew that certain person was president of debtor and another individual was president of corporate defendant, that each company had different officers and directors and that each operated differently from the other in different cities.
Document Preview: Action based on allegation that one defendant, who was vice president of debtor and defendant corporations, had fraudulently misrepresented to plaintiff creditor that another individual defendant and corporate defendant were backing debtor and would stand behind its debt, thereby misleading plaintiff into extending credit to debtor so that plaintiff suffered loss when debtor was declared bankrupt. The District Court, Harris County, John Snell, Jr., J., entered judgment for defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Peden, J., held that testimony of employee of another corporation to effect that vice president had made similar representations to him and that defendant corporation had not performed in accordance therewith was properly excluded since it did not tend to show that vice president knew when he made representation to plaintiff that defendants would not pay debtor's obligation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Schoenberg v. Benner
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Trial court properly disregarded corporate entity and imposed liability upon sole owners of real estate broker corporation in vendors' fraud action against corporation where corporation was undercapitalized, owners had complete control of board of directors and of corporation's business, assets, and finances, corporation failed to pay dividends and owners used corporate funds as if they were their own.
Document Preview: Action by vendors against purchasers, corporate real estate broker and three of broker's salesmen for fraud and negligence in sale of vendors' real property. The broker and the salesmen cross-complained against the purchasers for indemnity. The purchasers cross-complained against the vendors. The Superior Court of Los Angeles County, Leonard A. Diether, J., rendered judgment in favor of the vendors and against the purchasers, broker and salesmen and denied all cross-complaints. The sole owners of the broker corporation were ordered joined and subjected to the same judgment liability of the corporation. The broker, its owners and one of the salesmen appealed. The Court of Appeal, Shinn, J., held, inter alia, that false statement by real estate salesmen as to value of property on which purchasers proposed giving vendors a trust deed as part of consideration for sale imposed liability upon salesmen and broker even though statements were uttered to vendors without fraudulent...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Larson v. Western Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Where corporation which sold realty under contract for deed was a mere form or name under which principal stockholder and managing officer did business as an individual, such individual was personally liable in damages as a matter of law for misrepresentation made by corporation in sale of realty as to connection of such property with city sewer.
Document Preview: Action by purchasers of realty under contract for deed against vendor corporation and its principal stockholder and managing officer for appointment of a receiver and damages for misrepresentation in sale of realty, wherein defendants, by counterclaim, sought foreclosure of contract for deed. The Circuit Court of Minnehaha County, Roy D. Burns, J., entered judgment appointing a receiver and awarding damages, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Bogue, J., held, inter alia, that when purchasers of realty received notice that vendor corporation had defaulted in its payments on mortgage against the realty, purchasers properly instituted action for appointment of receiver and that failure to make one monthly payment on contract for deed until appointment of receiver did not entitle vendor corporation to invoke acceleration clause of contract and foreclose contract for deed. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: George Washington Memorial Park Cemetery Ass'n v. Memorial Development Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of New Jersey.
Headnote: Where development company was used to perpetrate a fraud on cemetery association and its lot owners, but company was in fact the alter ego of its promoters who, through use of that instrumentality, sought to realize huge profits from operations of the cemetery association, equity would disregard the corporate fiction. N.J.S.A. 8:1-1 et seq.
Document Preview: Suit by the George Washington Memorial Park Cemetery Association, a New Jersey corporation, against the Memorial Development Company and others involving liability of complainant for cemetery lands, wherein George E. Meagher, Frank DeGeeter, and others intervened, and named interveners filed counterclaims. Decree in favor of complainant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Fewell v. Tappan
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Corporation as well as sole owner thereof who acquired such ownership by virtue of fraud was liable for fraud in procuring stock in corporation at grossly inadequate price, since sole owner could not use corporation thus acquired as a corporate veil to serve as a shield to avoid his or corporation's liability.
Document Preview: Action by A. E. Fewell against J. E. Tappan and others to recover damages for fraud and conspiracy. From an order denying defendants' motion for a new trial but reducing the verdict subject to plaintiff's acceptance of the reduction, defendants appeal. Order affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Molina v. Sovereign Camp, W.O.W.
Court: District Court, D. Nebraska, Omaha Division.
Headnote: Where representative in Mexico of American fraternal benefit association organized a Mexican fraternal benefit association to enable him to perpetrate a fraud on American association, the government of Mexico, and American association's policyholders in Mexico, and to acquire American association's Mexican business, equity would disregard the corporate entity, and therefore the Mexican association stood in the shoes of the representative who organized it, as respects any claim for reimbursement by American association for the fraud practiced by the representative.
Document Preview: Action by Manuel Maria Molina and others against Sovereign Camp of the Woodmen of the World, a corporation, for an accounting and other relief. Action dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Pearl Assur. Co. v. National Ins. Agency
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where corporate defendant, licensed only as insurance broker, appropriated premiums actually received on fire policies which had been entrusted to it by insurer for purpose of delivery and to collect premiums and pay the same, less commission, to insurer, the corporate defendant's sole stockholder who personally performed all acts complained of could be held personally liable to the insurer.
Document Preview: Appeals Nos. 112, 116 October Term, 1941, from Judgment of Court of Common Pleas No. 2 of Philadelphia County, to No. 597 June Term, 1940; Frank Smith, Judge. On reargument. Judgment for plaintiff affirmed. For original opinion, see 150 Pa.Super. 265, 28 A.2d 334.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Rogers-Ebert Co. v. Century Const. Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of New Jersey.
Headnote: Where evidence established that real estate dealer evolved scheme for purpose of defrauding creditors, including complainant, by acquiring property in dealer's own name and holding out to public that property was owned by various corporations which the dealer used as dummies, that a judgment at law was obtained by complainant against a dummy corporation, and that during pendency of the law action the dealer unwittingly put title to certain property in name of the dummy corporation, the dummy corporation would be considered as one and the same with the dealer, and court of chancery would not consider them as separate entities and declare a "resulting trust" in favor of the dealer and thereby permit him to avoid payment of the judgment. N.J.S.A. 2:29-110.
Document Preview: Action by the Rogers-Ebert Company against Century Construction Co. and others to set aside a fraudulent conveyance and in aid of a judgment at law, wherein defendant Jack Epstein filed a counterclaim seeking decree adjudging that defendant Century Construction Co. holds title to certain property in trust for the defendant Jack Epstein. Decree to be entered directing payment of complainant's judgment from moneys on deposit, dismissing bill of complaint as to defendants Pauline Epstein and Century Construction Co., and dismissing the counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Ashby v. Peters
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded, and persons responsible for fraud committed by corporation may be held liable therefor in their individual capacity.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Lancaster County; Shepherd, Judge. Action by Minnie I. Ashby against Richard C. Peters and others. From a judgment for plaintiff, defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: K.H. Butler & Co. v. A Certain Fund of Money, etc.
Court: Court of Appeals of District of Columbia.
Headnote: Repayment of loan between corporations having interlocking directorates held not to raise presumption of fraud; money for repayment being raised personally by sole stockholder of borrowing corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia. Suit by K. H. Butler & Co., Inc., against a certain fund of money, Thomas W. Miller, as Alien Property Custodian, and Frank White, as Treasurer of the United States. From a decree overruling exceptions to the report of the special master, confirming the report and dismissing the bill, plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Murphy v. Jewell
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Occupants of vehicle adequately pleaded that sole shareholder of transportation company, whose employee allegedly injured occupants when he lost control of truck on expressway, dominated company and engaged in acts amounting to abuse of corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against occupants, as required to state claim to pierce the corporate veil and impose personal liability on shareholder; occupants alleged shareholder wound down company following accident and transferred company assets to three other corporate entities in effort to keep company undercapitalized and judgment proof. N.Y. CPLR § 3211(a)(7).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiffs stated claim for piercing corporate veil against sole shareholder who allegedly wound down company following accident to be judgment proof.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: "Injustice" prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not satisfied with regard to trucking companies for which injured tractor-trailer driver was working at time of accident, and thus alter ego theory did not provide basis for piercing corporate veil and holding trucking companies' owner and his wife individually liable in driver and his wife's action for negligence and gross negligence, although companies had opted out of workers' compensation; nothing in record indicated that owner or wife abused the corporate form, and there was evidence that companies had the resources to protect their drivers. Tex. Labor Code Ann. § 406.002(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Injustice prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not met in truck driver's personal injury action against trucking companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Webb v. Medicalodges, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Estate of skilled nursing facility resident put forth sufficient allegations to pierce corporate veil of corporation which operated facility, and thus could maintain claim against corporation for alter ego liability under Missouri law, regarding resident's death after she developed urosepsis; estate pleaded that corporation exercised complete control and domination over facility's policy and business practices, such that facility had no separate mind of its own as to funding, staffing, and patient load and acuity levels, pleaded that such control was used to deplete facility's assets, thereby making it unable to pay a judgment resulting from its care, and to violate legal duty of care through understaffing, and pleaded that such control proximately caused resident's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Estate of skilled nursing facility resident put forth sufficient allegations to pierce the corporate veil of corporation which operated facility.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Brummett v. Bailey
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil was not warranted to find owner, who was sole shareholder of bar, and former owner, who financed owner's purchase of bar, personally liable for alleged acts of bar staff in breaching duty of care to patron injured in altercation in which he allegedly was assaulted by another patron in the bar, even though other patron had previously installed cameras in bar and done plumbing and construction work for owner for ten years; owner, who was also employed by bar as bar manager, was still making monthly installment payments to former owner in connection with the purchase, but owner did not operate bar in a personal capacity and observed all corporate formalities, and no evidence suggested owner or former owner were present at bar at time of altercation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to find bar's owner and former owner personally liable for alleged assault on patron.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Tubbs v. Swift Transportation Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Laredo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, unless alter ego is established, corporate officers are subject to personal liability for their actions within the employment context only when they breach an independent duty of care.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Parties. Worker, who was Texan, stated personal injury claim against coworker, who was also a Texas citizen, precluding finding of improper joinder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Doherty v. Town of Woodstock
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on corporation's sole shareholder was unwarranted in pedestrian's personal-injury action that arose from incident in which pedestrian slipped and fell on town's sidewalk that abutted corporation's property, at which two other companies that shareholder owned had their main offices, after it began snowing, despite contention that shareholder effectively negotiated with himself for rent payments, absent any indication that shareholder was using corporation for fraudulent purposes, that action against corporation would provide inadequate relief, or that shareholder improperly intermingled business and personal funds or was purposely running corporation without profit, assets, or capital to shield himself from personal-injury liability. 11A Vt. Stat. Ann. § 6.22(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose liability on corporation's sole shareholder was unwarranted in action arising from slip and fall on sidewalk.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Hamilton v. Young Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil was not warranted under Massachusetts law in order to bring within the jurisdiction of the district court either the successor to booking agent with which vacationer and her husband booked travel or an allegedly related partnership, in action brought by vacationer and husband, asserting claims for negligence and breach of contract, stemming from vacationer's injury at resort, despite their argument that agent, its successor, and partnership were alter egos of each other; although such entities had a common owner, shared an address, and had the common purpose of supporting owner's hotels, there was no evidence that owner disregarded corporate formalities, mixed assets among entities, or operated the companies as a front to perpetrate fraud or escape jurisdiction.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Booking agent availed itself of the privilege of conducting activities in forum state, thus subjecting it to jurisdiction in injured traveler's suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Lowery v. Noodle Life, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Corporate owner of restaurant with same name as restaurant that allegedly improperly packaged a "to go" container of hot soup that spilled onto customer's lap and severely burned her inner thighs and groin area when she retrieved the package from the front seat of her car could not be held liable under the alter ego doctrine, absent evidence that the two corporate owners of the two restaurants were interchangeable entities; there was no evidence that one corporation was an instrumentality for the transactions of the other, or that there was any commingling of assets, records, or employees, nor was there any evidence that one had the right to control the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of restaurant with same name as restaurant that served customer a package of hot soup that burned her was not liable under the alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Lowery v. Noodle Life, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Corporate owner of restaurant with same name as restaurant that allegedly improperly packaged a "to go" container of hot soup that spilled onto customer's lap and severely burned her inner thighs and groin area when she retrieved the package from the front seat of her car could not be held liable under the doctrine of apparent or ostensible agency, where customer pointed to no evidence showing that corporate owner held the owner of the restaurant that served her the soup out to be its agent or that she relied on any such representation. Ga. Code Ann. § 10-6-1.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of restaurant with same name as restaurant that served customer a package of hot soup that burned her was not liable under the alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Micheli v. Michigan Automobile Insurance Placement Facility
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Subject to exceptions for malpractice, principles of respecting the corporate form generally apply to professional corporations.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Automobile. Records that were subject of plaintiff's subpoena to nonparty doctor were relevant and, thus, discoverable, in action for PIP benefits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: In re Flint Water Cases
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, there was no evidence that parent corporation exercised control over subsidiary in manner amounting to fraud, wrong, or misuse of corporate form, and thus, corporate veil could not be pierced to impose alter ego liability against parent for alleged professional negligence of subsidiary engineering services contractor for city's water treatment plant, based on parent-subsidiary relationship, in Bellwether cases regarding city's contaminated water supply, since subsidiary was not formed for any improper purpose and did not engage in unlawful activity through performance of professional engineering services.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego liability could not be imposed against parent by piercing corporate veil based on parent-subsidiary relationship in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Neill v. Cinema de Lux
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation of movie theater operator did not owe duty of care to patron who allegedly fell on wet condition in restroom at leased premises, in absence of any evidence that corporation exercised complete domination and control over the wholly owned subsidiary, to which it had assigned its rights and obligations under the lease.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Parent corporation owed no duty of care to patron who fell on premises operated by wholly-owned subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Clarke v. Service Employees International Union
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: There was no unity of interest and ownership between union that had employed employee and union that had imposed trusteeship over employer union, such that unions were inseparable from one another, as necessary to hold union that imposed trusteeship liable, pursuant to alter ego liability, in action brought by employee against unions, alleging breach of contract, breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, intentional interference with contractual relations, wrongful termination, tortious discharge, and negligence; employer union maintained its own accounts and was financed by its members, and trustees utilized employer union's headquarters and finances during trusteeship.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Unions. There was no unity of interest and ownership between union that had employed employee and another union, as necessary to impose alter ego liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ledford v. Keen
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, rodeo attendee could not pierce rodeo operating club's corporate veil, so as to sue club's directors personally, based solely on evidence that club was undercapitalized, in attendee's negligence action against club arising out of injury which occurred while attending rodeo.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Texas law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, corporate veil could not be pierced based solely on evidence of undercapitalization.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Cunningham v. Mary Agnes Manor Management, L.L.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Administrator of decedent's estate stated a claim for negligence premised on theory of vicarious liability based on doctrine of piercing the corporate veil in action to recover damages arising from injuries decedent suffered while he was patient at a nursing home facility and was assaulted by another resident of facility who had history of mental illness and violent behavior, where administrator alleged corporations acting as owner and operator of nursing home were operated in such a way as if they were one by commingling them on an interchangeable basis or convoluted separate properties, records or control, and alleged corporate formalities were conduits to avoid obligations to facility's residents.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Administrator of decedent's estate stated claim for negligence premised on theory of vicarious liability based on doctrine of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Cunningham v. Mary Agnes Manor Management, L.L.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: To state cause of action for negligence premised on theory of vicarious liability based on doctrine of piercing corporate veil or alter ego, plaintiff must allege that the domination and control of corporation constituted a fraud or an abuse of the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Administrator of decedent's estate stated claim for negligence premised on theory of vicarious liability based on doctrine of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Cunningham v. Mary Agnes Manor Management, L.L.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Administrator of decedent's estate stated a claim that corporations acting as owner and operator of nursing home were vicariously liable for decedent's injuries under theories of agency and joint venture in action to recover damages arising from injuries decedent suffered while he was patient at nursing home facility and was assaulted by another resident of facility who had history of mental illness and violent behavior, where administrator alleged corporations acted as agents for one another, and ratified the acts of one another regarding operation of facility, allocation of resources, and mismanagement of facility.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Administrator of decedent's estate stated claim for negligence premised on theory of vicarious liability based on doctrine of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: McElroy v. FirstEnergy Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, security guard employed by security company, who fell on a set of stairs and injured his ankle while working at power plant, together with his wife could not pierce the corporate veil to assert claims for negligence and loss of consortium against plant operator's parent company, since these were straightforward torts, that were not based on allegations of extreme shareholder misconduct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Security guard injured in fall at jobsite could not pierce corporate veil to assert tort claims against parent of jobsite operator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Layne Christensen Company v. City of Franklin, Tennessee
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: City, who alleged subsidiary of water resource company performed defective work prior to company's acquisition of subsidiary, was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil of water resource company or its parent company in action brought by company against city for declaratory judgment to determine whether company was financially liable for alleged defective work; city did not assert that company or subsidiary used the corporate entity to avoid obligations, and at the time subsidiary performed the alleged defective work company and its parent company were not in control of subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Fact issue existed whether company's acquisition of subsidiary resulted in mere continuance of subsidiary on issue of company's liability for subsidiary's defective work.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Avery v. Schneider as Next Friend of Schneider
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Allegations supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil to find officer for corporate entity hired to oversee safety, maintenance, and supervision of pool liable in action by parents and next friend of minor child, who nearly died from drowning and sustained brain injury, for negligence and fraud, despite claim that entity owed no duty or damages; officer and entity held entity out as qualified pool management company with properly trained and qualified lifeguards to protect members of community, lifeguard failed to employ proper post-drowning lifesaving techniques after she became aware of incident because she was improperly trained and supervised by entity, and since incident, and child had regular seizures requiring constant medication, migraine headaches, processing difficulties, poor memory, social difficulties, and other neurological and academic issues. (Per Hodges, J., with one judge concurring in the result.)
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Allegations supported finding that officer for corporate entity that supervised pool breached duty to child who nearly drowned by inadequately training lifeguard.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Johnson & Johnson Talcum Powder Cases
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Agency or alter ego theory did not apply to render initial manufacturer of talcum powder, which passed production to wholly owned subsidiary, liable for negligent failure to warn of risks of ovarian cancer after manufacturer had ceased production, despite contention that manufacturer was "directing" subsidiary's actions; even though there was legal relationship between manufacturer and subsidiary, which had similar company names, and some coordination between manufacturer and subsidiary on issues related to talc, manufacturer did not control subsidiary or treat subsidiary as merely conduit or instrumentality of itself.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Warnings. Initial manufacturer of talcum powder did not have duty to warn of ovarian cancer risk at time it was manufacturing or after it ceased production.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Stoneledge at Lake Keowee Owners' Association, Inc. v. IMK Development Co., LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's ruling that business operations of two developers engaged in a townhome development enterprise were in pursuit of a common business purpose so as to justify amalgamation of their interests in action alleging negligence, breach of implied warranty of workmanlike service, and breach of fiduciary duty; developers were corporately affiliated under one umbrella company, which was created to hold the title for the townhome project, developers passed corporate funds, they allowed individual members to operate as dual agents without distinction as to who they represented, they shared responsibility for management of the team selling the townhome units, they appeared as one and the same to members of the homeowners association, and profits of both developers were entirely dependent upon the sales of the units.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Developers could be held liable for their own negligent construction, but not for negligence of prior developers from whom they took over the project.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Stoner v. Montpelier Tavern Company
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Williams County.
Headnote: Bar owner, who was sole shareholder of company that owned bar, was not liable for injury to patron resulting from a fight at the bar, absent evidence that bar owner was indistinguishable from or the alter ego of the bar itself, or that owner established bar to defraud existing creditors or evade existing obligations.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Patron injured in bar fight failed to demonstrate foreseeability of violence required to established negligence claim against bar.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Doe v. Bank of America Corporation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Bank's parent corporation could not be held liable for negligence or breach of contract based on bank's alleged actions in abruptly closing, without explanation, accounts held by an international political figure and his daughter, where plaintiffs pled no facts under either a direct or derivative theory of liability and advanced no alternative theories under which parent could be found liable, as bank agreement governing the accounts made clear that relevant banking relationship was with bank, not its parent, which was accepted by plaintiffs when they signed personal signature cards that indicated that banking agreement governed their accounts.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING  Accounts. There was no claim for breach of implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing where bank had no contractual duty to not close bank accounts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Cerrato v. Dee Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Home purchasers failed to demonstrate that individual defendants dominated the corporate entities they represented by, inter alia, ignoring corporate formalities and engaging in self-dealing in order to perpetuate a fraud or wrong against purchasers, thus precluding court from piercing corporate veil in purchaser's action alleging negligence in the architectural design and construction of their new home.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil in home purchaser's negligence action was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Gourdine v. Karl Storz Endoscopy–America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under California law, German medical device manufacturer's subsidiary, which was a California company that marketed and distributed the devices within the United States, was manufacturer's agent under representative services theory, as required for subsidiary's actions to be imputed to manufacturer in patient's products liability action; manufacturer and subsidiary shared the same market branding, manufacturer drafted all marketing, training, and sales materials used by the subsidiary and directed the subsidiary to market its products in all states, manufacturer had similar subsidiaries in other markets around the world and managed those subsidiaries collectively, and services of those subsidiaries were essential to manufacturer's unitary enterprise.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over German medical device manufacturer in products liability action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Cobra 4 Enterprises v. Powell-Newman
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Individual owner of both lessor corporation, which owned vehicle, and lessor company, which leased vehicle, was alter ego of those companies, and thus motorist who was allegedly injured in accident caused by lessee company's employee could pierce corporate veil and hold owner personally liable; owner was sole owner of both companies, he funded them initially with his own money and he used them to protect his own assets, owner under-insured companies, and he sold lessee company's vehicles to lessor corporation for only $1 a piece, and owner ignored corporate formalities with respect to lessor corporation, as he failed to hold shareholder meetings or elections of corporate officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation that owned vehicle involved in accident was not alter ego of sibling company that leased vehicle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Cobra 4 Enterprises v. Powell-Newman
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Lessor corporation that leased vehicle to lessee company was not alter ego of the lessee company, and thus motorist who was allegedly injured in accident caused by lessee company's employee could not pierce corporate veil horizontally and hold lessor corporation liable in personal injury action, though companies were sibling companies owned by same individual and there was some overlap between companies; there was no evidence that companies commingled their assets or otherwise confused their separate records or control, lessor corporation had no right to control or possession over vehicles leased to lessee company, lessor corporation had leased vehicles to other company that owner did not own, companies had separate bank accounts, and neither company paid any expenses for the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation that owned vehicle involved in accident was not alter ego of sibling company that leased vehicle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Federico v. Lincoln Military Housing, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, parent company of property acquisition and management company that managed and operated military housing communities could not be held liable in action, brought by family that resided in military housing community, against company and independent contractor, alleging violations of Virginia Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (VRLTA), breach of lease, negligence, and negligence per se, based on allegations that property company and contractor failed to disclose known and concealed defects concerning water intrusion and mold, failed to maintain portions of home outside the exclusive possession and control of tenant, and negligently performed repairs, where parent company did not use organizational structure to perpetrate fraud or gain unfair advantage, and separateness of companies did not work injustice. West's V.C.A. § 36–97 et seq.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Immunity. Family's claim against company that managed military housing community was not barred by derivative immunity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Collins v. State Farm Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Exceptional circumstances did not exist, and thus piercing of corporate veil was not warranted, so as to hold homeowner's insurance agent personally liable for any negligent misrepresentation by insurance agency, where agent, who was sole shareholder of agency, did not commit fraud, and did not entirely ignore corporate formalities.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Insurance agent had no independent duty to inform insured of homeowner's insurer's cancellation or nonrenewal of homeowner's insurance policy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Muniz v. Walgreen Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, corporate parent of drug store operator did not exercise sufficient control over operator to warrant piercing corporate veil in customers' negligence action alleging that their child was given wrong prescription, although operator and parent shared close branding relationship, where parent did not disregard corporate formalities, parent did not exercise control over operator's day-to-day operations, parent and operator did not have overlapping directors or personnel, operator was not undercapitalized, operator filed independent annual reports, operator had own headquarters, operator independently obtained all necessary licensing and permits required by Puerto Rico, operator maintained separate accounting books, and operator paid salary of its employees.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Puerto Rico contacts of drug store operator's corporate parent were not proximate cause of child receiving wrong prescription.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Glenn v. TPI Petroleum, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil of parent company was not warranted in order to establish liability for alleged wrongful acts of subsidiaries related to negligence action, where parent company was a holding company without employees or direct involvement in provision of goods or services, there was no evidence of comingling of funds between parent and subsidiaries or that parent controlled decisions and acts of subsidiaries, the only tangible indication of a relationship between parent and subsidiaries was location of offices at a shared address, and there was no allegation that parent engaged in any wrongdoing.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked limited personal jurisdiction over non-resident petroleum company in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Nieto-Vincenty v. Valledor
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, piercing corporate veil of corporation that was record owner of vessel that sank in order to impose individual liability on director and shareholder of corporation was not warranted, in action by passengers who were aboard vessel when it sank, asserting claims for negligence and maritime tort, even though corporation was extensively controlled by its shareholders, absent evidence that corporation was merely shareholder's alter ego or that recognizing the corporate form would sanction a fraud or promote an injustice. 14 L.P.R.A. § 3501 et seq.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Personal Injury. Vessel passenger's wife was not in zone of danger, as required to establish admiralty claim for NIED.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Seghers v. LaPlace Equipment Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Worker failed to allege fraud or deceit, or to assert facts that suggested that the purported manager/employee of rental company had a personal duty towards worker separate from manager/employee's corporate duties, as required to ignore the corporate entity and to hold manager/employee personally liable for the rental company's purported negligence and worker's injuries; manager/employee attested that he did not personally select the equipment that was rented to worker's employer, and that he was not directly involved in the subject rental.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Venue. Corporate defendant waived improper venue by answering before filing a declinatory exception of improper venue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: U.S. v. Trek Leather, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Penalties could not be imposed upon person who was acting in his capacity as officer of corporate "importer of record" for negligently filling out entry papers required of corporation, absent piercing corporate veil to establish that officer was actual importer of record, or establishing that officer was liable for fraud or as aider and abettor of fraud by corporation. Tariff Act of 1930, §§ 484, 485, 592(a)(1)(B), (c)(2), 641, 19 U.S.C.A. §§ 1484, 1485, 1592(a)(1)(B), (c)(2), 1641.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Customs and Tariffs. Penalties could not be imposed upon person who was acting in his capacity as officer of corporate importer of record.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Vasquez v. Sportsman's Inn, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Because bar patron failed to establish a reasonable likelihood of success on the merits of his underlying negligence claim against bar operator for shooting incident that occurred outside of bar, it was premature to consider piercing the corporate veil so as to hold bar lessor liable.
Document Preview: TORTS - Injunction. Patron failed to show likelihood of success on merits on negligence claim as required for preliminary injunction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: DeCaprio v. Gas & Oil, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Summit County.
Headnote: Corporate veil of heating oil delivery company could not be pierced to impose personal liability on president/sole shareholder for damage to home caused when company employee accidentally pumped heating oil directly into basement with no receptacle to contain it, since evidence did not show that president/shareholder had complete control over the company; although company did not possess liability insurance at time of incident, there was no showing that president/shareholder commingled funds, failed to observe corporate formalities, failed to keep accounting records, and/or commingled assets of the company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of heating oil company could not be pierced to impose personal liability on shareholder for oil spill.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: North Cypress Medical Center Operating Co. Ltd v. Fedex Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Delivery service provider's parent company could not be held liable for provider's alleged negligence in failing to notify medical center operator that a box containing confidential patient information had been dropped and documents had been lost during shipment merely because of their corporate relationship.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Airline Deregulation Act preempted medical center operator's tort claims against delivery service provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Endsley Elec., Inc. v. Altech, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil in action by general contractor for breach of contract and negligence, even if it lacked the funds or cash flow to pay all of its bills, where any such lack of funds did not render shareholders or officers liable for corporate debt, and contractor did not produce any evidence of subcontractor's capital, other assets, debts, and liabilities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Endsley Elec., Inc. v. Altech, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Forfeiture of subcontractor's corporation charter did not support personal liability for corporate officers or shareholders in action by general contractor for breach of contract and negligence, where there was no evidence that the liability case was created or incurred after the corporate forfeiture. V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 171.255.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor was not undercapitalized as would support the piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Atelier Constantin Popescu, LLC v. JC Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Lessor's sole corporate officers, who were also two of four shareholders, did not observe corporate formalities and exerted a large amount of control over lessor, and thus lessor's corporate veil could be pierced, so as to impose personal liability on officers for gross negligence and recklessness in causing fire that destroyed commercial building prior to lessee's taking possession, in breach of lease providing that lessor could be liable for damages caused by lessor's gross negligence or willful misconduct preventing lessee from taking initial possession; officers had complete control of lessor's finances, made all corporate decisions without consulting other two shareholders, and did not contact other shareholders regarding lease.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lessor breached commercial lease by recklessly causing fire that destroyed building prior to lessee taking possession.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Yanmar Co., Ltd. v. Slater
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: American subsidiary of Japanese tractor manufacturer owed no duty to purchaser, who was using tractor to mow grass on slope near a pond on his property when it rolled over, thereby killing him, for purposes of negligence action brought by purchaser's estate; subsidiary was not even in existence at the time that the tractor was manufactured, subsidiary had nothing to do with the design, manufacture, or distribution of the tractor, subsidiary never sold purchaser a part for his tractor, and appellate court would not impute any duty of manufacturer to its subsidiary because there was no indication that subsidiary was engaged in a joint venture with manufacturer or acted as an agent for manufacturer.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Courts did not have general jurisdiction over Japanese tractor manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Howsden v. Roper's Real Estate Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Corporate tenant's employee's third-party claim against corporate landlord, a separate legal entity, alleging that landlord's negligence caused the injuries employee sustained when she fell down an elevator shaft on the leased premises, was not barred by the exclusive remedy provision of the Workers' Compensation Act, even though landlord was owned and operated by the same shareholders as tenant, where there was no equitable basis in the record to justify piercing the corporate veil between landlord and tenant, and there was no basis to conclude that employee was employed by both tenant and landlord. West's Neb.Rev.St. § 48–148.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Corporate employee's claim against separate legal entity owned by same shareholders was not barred by exclusive remedy provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Kindig v. Whole Foods Market Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, corporation's principal was not subject to individual liability in action seeking indemnification and contribution for liability in personal injury suit, where there was no allegation that corporation was simply principal's alter ego or was being used to perpetuate fraud or wrong, and only corporation had entered into agreement with party seeking indemnification and contribution.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Store owner's claims against parking lot operator for indemnification and contribution were subject to arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Hottenstein v. City of Seal Isle City
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, individual shareholder of corporation that owned bar could not be held personally liable for bar's alleged violation of New Jersey's Dram Shop Act and negligence, which allegedly resulted in death of patron when she fell off a dock while intoxicated, absent any allegations that shareholder used corporate form to defeat ends of justice, perpetrate a fraud, or otherwise evade the law or that the individual shareholder was at the bar or in contact with patron during the relevant time period. N.J.S.A. 2A:22A–4.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Negligence claims against bars were barred by the New Jersey Dram Shop Act's exclusive remedy provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Michnovez v. Blair, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Under New Hampshire law, sister corporation of company which had performed testing on bathrobe material for compliance with federal flammability standards could not be held liable for company's negligence in failing to properly conduct the tests, under a single-enterprise theory, since New Hampshire did not recognize the theory; New Hampshire veil piercing law provided only that owners of corporations could be held liable for the debts of the corporations they owned.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Under New Hampshire law, corporation was not liable for the negligence of its sister corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ramcke v. Georgia Power Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for any negligence on part of subsidiary that owned property and subsidiary that engineered and designed property's construction project on property regarding alleged failure to keep premises safe during project; there was insufficient evidence to pierce corporate veil, and there was no indication that parent corporation participated in a joint venture with its subsidiaries or acted as their agent or alter ego. West's Ga.Code Ann. § 51–3–1.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Property owner and its agent had no duty to keep work premises safe for construction company's invitees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Kriegel v. Bank of America, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Banking corporation could not be held directly liable for alleged fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, negligent misrepresentation, and violations of Washington's Consumer Protection Act (WCPA) that purportedly arose from automatic renewal of certificate of deposit (CD) by corporation's subsidiary. While corporation and subsidiary clearly had similar names, the deposit agreement governing the CD specifically defined the name of the bank as referring to the subsidiary. Customer's relationship was solely with the subsidiary. West's RCWA 19.86.020.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Banking corporation could not be held directly liable regarding automatic renewal of certificate of deposit by subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Huff v. First Energy Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Trumbull County.
Headnote: Holding company that developed specifications controlling manner in which subsidiary companies would manage vegetation surrounding electrical lines owed no duty of care to pedestrian who was struck by decaying maple tree in inspection zone created by those specifications, where holding company did not create subsidiary power company that had easement to control surrounding vegetation, there was no indication that holding company obtained its controlling interest to defraud or engage in malfeasance, and there was no indication that holding company supervised power company's implementation of specifications or had any say over which contractor was hired to manage vegetation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Issue as to whether pedestrian struck by tree was intended beneficiary of vegetation management contract barred summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: J. Criss Builder, Inc. v. White
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: Owner of building company, which was a corporation, was subject to individual liability to homeowners in their suit against owner and company alleging breach of warranty, negligence, and failure to disclose regarding construction of homeowners' home, which allegedly had foundation defects, as owner was a licensed residential builder, company did not have builder's license, such that it was prohibited from performing residential construction, and, thus, owner, in her individual capacity, was the licensed builder of home. West's A.M.C. §§ 73-59-1(b), 73-59-3(1), 73-59-9(3).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Trial court's grant of additur absent required statutory findings was abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Marlyn Nutraceuticals, Inc. v. Improvita Health Products
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Corporate veil need not have been pierced, under Arizona law, to assert fraud or negligence claims against corporate officers.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Arizona court had specific jurisdiction over Ohio buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Mynes v. Brooks
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fourth District, Scioto County.
Headnote: Purchasers could not prevail on claim of negligent construction against vendors in their individual capacities, even though the vendors were owners of the development corporation that constructed the house, absent evidence that vendors exercised control over the corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act as would justify piercing corporate veil. (Per Kline, J., with one judge concurring in result.)
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. In light of as is sale, doctrine of caveat emptor barred purchasers' negligent misrepresentation against vendors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: R.F.M.A.S., Inc. v. Mimi So
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Competitors which had produced allegedly infringing line of jewelry were not alter egos of other competitors which had invested in their business and which previously entered into negotiations to invest in copyright owner's jewelry business, as would be required to find investing competitor had directly infringed owner's trade dress as to certain pieces of jewelry in violation of Lanham Act; jewelry-producing competitor was separately incorporated entity, and only two out of five members of its board of directors were appointed by investing competitor, investing competitor held only minority interest in jewelry-producing competitor when it invested in competitor, and there would be no injustice or unfairness if competitors' corporate structure would be respected, as owners have alleged vicarious and contributory infringement against investing competitor, which would hold them liable for acts of jewelry-producing competitor without piercing corporate veils of competitors. Lanham Act, § 43(a), 15 U.S.C.A. § 1125(a).
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Competitors did not directly infringe owner's copyright to pieces of jewelry.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ward v. Cross County Multiplex Cinemas, Inc
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff, who was injured at a theater, failed to allege the type of domination required to pierce the corporate veil, so as to hold parent corporation of theater's owner liable for the purported negligence of the theater owner.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Merged corporation was not liable for purported negligence of surviving corporate occurring more than two years after merger.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Shaw v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: A parent corporation could not be held liable for the alleged negligent actions of its indirect subsidiary in Brazil where the parent corporation was a separate and distinct legal entity that was not responsible for the Brazil subsidiary. The parent corporation asserted that the subsidiary had separate corporate leadership and separate finances. Despite being given the explicit opportunity to do so, an injured consumer did not provide any evidence to the contrary nor did the consumer allege that the parent corporation's improper corporate conduct caused the consumer inability to obtain an adequate remedy from the subsidiary. Therefore, the parent corporation's motion to dismiss was granted.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dismissal. A parent corporation could not be held liable for the alleged negligent actions of its indirect subsidiary in Brazil where the parent corporation was a separate and distinct legal entity that was not responsible for the Brazil subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Nassau County v. Richard Dattner Architect, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for alleged breach of contract and negligence of contractor acquired by its subsidiary was not warranted, absent showing that parent dominated and controlled the activities of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to hold parent liable for subsidiary's breach of contract

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Davidovici v. Fritzson
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of former employer was not justified, as required to hold its officer personally liable for new employer's claims of negligent hiring and supervision and negligent infliction of emotional distress based on employee's alleged embezzlement of new employer's accounts.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Former employer's hiring and supervision was not proximate cause of damages to new employer from employee's embezzlement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Haynes v. Edgerson
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil of insurance agency to hold agent personally liable was justified, in context of insured's action against insurance agency and agent for negligent procurement of insurance, arising from denial of liability coverage to insured after patron attending party at hall was shot and killed; agency had no assets beyond office furniture and had insurance coverage good for only one year, which was essentially the state agency was in when it was incorporated, agent completed and signed paperwork, mostly in form of applications for insured's first and second policies, and he contacted and informed insured about coverage, and agent had complete control over the agency.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Insurance agent had duty to procure same liability coverage for insured in renewing policy or to explain why he could not.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Figueiredo v. New Palace Painters Supply Co. Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: General contractor could not seek indemnification or contribution from property owner on negligence and scaffolding law claims asserted against general contractor on behalf of laborer who died on renovation project when he fell through an open hole, though general contractor and property owner shared common owners and officers, as general contractor and property owner were separate entities and not parent/subsidiary, property owner had hired general contractor to run the renovation project, and property owner did not supervise, direct, or control the contractors or work, and it did not enter into contracts with subcontractors, or provide tools or materials. McKinney's Labor Law § 240(1).
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Contractors and Developers. Violation of scaffolding law was the proximate cause of death of laborer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Mistrulli v. McFinnigan, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no basis upon which to pierce the corporate veil so as to hold individuals who were shareholders of corporation that allegedly owned and operated bar in which plaintiff's husband was fatally stabbed during altercation with other patrons liable for common-law negligence and violation of the Dram Shop Act; the evidence failed to raise a triable issue of fact as to the presence of either element required to pierce the veil, namely, that the individuals exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction at issue, or that such domination was used to commit a wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury. McKinney's General Obligations Law § 11-101.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced as to individuals who owned company that owned bar in which patron was fatally stabbed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Pico v. Capriccio Italian Restaurant, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Unless alter ego is established, a corporate officer or agent may be individually liable to others for his own negligence within the employment context only when he owes an independent duty of reasonable care to the injured party apart from the employer's duty.
Document Preview: TORTS - Wrongful Death. Issue of whether assault occurred on nightclub premises precluded summary judgment for nightclub in wrongful death action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Farmers Alliance Mut. Ins. Co. v. Naylor
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was unwarranted, for purpose of holding fire investigator who owned fire investigation corporation personally liable, in property insurer's action alleging breach of contract and professional negligence, arising from investigator's alleged failure to preserve evidence of the origin of fire on insured's premises; corporation adhered to corporate formalities, it was operated in a legitimate way to serve the goals of the corporation, rather than for the benefit of the individual investigator, corporation was properly capitalized, and there was no showing that investigator's corporate status was linked to insurer's alleged injury.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Economic loss rule did not bar professional negligence claim arising from service contract with fire investigator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Berhow v. The Peoples Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, holding corporation was not vicariously liable to bank customer for negligence and gross negligence in supervising activities of bank's loan officer, who fraudulently obtained funds in customer's name over course of several years, on ground that holding corporation and bank shared officers and directors, absent any evidence of a frustration of contractual expectations, a flagrant disregard of corporate formalities, or a demonstration of fraud or some other equivalent misfeasance on the part of holding corporation.
