Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. UCC section which limited remedy for conversion to compensatory damages applied to bank customer's claims against bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Berry v. Lee
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Corporate agents could not be held individually liable under Texas law for negligent failure to warn and negligent supervision of employee who allegedly sexually assaulted a subordinate employee where subordinate employee did not allege that either corporate agent was the alter ego of the employer or that either had an independent duty to give notice to her, to supervise employee, or to provide a safe workplace, apart from that person's duties arising in the course and scope of his employment.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Chinese corporation and other corporate entities were a single business enterprise for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Moyle v. Elliott Aviation, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Charter flight subsidiary of parent aviation company did not perform repairs or maintenance work on decedent's single-engine aircraft, precluding decedent's estate from recovering on negligence claim against subsidiary following decedent's fatal plane crash, even though parent company printed subsidiary's name on an invoice for the relevant repairs; charter flight subsidiary appeared on invoice in clerical error, parent company's other subsidiary, a repair facility, admitted that it performed the allegedly negligent repairs, and payment collected by invoice was credited to the repair subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Aviation repair subsidiary was a viable corporation, precluding estate from piercing the corporate veil in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Moyle v. Elliott Aviation, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Subsidiary of parent aviation company that admitted to performing repairs to decedent's single-engine aircraft, which repairs allegedly caused decedent's fatal air crash, was a viable corporation, precluding decedent's estate from piercing the corporate veil in order to hold parent company liable for subsidiary's alleged negligence; even though subsidiary did not maintain a separate bank account from parent, subsidiary was a licensed aircraft repair business and carried its own liability insurance policy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Aviation repair subsidiary was a viable corporation, precluding estate from piercing the corporate veil in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Moyle v. Elliott Aviation, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Repair subsidiary of parent aviation company was not a mere instrumentality of its parent, precluding decedent's estate from recovering on negligence claim against the parent company for repairs performed by subsidiary that allegedly caused decedent's fatal single-engine plane crash; subsidiary did not intend to avoid a legal obligation, as it conceded that it performed the allegedly negligent repairs, it did not move for summary judgment, and its financial resources included a large liability insurance policy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Aviation repair subsidiary was a viable corporation, precluding estate from piercing the corporate veil in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Beck v. Consolidated Rail Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, pedestrian's conclusory statements were insufficient to support piercing of parent corporation's corporate veil based on its subsidiary's alleged negligence in maintaining property, in pedestrian's negligence action to recover damages for injury she sustained when concrete curb broke under her foot, causing her to fall forward into street, absent evidence that parent corporation managed subsidiary, or that any control parent corporation exercised over subsidiary was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured pedestrian.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Former owner of property owed no direct duty to pedestrian injured when curb broke under her foot.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Forsythe v. Clark USA, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Estates of deceased employees who alleged that employer's sole corporate shareholder, by mandating that employer was to operate oil refinery at 25% cost reduction, interposed guiding hand in employer's management of refinery, leaving employer no choice but to obey, invoked "direct participation" exception to the general rule that corporate veil will not be pierced in absence of large-scale disregard of separate existence of subsidiary corporation, given that estates' theory of negligence did not rest upon corporate shareholder's legal status in relation to employer, but, instead, on shareholder's own conduct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employees' estates invoked direct participation exception to rule that corporate veil will not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Wood v. McDonald's Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence did not support piercing corporate veil to impose liability, in restaurant patron's slip-and-fall negligence action, on president of corporations that had been assigned the restaurant franchise and that managed the restaurant pursuant to management services agreement; evidence showed that each corporation adhered to corporate formalities and kept separate records, that regular meetings of shareholders and directors were held, that minutes were kept, that bylaws were in place, and that each corporation had obtained same amount of liability insurance coverage.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support piercing corporate veil of assignee of restaurant franchise and management company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Coleman & Co. Securities, Inc. v. Giaquinto Family Trust
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, reverse veil piercing doctrine that holds a corporate entity liable for the acts of its shareholders is not available in the negligence context.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Limitations. Discovery rule did not toll statute of limitations on investors' state securities fraud claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Coleman & Co. Securities, Inc. v. Giaquinto Family Trust
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Even if broker-dealer was dominated by investment advisor who also was board member and part owner of broker-dealer, that domination ceased to relate to investment advice given by advisor to investors after advisor and investors moved to another brokerage firm, and thus did not provide basis under New York law for investors to recover from broker-dealer for advisor's alleged negligence under reverse veil-piercing theory.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Limitations. Discovery rule did not toll statute of limitations on investors' state securities fraud claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Paul v. Destito
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Businesses were liable for punitive damages verdict in action brought by shareholder against other shareholders of corporation and other businesses owned by them, in which shareholder alleged fraud, negligent misrepresentation, conspiracy to breach fiduciary duty, negligent breach of fiduciary duty, and other claims, under theory of alter ego liability, where jury concluded that all corporate and individual defendants were alter egos of each other and should be treated as same personality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Status as shareholder and former director did not bar claim of alter eqo liability against other shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Potash v. Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Slip and fall victim failed to prove that premises lessee's parent corporation so dominated the lessee's operation as to warrant piercing the corporate veil to hold the parent liable for the lessee's negligence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Premises lessee's parent corporation was not liable to slip and fall victim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Temporary staffing company and related company were "single business enterprise," such that both companies could be held liable for negligence of staffing company's employee, in view of companies' common management, shared trade name, and shared office and employees.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Sullivan v. Wallace
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Co-owner of wooded tract could not pierce the corporate veil and recover against corporate officer of timber company for trespass, conversion, or negligence in the removal of timber, absent any showing that officer committed fraud, personally trespassed, or physically removed timber, or that he failed to follow the statutory requirements for transacting corporate affairs, such as maintaining corporate bank accounts and filing corporate tax returns.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Timber. Whether timber company should have known that tree removal was without consent of one co-owner presented fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: McConkey v. McGhan Medical Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Former parent company had no duty to customers of former subsidiary that had separate legal identity, and therefore claim of negligence under Tennessee law against former parent company by customers of former subsidiary failed.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Breast implant recipient failed to make showing that former parent company controlled former subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Paredes v. Abercrombie & Kent Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, piercing-the-corporate-veil/alter-ego doctrine did not apply to passengers' negligence action against cruise line for injuries suffered during ground tour conducted by tour operator, where tour operator was a partnership, and cruise line was not a shareholder of tour operator.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Passengers failed to pierce the corporate veil so as to hold cruise line liable for tour operator's conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Manchester Equipment Co., Inc. v. American Way
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, subsidiary did not have apparent authority to act on parent's behalf, and thus parent could not be held liable to seller for any negligence of subsidiary in failing to implement appropriate security measures before allowing unknown persons to take computers from subsidiary's warehouse, even though buyer may have believed he was dealing with parent, absent evidence that seller believed he was dealing with parent when he contracted with subsidiary
Document Preview: Seller of computer equipment brought state court action against parent of storage company for negligently delivering goods to unknown persons. Following removal, parent moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Wexler, J., held that: (1) parent was not liable for subsidiary's negligent security, and (2) subsidiary did not have apparent authority to act on behalf of parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Parent corporation's relationship with subsidiary hospital perpetuated a separate and individual corporate existence which could not be disregarded for purposes of imposing liability on parent corporation for alleged negligent acts with respect to care and treatment provided to patient while undergoing surgery at hospital, absent showing that parent corporation entered into a relationship with hospital to perpetuate fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital's parent corporation was not liable for hospital's allegedly negligent medical care.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Corporate forms of hospital and its parent corporation could not be disregarded to impose liability on parent corporation for alleged negligent acts with respect to care and treatment provided to patient while undergoing surgery at hospital, though parent corporation had control over some of hospital's affairs and participated in many of hospital's activities, absent showing that parent corporation had control or right to control over medical care of patients at hospital.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital's parent corporation was not liable for hospital's allegedly negligent medical care.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Affiliation agreement entered into between hospital and its parent corporation and hospital documents bearing the parent corporation's emblem merely suggested that hospital was an affiliate in the parent corporation's health care delivery system, not that parent corporation consented or knowingly permitted hospital to perform patient's surgery so as to impose liability on parent corporation under apparent authority principles for alleged negligent acts with respect to care and treatment provided to patient while undergoing surgery at hospital.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital's parent corporation was not liable for hospital's allegedly negligent medical care.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: In re W.T. Mayfield Sons Trucking Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, attorney who is negligent or who engages in misconduct cannot hide behind corporate veil. O.C.G.A. § 14-2-622.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Attorney Fees. Debtor's attorney had to disgorge secret payments from debtor's subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Abdel-Fattah v. Pepsico, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Parent corporation's 100% ownership of stock of subsidiary corporation did not make it liable for alleged negligence of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer Torts. Parent's 100% ownership of subsidiary's stock corporation did not make it liable for subsidiary's alleged negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Leitch v. Hornsby
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Unless alter ego is established, corporate officers and agents are subject to personal liability for their actions within employment context only when they breach independent duty of care.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporations. Corporate officers were not individually liable in negligence action for work-related injury suffered by corporate employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Leitch v. Hornsby
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Corporate officers could not be held individually liable in negligence action for injuries sustained by employee of corporation, where jury found that corporation was not alter ego of officers, and record did not indicate that officers had breached any independent duty of care apart from employer's nondelegable duty to provide safe workplace.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporations. Corporate officers were not individually liable in negligence action for work-related injury suffered by corporate employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Humana, Inc. v. Kissun
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Corporate veil separating parent corporation owning number of hospitals from subsidiary operating one hospital would not be pierced, in malpractice suit brought against subsidiary, even though subsidiary used logo of parent on its letterhead, sign and advertising, parent hired attorneys to handle suits for or against subsidiary, and subsidiary's chief executive officer was hired and supervised by a regional vice president of parent; there was no showing of abuse of corporate form or that adherence to separate corporate identity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate veil of subsidiary could not be pierced in malpractice case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Humana, Inc. v. Kissun
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable for alleged malpractice on part of physicians who were employees of subsidiary corporation operating hospital, under theories of apparent agency or joint venture, even though hospital displayed logo of parent.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate veil of subsidiary could not be pierced in malpractice case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Aronson v. Price
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Although incorporated body shop's failure to file assumed business name certificate violated statute, it was not grounds to impose personal liability on corporation's shareholder for negligence and breach of contract of corporation; statute did not provide for piercing of corporate veil as sanction for violation. West's A.I.C. 23-15-1-1, 23-1-26-3(b).
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's breach of contract and negligence, even though it failed to file assumed business name certificate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Aronson v. Price
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Although incorporated body shop's failure to file assumed business name certificate was breach of required corporate formalities, it was not in of itself grounds to impose personal liability on corporation's shareholder for negligence and breach of contract of corporation; no other factors which courts consider in determining whether to pierce corporate veil were present, and corporation observed other formalities such as conducting directors and shareholders meetings, keeping records, and filing annual reports. West's A.I.C. 23-1-26-3(b).
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's breach of contract and negligence, even though it failed to file assumed business name certificate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Leitch v. Hornsby
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Only where individual's negligence is merely derivative of corporation's negligence is it necessary to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Assistance. Employer has nondelegable and continuous duty to employee to provide adequate help in performance of his work.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Leitch v. Hornsby
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Individual defendants were liable for negligence, and thus it was not necessary to pierce corporate veil, where injured employee testified that he requested safety and lifting equipment from both of individual defendants, and requests were denied, and jury found denial of such requests to be negligence.
Document Preview: Assistance. Employer has nondelegable and continuous duty to employee to provide adequate help in performance of his work.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ernst v. Parkshore Club Apartments Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, district court would not pierce corporate veil of corporation which comanaged apartment building to hold developer of building, which was sister corporation, liable for managing corporation's actions in hiring or supervising maintenance employee who attacked resident; there was no evidence that managing corporation was sham corporation set up for benefit of developer.
Document Preview: Apartment building resident, who was attacked by maintenance employee, brought negligence action against building owner, developer, two management companies, and individual involved in hiring employee.  Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Zagel, J., held that: (1) neither owner nor developer could be held vicariously liable for actions of management companies; (2) companies did not have duty to investigate maintenance employee's arrest record before hiring him; (3) even if companies had such duty, failure to investigate was not proximate cause of resident's injuries; (4) defendants were not negligent in providing security; and (5) defendants did not breach lease. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Porter v. LSB Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: No basis existed for imposing liability in products liability and negligence action on holder of trademark for lathe in its capacity as shareholder of subsidiary which distributed lathe by "piercing the corporate veil," where subsidiary was not undercapitalized, shareholder observed corporate formalities, and subsidiary was not misused either to perpetuate a fraud or to inflict injury, nor was subsidiary formed for the purpose of carrying out parent's business while insulating parent from liability.
Document Preview: Trademark. Holder of trademark on lathe could not be held liable either in negligence or in strict products liability for injury suffered by lathe operator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Munder v. Circle One Condominium, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: President and sole stockholder of condominium development corporation could not be held liable for corporation's breach of duty in failing to renew fire policy on clubhouse, even though the failure was an obvious wrong; no basis was alleged for piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Condominium association brought action against condominium developer, in both his corporate and individual capacity.  The Circuit Court for Broward County, John T. Luzzo, J., entered judgment in favor of association against developer in both his corporate and individual capacity, and developer appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Letts, J., held that: (1) corporation breached its fiduciary duty, and (2) developer could not be held liable in individual capacity. Affirmed in part; reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: National Bank of Commerce (of El Dorado) v. HCA Health Services of Midwest, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: There was no evidence to support piercing of corporate veil of hospital to hold hospital's parent liable for hospital's negligence.
Document Preview: In action for injuries sustained by newborn infant, the Circuit Court, Saline County, John W. Cole, J., rendered judgment for defendant nurses and for plaintiffs against hospital.  Hospital and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, 294 Ark. 525, 745 S.W.2d 120, reversed and remanded.  On second trial, the Circuit Court, Saline County, John W. Cole, J., rendered judgment in favor of defendants, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Supreme Court, W. Dent Gitchel, Special Justice, held that: (1) trial court's error in entering summary judgment in favor of hospital's parent corporation was harmless; (2) plaintiffs were not prejudiced by trial court's refusal to strike juror for cause; (3) statute governing procedure to be followed when jury desires further instruction during deliberation was violated, but there was no prejudice; (4) failure to question verdict before jury was discharged waived claim that verdict was result of jury...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Lener v. Club Med, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable for negligence or breach of contract in connection with injuries sustained by passenger when he slipped and fell on excursion boat owned by parent corporation's partially-owned subsidiary, even though parent corporation provided some personnel and administrative technical services to subsidiary; passenger failed to show that parent exercised such complete domination and control over subsidiary that parent could be held liable for torts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Passenger who was injured on an excursion boat sued the resort owner and its parent corporation for negligence and breach of contract.  The Supreme Court, Westchester County, Marbach, J., granted parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, and granted resort owner's motion to vacate the default judgment entered against it.  Passenger appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) parent corporation was not liable for the torts of resort owner, and (2) resort owner failed to establish existence of a meritorious defense. Affirmed in part, and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Montgomery Health Care Facility, Inc. v. Ballard
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Parent corporation of nursing home owner could be held liable for nursing home's negligence, resulting in patient's death, where parent controlled, or retained right to control day-to-day operations of home.
Document Preview: Estate of nursing home patient, who had died as result of multiple infected bedsores, brought negligence action against nursing home.  The Circuit Court, Montgomery County, No. CV87173TH, H. Randall Thomas, J., entered judgment on jury verdict against nursing home, and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Shores, J., held that reports compiled by state concerning deficiencies found in nursing home were admissible. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Meshel v. Resorts Intern. of New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation, which operated tour business which provided customers to hotel indirectly owned by parent corporation and which did not share employees, assets, or business of parent corporation, could not be held liable for alleged negligence of hotel's agents or employees in responding to an emergency with defective oxygen equipment and spent or inadequate oxygen cylinders.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against a tour operator seeking to hold it liable for alleged negligence of hotel employees in responding to an emergency with defective oxygen equipment and spent or inadequate oxygen cylinders.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Fingerhood, J., denied the defendant's cross motion for summary judgment, and defendant appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that subsidiary corporation, which operated tour business which provided customers to hotel indirectly owned by parent corporation and which did not share employees, assets, or business of parent corporation, could not be held liable for alleged negligence of hotel's agents or employees. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Keenan v. Hill
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In action brought by motorist for personal injuries sustained in hit-and-run collision with automobile owned by leasing company and driven by leasing company's vice-president, even assuming that vice-president's knowledge of his own poor driving record could be imputed to leasing company, leasing company nevertheless did not furnish automobile to vice-president negligently so as to be held liable to motorist; on day of accident automobile was leased to another corporation, notwithstanding that officers and shareholders of leasing company and lessee of automobile were the same.
Document Preview: Motorist brought suit for personal injuries sustained in collision with automobile owned by leasing company and driven by leasing company's vice-president.  The Superior Court, Newton County, Ridgway, J., entered judgment in favor of motorist, and appeal followed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, P.J., held that: (1) motorist's uninsured motorist insurer was not required to proceed in its own name simply because it elected initially to do so when named as defendant after having settled with motorist; (2) trial court was entitled to permit motorist to amend complaint on morning of trial to seek punitive damages; (3) leasing company was not liable for motorist's injuries, as evidence did not support finding that it negligently entrusted automobile to vice-president; and (4) trial court's instruction that driving without a license constituted negligence per se was not harmful error. Affirmed in part with direction and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Law Offices of Lawrence J. Stockler, P.C. v. Rose
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Clients alleging legal malpractice would not be entitled to pierce clients' corporate veil in order to hold attorney liable for benefit of bargain damages as result of attorney's malpractice, which resulted in entry of judgment against clients in their action against accounting firm for inaccurate financial reviews of another corporation, upon which client's corporation relied when purchasing other corporation.
Document Preview: Law firm brought action against clients to recover legal fees, clients filed counterclaim for legal malpractice, and law firm filed third-party complaint against law firm which represented client in one matter for which legal malpractice was asserted.  The Oakland Circuit Court, Norman L. Lippitt, J., entered judgments awarding law firm legal fees, granted third-party law firm judgment of no cause of action, and awarded clients judgment on counterclaim, and law firm appealed and clients cross-appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Shepherd, P.J., held that: (1) judge was not required to disqualify himself; (2) certain damages awarded against law firm in malpractice counterclaim were not recoverable; (3) clients were not entitled to exemplary damages; (4) law firm was not entitled to indemnification or contribution from third-party law firm; and (5) trial court properly gave effect to contingency fee arrangements underlying law firm's claim...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Helzer v. F. Joseph Lamb Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Public policy did not require that corporate veil of Canadian corporation be pierced in negligence action by Michigan resident injured in accident in Canada involving employee of that corporation, to reach United States parent of Canadian corporation.
Document Preview: Michigan resident who was injured when struck while crossing Canadian street filed automobile negligence action against driver, his employer, and employer's United States parent corporation.  The Wayne Circuit Court, Sharon Tevis Finch, J., granted summary disposition in favor of Canadian corporation and its employee and, in separate order, to United States parent.  On consolidated appeal, the Court of Appeals, Kelly, J., held that: (1) public policy did not require that corporate veil of Canadian corporation be pierced in order to reach its United States parent; (2) personal jurisdiction existed over Canadian corporation; and (3) no limited personal jurisdiction existed over either Canadian corporation or its employee. Affirmed in part and reversed in part. MacKenzie, P.J., dissented in part and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Eastridge Development Co. v. Halpert Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate parent of engineering firm acted as firm's alter ego and was therefore liable for firm's negligent performance of soil studies, where parent used its subsidiaries in manner calculated to insulate assets from professional liability, and after acquiring engineering firm, allowed professional liability insurance to lapse, assumed control of its operations and management and moved it in with another subsidiary.
Document Preview: Developer brought suit seeking damages for professional negligence in preparation of soil studies for shopping mall site.  The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, Clarence A. Brimmer, Chief Judge, rendered judgment against engineering firm and its parent, and those defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Wesley E. Brown, Senior District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) there was long-arm jurisdiction over nonresident parent; (2) verdict on causation was supported by evidence; (3) fee and rate schedule limiting engineering firm's liability for professional negligence was inadmissible; (4) parent was liable as alter ego for engineering firm's negligent performance of soil studies; (5) trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying motion to separate portion of trial relating to piercing the corporate veil from trial on liability; (6) whether action was timely commenced under Wyoming...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Eastridge Development Co. v. Halpert Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Punitive damages were not recoverable against corporate parent of engineering firm with respect to parent's liability as alter-ego of engineering firm, since liability of parent could not exceed that which arose from engineering firm's professional negligence.
Document Preview: Developer brought suit seeking damages for professional negligence in preparation of soil studies for shopping mall site.  The United States District Court for the District of Wyoming, Clarence A. Brimmer, Chief Judge, rendered judgment against engineering firm and its parent, and those defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Wesley E. Brown, Senior District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) there was long-arm jurisdiction over nonresident parent; (2) verdict on causation was supported by evidence; (3) fee and rate schedule limiting engineering firm's liability for professional negligence was inadmissible; (4) parent was liable as alter ego for engineering firm's negligent performance of soil studies; (5) trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying motion to separate portion of trial relating to piercing the corporate veil from trial on liability; (6) whether action was timely commenced under Wyoming...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Bates v. Merritt Seafood, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Fish wholesaling corporation was apparent owner of fishing boat, liable to injured third party for negligence of captain and crew, though corporation was not owner of record, where corporation held itself out as, and was believed by crew and public to be, owner of record; documented ship owner and wholesaling corporation shared officers and directors and had common shareholders.
Document Preview: Radar repairman and his wife brought action against owners of fishing boat on which repairman slipped and fell, to recover damages for injuries and loss of consortium.  The District Court, Hawkins, J., held that: (1) captain and crew of fishing boat were negligent; (2) company which held itself out as owner of boat was apparent owner, liable for crew's negligence; (3) both actual and apparent owner were liable to repairman and his wife for crew's negligence in leaving fish slime on deck; and (4) repairman was entitled to damages of $768,604.65, while wife was entitled to damages of $39,500. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Bergen v. F/V St. Patrick
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Owners of fishing vessel were personally liable for negligence and for unseaworthiness as shareholders of corporation which owned vessel on grounds that corporation was an artifice and a sham; record reflected intermingling of personal and corporate funds, lack of company bank account, absence of organizational minutes, failure to file corporate tax returns, and failure to pay dividends.
Document Preview: In case arising from the abandonment of a ship, the United States District Court for the District of Alaska, James A. von der Heydt, District Judge, found that owners of the fishing vessel liable for negligence and for unseaworthiness and awarded punitive damages as well as damages for predeath pain and suffering and for loss of support, services and inheritance to estates of deceased crew members.  The owners appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Farris, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) punitive damages available under general maritime law could not supplement Death on the High Seas Act or the Jones Act remedies; (2) factual findings were insufficient to support punitive damages award to survivors; (3) awards for loss of support, services and inheritance were only partially supported; and (4) individual owners were personally liable as shareholders of sham corporation. Affirmed in part, reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Spearing v. Bayfield County
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil" did not prohibit state court from stacking negligence of subsidiary with negligence of parent corporation where tort liability resulting from accident involved neither fraud nor claim in equity.
Document Preview: Truck driver and his wife and unincorporated division of manufacturer of truck-crane brought action regarding damages sustained in single vehicle truck-crane accident on state highway.  The Circuit Court, Bayfield County, Thomas J. Gallagher, J., dismissed claims on basis that they were collaterally estopped by virtue of verdict and judgment in federal court and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, LaRocque, J., held that: (1) injured driver and wife were foreclosed from bringing litigation in state court where issue had been resolved in federal court; (2) negligence of subsidiary and parent company were appropriately stacked; and (3) manufacturer's failure to answer in litigation could not be attributed to manufacturer's insurer. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Kincaid v. Landing Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Corporation which was sales and marketing agent for development was not distinguishable from developer or contractor for purposes of homeowners' action against developer, sales and marketing agent and contractor alleging negligence and breach of warranty, where all three corporations had same shareholders, same vice president and same additional officer, all three corporate offices were located at same place, homeowner testified that she called marketing agent concerning problems with house and someone then came to house to correct problem and letters sent to homeowners indicated marketing agent was project developer and would handle all construction questions and that marketing agent was development, construction, sales, and property management company.
Document Preview: Homeowners brought action against developer, sales and marketing agent and contractor, alleging negligence and breach of warranty.  The Common Pleas Court, Horry County, Ralph King Anderson, Jr., J., entered judgment upon jury verdict awarding homeowners $19,800 actual damages and $13,500 punitive damages, and developer, sales and marketing agent and contractor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Shaw, J., held that: (1) erroneous instruction that violation of alleged building code was negligence per se was not reversible error; (2) allowing jury to view house prior to testimony by structural engineer was not abuse of trial court's discretion; and (3) allowing homeowners to amend claim during trial to increase damages request was not abuse of discretion. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Boafo v. Hospital Corp. of America
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Even though two corporations shared some officers and had jointly purchased hospital property from bankruptcy receivership, subsidiary was not a shell for parent corporation in operating hospital, but did fully and, for the most part, autonomously operate and manage hospital, and thus, patient, who allegedly suffered severe and unremedied injury while being administered anesthesia at hospital, was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of parent corporation, where subsidiary was fully capitalized entity which was insured and which owned hospital property, subsidiary managed and operated hospital on a day-to-day basis, and subsidiary maintained its own payroll and employed its own employees.
Document Preview: Patient who allegedly suffered severe and unremedied injury while being administered anesthesia at hospital operated by subsidiary brought action against parent corporation.  The Superior Court, Fulton County, Etheridge, J., granted parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, and patient appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, P.J., held that subsidiary was not a shell for parent corporation in operating hospital, but did fully and, for the most part, autonomously operate and manage hospital, and thus, patient was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of parent corporation, even though two corporations shared some officers and had jointly purchased hospital property from bankruptcy receivership. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Boafo v. Hospital Corp. of America
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Assuming the means of sustaining independent identity of subsidiary corporation from parent were absent, no basis existed for disregarding parent's separate identity and holding it liable to patient, who allegedly suffered severe and unremedied injury while being administered anesthesia at hospital operated by subsidiary, unless parent's ulterior motive or purpose was to promote fraud and injustice or defeat a public convenience, and thus, corporate veil of parent would not be pierced, since no such evidence was presented.
Document Preview: Patient who allegedly suffered severe and unremedied injury while being administered anesthesia at hospital operated by subsidiary brought action against parent corporation.  The Superior Court, Fulton County, Etheridge, J., granted parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, and patient appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, P.J., held that subsidiary was not a shell for parent corporation in operating hospital, but did fully and, for the most part, autonomously operate and manage hospital, and thus, patient was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of parent corporation, even though two corporations shared some officers and had jointly purchased hospital property from bankruptcy receivership. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Agristor Leasing v. Guggisberg
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Minnesota law did not allow piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation of manufacturer of animal feed storage system liable on farmers' claims against the manufacturer on claims of strict liability, negligence, breach of warranty, and misrepresentation, absent showing that the manufacturer had been operated in unjust manner or that it was alter ego of the parent corporation.
Document Preview: Farmers against whom action was brought for breach of lease and wrongful detention of property filed third-party complaint against manufacturer, marketer, and seller of animal feed storage system, alleging strict liability, negligence, breach of warranty, and misrepresentation.  Third-party defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Diana E. Murphy, J., held that: (1) Minnesota statute of limitations for actions for damages for injury arising out of defective and unsafe condition of improvement to real property did not apply; (2) Minnesota law did not allow piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation of manufacturer liable; (3) genuine issues of material fact existed to preclude summary judgment on farmers' fraud claim, seller's indemnification claim, and farmers' punitive damages claim; (4) alleged damage to farmers' feed and cows were nonrecoverable economic losses; and (5) disclaimers of warranty and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ely v. Kirk
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Mortgages obtained by individual on several occasions for corporate operator of sewage system for township, plus fact that individual represented to customers, to county officials, and to others that he was owner and operator of system, were sufficient to warrant piercing of corporate veil so as to make individual liable for negligence in allowing sewage system to back into basement of a private home on a number of occasions.
Document Preview: Owner of private home sought to recover against operators of sewage system for alleged negligence in allowing sewage to back up into basement of home on a number of occasions.  The District Court, Campbell County, Paul T. Liamos, Jr., J., entered judgment for owner, and operators appealed.  The Supreme Court, Rooney, J., held that: (1) failure of operators to take action to make system effective from standpoint of accomplishing its purpose, delivering sewage to disposal plant rather than to basement of private home, was a violation of duty or standard of care imposed upon operator and, as such, was negligence which, when established as proximate cause of damages sustained, rendered operators liable to owner for those damages; (2) mortgages obtained by individual on behalf of corporate operator, plus fact that individual represented customers, to county officials, and to others that he was owner and operator of system, were a sufficient basis for piercing...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Dania Jai-Alai Palace, Inc. v. Sykes
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: First corporation could be held liable for injuries sustained by plaintiff when crushed between her automobile and another by reason of negligence of parking attendant employed by second corporation where both corporations presented a public image of a single enterprise.
Document Preview: Action was instituted to recover against three corporations for injuries sustained by plaintiff when crushed between two automobiles in parking lot.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, James F. Minnet, J., entered judgment on verdict for plaintiff, and defendants appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Hurley, J., held that: (1) parking attendant employed by second corporation was negligent when, though trying to apply brakes on plaintiff's vehicle, he hit accelerator and caused plaintiff, then in front of vehicle, to be propelled forward and crushed between cars; (2) whether plaintiff was contributorily negligent, however, was a question which should have been submitted to jury instead of being determined on motion for directed verdict; (3) first corporation could be held liable for negligence of parking attendant employed by second corporation where both corporations held themselves out as a single enterprise; and (4) whether third...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Luckett v. Bethlehem Steel Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Although parent corporation indirectly owned 70% of stock of foreign subsidiary and furnished ten of the managing officers of the latter, many of whom held managerial posts in parent, and had contracted to furnish subsidiary with technical services and manufacturing equipment as well as locating the business for it and although parent's employee, who while with subsidiary, negotiated contract with plaintiff's employer, it could not be said that subsidiary was a mere alter ego instrumentality of the parent so as to hold parent liable for any negligence of subsidiary employee, especially absent any showing of fraud or inequitable conduct resulting from use of separate corporate structures.
Document Preview: Action was brought against United States corporation and its subsidiary, a Singapore corporation, to recover for injuries which plaintiff sustained when crane cable snapped on board a drilling rig on which he was employed in Singapore. The United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Ralph G. Thompson, J., granted summary judgment as to parent and granted subsidiary's motion to dismiss, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Holloway, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) although parent furnished management team for subsidiary it could not be said that subsidiary was a mere alter ego of the parent so as to hold parent liable for any negligence of subsidiary employee, especially absent showing of fraud or inequitable conduct in use of separate corporate structures; (2) material fact issue existed as to liability of parent based on doctrines of respondeat superior and loaned servant; and (3) in personam jurisdiction could not be asserted over subsidiary...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ruppa v. American States Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Corporate status of nonprofit saddle club would not be ignored because of alleged informal manner in which its officers conducted business, and vicarious liability therefore could not be imposed on all members for alleged negligence of one member in manner in which he controlled and supervised horse show sponsored by club.
Document Preview: In a wrongful death action, the Circuit Court, Dane County, William C. Sachtjen, J., sustained defendants' motion for summary judgment, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Beilfuss, C. J., held, inter alia, that death of a participant in a cutting event of a horse show was covered by an exclusion in a liability insurance policy obtained by the saddle club which conducted the show. Judgment affirmed as to insurer and reversed as to other defendants and remanded for further proceedings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Crown Central Petroleum Corp. v. Cosmopolitan Shipping Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Even though company which acted as managing agent for vessel and corporation which owned vessel were owned by the same persons and had the same officers and directors at all relevant times, where the vessel owner and the managing agent were separate and distinct corporate entities and where the vessel owner retained chartering authority and the right to designate the route of the vessel and retained control over all dry-docking and capital improvement decisions, the managing agent, which arranged for the manning of the ship and had the authority to hire and fire, was not the owner pro hac vice of the vessel so as to be liable for damages caused by negligent navigation.
Document Preview: Managing agent of cargo vessel appealed from a judgment of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Cannella, J., which awarded the owner and consignee of the cargo damages for partial loss of cargo and recovery for any contributions in general average and salvage that it might be compelled to pay as a result of the stranding of the vessel. The Court of Appeals, Waterman, Circuit Judge, held that the facts did not support the district court's conclusion that the managing agent had such control over the day-to-day operations of the vessel as to render it liable for damages arising from negligent navigation. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Jones v. Adamson's, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Fact that father was sole shareholder and president of corporation furnished no grounds for holding him personally liable for injuries sustained in collision between corporation's truck, which was being operated by employee son, and plaintiffs' vehicle, nor did facts that he employed his nephew and son and rented property to corporation or that one of the corporation's phones was listed in his name.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and its sole shareholder to recover for death of plaintiffs' father/husband in collision between latter's vehicle and corporation's truck. The Clayton Superior Court, Ison, J., rendered summary judgment for shareholder, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Smith, J., held that: (1) motion to dismiss appeal because of unreasonable and inexcusable delay in transmitting record to reviewing court was to be made in trial court; (2) although truck was being operated by shareholder's son, family purpose doctrine was inapplicable, and (3) fact that father was president and sole shareholder furnished no grounds for piercing corporate veil. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Williams v. American Title Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Since plaintiffs, corporation and its shareholders, were ones that set up and took advantage of corporate status for many years, they were not allowed to raise question of piercing corporate veil in negligence action so as to increase damages.
Document Preview: Landowners and corporate tenant brought action against abstract company for negligent misrepresentation arising from existence of deed not mentioned in abstract, seeking damages to compensate them for restaurant on land which was torn down. Landowners were sole shareholders of corporate tenant. The Macomb Circuit Court, Howard R. Carroll, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs, and appeals were taken. The Court of Appeals, Kaufman, J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in not awarding damages for loss of equipment, fixtures, and improvements to restaurant; (2) trial court's ruling that corporate plaintiff was only month-to-month tenant of individual plaintiffs was not error; (3) there was no error in failure of plaintiffs' complaint to allege any fact as to status of corporation; (4) plaintiffs were not precluded from recovery by warning given to them by their attorney to check about future condemnation proceedings before purchasing property, and (5) court properly determined...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Pushnik v. Winky's Drive-In Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Although wholly owned subsidiary was separate legal entity from its owner, where owner leased land for subsidiary and then subleased land to subsidiary, where owner hired and paid architect and contractors responsible for building subsidiary, which was fast food restaurant, where subsequent to time of accident wherein automobile crashed through glass enclosure into restaurant pinning patron to steel counters, decision was made to alter structure of subsidiary to provide seating space for customers in restaurant, which decision was made and alterations paid for by owner, where owner employed supervisors who made periodic inspections of fast food restaurant, where supervisors were responsible for hiring, training, and firing management of restaurant, it could be found that owner was in control of premises on date of accident and thus owner could be held liable in patron's negligence suit against it, subsidiary, and others.(Per Price, J., with one Judge concurring and with three Judges joining in concurring opinion and two Judges concurring in result.)
Document Preview: Fast food restaurant patron brought negligence action against restaurant owner, restaurant, i.e., wholly owned subsidiary of owner, lessor, et al., for injuries arising out of accident wherein automobile crashed through front glass of restaurant pinning patron to steel counters. The Court of Common Pleas of Westmoreland County, Civil Division, at No. 916 July Term, 1970, held owner and restaurant liable, and owner, et al., appealed. The Superior Court, Nos. 285, 299, April Term, 1975 Price, J., held that where similar accidents had occurred on two prior occasions, failure of restaurant owner and restaurant to construct precautionary structure was negligent conduct causing patron's injuries, and negligence of automobile driver could not be claimed as superseding cause; that owner of subsidiary had sufficient control of restaurant to be held liable; and that lessor, who had no control over construction or design of building and who had never seen plans for building, could not be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Bujosa v. Metropolitan Transp. Authority
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In absence of special circumstances, separate corporate status of railroad, stock of which had been taken over by metropolitan transportation authority, could not be disregarded so as to hold authority liable for alleged negligence of railroad. Public Authorities Law § 1260 et seq.
Document Preview: In an action to recover damages for wrongful death and conscious pain and suffering, an order of the Supreme Court, Nassau County, granted plaintiff's motion for leave to file a statement of readiness and denied defendant's cross motion for summary judgment, without prejudice. The defendant appealed. The defendant metropolitan transportation authority appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that in absence of special circumstances, the separate corporate status of a railroad, stock of which had been taken by the metropolitan transportation authority, could not be disregarded so as to hold the authority liable for alleged negligence of the railroad. Order reversed on the law; authority's cross motion granted, and plaintiff's motion dismissed as academic.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co. v. Arkla Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Where workman sustained injuries when he inhaled and came in contact with hydrochloric acid while unloading the acid from tank truck which was owned by chemical company but leased by gas company, the chemical company which was wholly-owned subsidiary of gas company was, under Arkansas law, legally responsible for negligent acts of employees of the gas company in connection with handling of the acid.
Document Preview: Action was brought by insurer, injured workman, and his wife against chemical company for injuries sustained when the workman inhaled hydrochloric acid while unloading the acid from tank truck owned by chemical company but under control of gas company by virtue of lease. The United States District Court for the Western District of Arkansas, Oren Harris, Chief Judge, entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of the workman but against recovery for his wife. The chemical company appealed from the judgment and the wife appealed from denial of motion for new trial. The Court of Appeals held that under Arkansas law, the chemical company which was wholly-owned subsidiary of gas company was legally responsible for negligent acts of employees of the gas company in connection with handling of the acid. Affirmed in both appeals. See also 8 Cir., 431 F.2d 959.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: American Trading & Production Corp. v. Fischbach & Moore, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Where corporate parent of subsidiary, which installed allegedly defective wiring which caused fire resulting in damage to plaintiffs, exercised supervision over general performance of subsidiary but separate corporate identities were scrupulously maintained and subsidiary was not operated as an undercapitalized "dummy" and no fraud, injustice or unfairness was disclosed which would justify ignoring separate identities of the corporations, parent was not liable for allegedly negligent acts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages from fire allegedly caused by faulty electrical wiring installed by subsidiary. The District Court, Decker, J., held that where corporate parent of subsidiary which installed allegedly defective wiring which caused fire resulting in damage to plaintiffs exercised supervision over general performance of subsidiary but separate corporate identities were scrupulously maintained and subsidiary was not operated as an undercapitalized dummy and no fraud, injustice or unfairness was disclosed which would justify ignoring separate identities of the corporations, parent was not liable for allegedly negligent acts of subsidiary. Parent's motion for summary judgment granted. See also D.C., 47 F.R.D. 155.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Noto v. Cia Secula di Armanento
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining liability for deaths and injuries caused by explosion of Italian tanker in Iranian port because of alleged negligence of Dutch corporation which owned terminal and loading facilities, under facts, Iranian, Dutch or Italian law would govern on issue of whether corporate veil might be pierced and Iranian Oil Consortium members held individually liable and, under any such law, claims for alleged tort liability could only be asserted against those corporate entities responsible, and their shareholders, direct or indirect, were exempt from personal liability for those claims.
Document Preview: Five actions brought on behalf of next of kin of 28 deceased crew members and by 7 injured survivors of a tanker which exploded in an Iranian port. The District Court, Edward Weinfeld, J., held, inter alia, that in determining liability for deaths and injuries caused by explosion of Italian tanker in Iranian port because of alleged negligence of Dutch corporation which owned terminal and loading facilities, under facts, Iranian, Dutch or Italian law would govern on issue of whether corporate veil might be pierced and Iranian Oil Consortium members held individually liable and, under any such law, claims for alleged tort liability could only be asserted against these corporate entities responsible, and their shareholders, direct or indirect, were exempt from personal liability for those claims, and that under the facts defendants were entitled to dismissal on ground of forum non conveniens. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Noto v. Cia Secula di Armanento
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate members of Iranian Oil Consortium were not liable for deaths and injuries resulting from explosion of Italian oil tanker in Iranian port because of alleged negligence of Dutch corporation which owned and operated terminal where explosion occurred on theory that corporate identity should be disregarded because corporation was the "alter ego" and agent of its parent corporations, where the Dutch corporation was a solvent and substantial corporation and functioned as a separate corporate unit as it was set up to function under the agreement.
Document Preview: Five actions brought on behalf of next of kin of 28 deceased crew members and by 7 injured survivors of a tanker which exploded in an Iranian port. The District Court, Edward Weinfeld, J., held, inter alia, that in determining liability for deaths and injuries caused by explosion of Italian tanker in Iranian port because of alleged negligence of Dutch corporation which owned terminal and loading facilities, under facts, Iranian, Dutch or Italian law would govern on issue of whether corporate veil might be pierced and Iranian Oil Consortium members held individually liable and, under any such law, claims for alleged tort liability could only be asserted against these corporate entities responsible, and their shareholders, direct or indirect, were exempt from personal liability for those claims, and that under the facts defendants were entitled to dismissal on ground of forum non conveniens. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Creeco Co. v. Northern Illinois Gas Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Allegedly negligent conduct of employee of one corporation was not chargeable to another corporation where corporations were separate entities and had different interests and were not in privity, even though they had same officers and were insured by same insurance company.
Document Preview: Action for property damages resulting from explosion and fire in building by owner and occupant of building against gas company and contractor. The Circuit Court, McHenry County, James H. Cooney, J., rendered judgment dismissing complaint on ground of estoppel by verdict. The Appellate Court, Thomas J. Moran, P.J., held that prior negligence action against four named parties in which owner had been voluntarily dismissed, contractor was found not negligent, and gas company and occupant were found negligent barred action by occupant against contractor based on wilful and wanton misconduct, but that occupant's charge of wilful and wanton misconduct against gas company was not determined in prior action so as to be barred, and that owner's claim against contractor and gas company was not barred since owner had been dismissed before verdict in prior action and owner and occupant were not in privity. Reversed and remanded in part, affirmed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Miller v. Bethlehem Steel Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Where corporation owned all of capital stock of a company and many of same persons were officers and directors in both company and corporation but corporation operated no physical property and corporation and company did not share same office space and directors meetings were held at different times and places and hiring of key personnel of company was not controlled or subject to approval of corporation, etc., company was not agent of corporation and corporation was not liable for alleged negligence of company.
Document Preview: Negligence action. The District Court, Harry E. Watkins, J., held that where corporation owned all of capital stock of a company and many of same persons were officers and directors in both company and corporation which operated no physical property, but corporation and company did not share same office space and directors meetings were held at different times and places and hiring of key personnel of company was not controlled or subject to approval of corporation, etc., company was not agent of corporation and corporation was not liable for alleged negligence of company. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Gardner v. 1111 Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Where owner of building and managing agent were each a corporation, they were separate legal entities and fact that both occupied same office space and had interlocking offices did not destroy relationship of owner and managing agent or establish liability on part of managing agent for nonfeasance in maintenance of building.
Document Preview: Action for alleged wrongful death arising out of elevator accident. From a judgment of the Supreme Court at Trial Term, James B. M. McNally, Nally, J., and jury, in favor of plaintiff, the defendant managing agent of the apartment house wherein the accident had occurred appealed. The Appellate Division, Rabin, J., held that under a contract between the owner of the apartment house and the managing agent whereby the agent was empowered to make necessary repairs and alterations with the limitation that any alteration of a capital nature in excess of $2,500 would require the owner's approval, and whereby the agent was empowered to supervise, hire and discharge employees but with the understanding that all such employees were in the employ of the owner and not of the managing agent, the agent did not have complete and exclusive control and was not liable for mere nonfeasance. Judgment in favor of plaintiff reversed and complaint dismissed.
