Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ernest v. Moore
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Liability under the respondeat superior doctrine for negligence of employee of incorporated produce market could not be imposed on owner thereof personally.
Document Preview: Action for personal injuries sustained when plaintiff scratched or cut his leg on a nail sticking out of a lettuce crate on the sidewalk in front of defendant's produce market. From a judgment of the Circuit Court, Jefferson County, Common Pleas Branch, 4th Division, J. Ward Lehigh, J., for plaintiff, defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Cullen, C., held that the evidence was sufficient to support a finding that defendant individually, not an employee of the market, which was incorporated, committed the alleged negligent act of putting the crate on the sidewalk with the nail sticking out. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Garden City Co. v. Burden
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: In action by a farmer against an irrigation company and its corporate parent, where irrigation company had no assets, owned no property other than easement in irrigation ditch and parent company owned, controlled and directed all operations of irrigation company, it would be inequitable to permit parent to escape liability because of negligent operation of ditch by irrigation company under pretext of separate identity of two corporations.
Document Preview: Action by J. L. Burden agasinst the Garden City Company, a corporation, and another for damages to plaintiff's land caused by the negligence of defendants in the operatinon of an irrigation canal crossing plaintiff's land. The United States District Court for the District of Kansas, Delmas C. Hill, J., entered judgment for plaintiff after jury verdict and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Huxman, Circuit Judge, held that the evidence was sufficient to sustain finding that defendants were negligent in the maintenance and operation of the irrigation ditch and that such negligence was the proximate cause of damage to plaintiff's land. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Cribbs v. Southern Coatings & Chemical Co.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: Where corporation by which plaintiff was employed at time he allegedly sustained injuries due to negligence of another employee, hired its own help, paid its own employees, kept its own books, and made separate income tax returns both to state and federal governments, defendant corporation was not alter ego or agent of another corporation which was under Compensation Act notwithstanding fact that stockholders of two corporations were largely same and as defendant was not under terms of Compensation Act, plaintiff could maintain common law action for injuries. Code 1942, §§ 7035-1 to 7035-78.
Document Preview: Action by W. D. Cribbs against the Southern Coatings and Chemical Company, and others for injuries sustained due to alleged negligent operation of truck owned by named defendant and being used in its business in which plaintiff was employed. The Common Pleas Court, Berkeley County, William H. Grimball, J., entered an order sustaining report of Special Referee that defendant was not the alter ego or agent of another corporation and therefore did not come under Workmen's Compensation Act and the defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Baker, C. J., held that record established that the defendant, which was not under compensation Act, was not the alter ego or agent of another corporation under act and plaintiff could maintain common law action for injuries. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: B. F. Hirsch, Inc. v. C. T. Gustafson Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Where jewelry was delivered by manufacturer's representative to a jobber doing business under a corporate veil to be sold, and a memorandum indicated that title should remain in representative and that jewelry should be returned to it on demand, and jewelry was lost through negligence of the jobber, both the jobber and the corporate entity under which he operated were liable for the loss of the jewelry.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Cook County; Michael Feinberg, Judge. Action to recover value of jewelry by B. F. Hirsch, Inc., against C. T. Gustafson Company, Inc., and J. J. Broucek. From a judgment in favor of J. J. Broucek, the plaintiff appeals. Reversed and judgment entered against J. J. Broucek.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Coryell v. Pilkington
Court: District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: A stockholder in corporation which owned vessel which caught fire following explosion was not individually liable for damages caused other vessels by fire, where there was no fraud or other improper conduct of purpose in creation or continued existence of corporation and character of negligence involved was failure to perform a duty, or nonfeasance.
Document Preview: Libel by Charles Coryell and others against George J. Pilkington and another for damages sustained by fire. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Barnes v. Liebig
Court: Supreme Court of Florida, Division A.
Headnote: The "alter ego" theory, that subordinate or servient corporation may be controlled by superior or dominant corporation, so that dominant corporation may be held liable for subordinate corporation's negligence, is in force in Florida and applicable at law as well as in equity.
Document Preview: Error to Circuit Court, Dade County; W. W. Trammell, Judge. Actions by Andrew J. Barnes, Jr., a minor, by Andrew J. Barnes, his next friend; by Andrew J. Barnes; and by Pearl Barnes, joined by her husband, Andrew J. Barnes, against Henry L. Liebig and others, for injuries suffered in automobile accident. To review judgment for defendants on demurrers sustained, plaintiffs bring error, and cases were consolidated for review. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: C. L. & L. Motor Express Co. v. Achenbach
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Where officers of storage company owned practically all of stock of express company, but there was one officer and stockholder of express company who had no interest in storage company, corporate entity could not under evidence be disregarded so as to render storage company liable for negligence of express company's truck driver.
Document Preview: Appeal from Circuit Court, Jefferson County, Common Pleas Branch, Second Division. Suits by Henry Achenbach and by Elizabeth Achenbach against the C. L. & L. Motor Express Company, Incorporated, and another. Judgments for plaintiffs, and defendants appeal. Judgments reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Perry v. Ohio Valley Electric Ry. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: It is not to be inferred that two corporations are in legal effect one and the same, so as to make one liable for the negligence of the other, simply because they have the same men as officers, employ the same laborers, and apportion between themselves the charges therefor.
Document Preview: Error to Circuit Court, Cabell County. Action by John W. Perry against the Ohio Valley Electric Railway Company. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendant brings errror. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Boston Scientific Corp. v. Cook Group Incorporated
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil of parent company of patent holders' competitor was not justified, as would support holding parent directly liable for competitor's infringement of patent directed to reversibly closeable endoscopic hemostatic clips for treating gastrointestinal bleeding; parent did not make, use, sell, offer to sell, or import competitor's products, and there was no indication competitor was an "alter ego" of parent or that treating competitor as a separate corporate entity would promote fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Medical Devices and Procedures. Products literally infringed patent claim disclosing a medical device comprising a separate link to release a control wire from a clip.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Lubby Holdings LLC v. Chung
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: A corporate officer, or perhaps only a corporate owner, cannot be found derivatively liable for the corporation's infringement of a patent without piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Damages. Patentee was not entitled to recover damages for sales of infringing products prior to commencement of its infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Rotor Blade, LLC v. Signature Utility Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: The corporate veil shields a corporate officer from personal liability for direct patent infringement committed on the corporation's behalf, unless the corporation is the officer's alter ego. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: PATENTS  Industrial Equipment. Patentee did not allege underlying act of direct infringement required to state claim for indirect infringement of patent for tree-trimming method.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Rotor Blade, LLC v. Signature Utility Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: A court determines whether an officer is personally liable for a corporation's direct patent infringement by invoking those general principles relating to piercing the corporate veil. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: PATENTS  Industrial Equipment. Patentee did not allege underlying act of direct infringement required to state claim for indirect infringement of patent for tree-trimming method.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Pado, Inc. v. SG Trademark Holding Co. LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, the corporate veil shields a company's officers from personal liability for direct patent infringement that the officers commit in the name of the corporation, unless the corporation is the officers' alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Patent owner failed to adequately plead facts justifying piercing corporate veil under New York law to hold competitor's owner directly liable for patent infringement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Pado, Inc. v. SG Trademark Holding Co. LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Determining whether corporate officers are personally liable for direct patent infringement requires invocation of those general principles relating to piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Patent owner failed to adequately plead facts justifying piercing corporate veil under New York law to hold competitor's owner directly liable for patent infringement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Sadieboo, Inc. v. MJ Tools Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, garden supply retailer which owned "THE GROW STORE" trademark alleged sufficient facts from which to infer the personal involvement of corporate competitors' sole shareholder and operator in alleged trademark infringement and other torts, arising from competitors' use of name "The Indoor Grow Store," as required to pierce veil of corporate entity defendants to reach owner; complaint alleged that owner incorporated competitors in Michigan and filed certificates of assumed name with name "THE INDOOR GROW STORE," that owner signed federal trademark application and declared that competitor had used "THE INDOOR GROW STORE" as trademark for several years, and that owner personally responded to cease-and-desist letters.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Name or Likeness. Owner of THE GROW STORE trademark sufficiently alleged facts from which to reasonably infer likelihood of customer confusion to state claim for trademark infringement against The Indoor Grow Store.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Town & Country Linen Corp. v. Ingenious Designs LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Personal liability for corporate officers under statute governing patent infringement requires evidence to justify piercing the corporate veil. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS  Dismissal. Control panel for portable clothes drying product was not copyrightable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: California Expanded Metal Products Company v. Klein
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: To determine whether corporate officers are personally liable for a corporation's direct infringement under the Patent Act requires invocation of the general principles relating to piercing the corporate veil. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Washington law, competitor could not be held personally liable for his corporation's alleged direct infringement of patents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: California Expanded Metal Products Company v. Klein
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: The corporate veil shields a company's officers from personal liability for direct infringement that the officers commit in the name of the corporation, unless the corporation is the officers' alter ego, or unusual circumstances justify disregarding the corporate structure.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Washington law, competitor could not be held personally liable for his corporation's alleged direct infringement of patents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: California Expanded Metal Products Company v. Klein
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: The corporate veil shields a company's officers from personal liability for direct infringement of a patent that the officers commit in the name of the corporation, unless the corporation is the officers' alter ego or unusual circumstances justify disregarding the corporate structure.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Consumer Goods. Individual could not be held personally liable for his corporation's alleged direct infringement of patent covering wall-of-head assemblies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: California Expanded Metal Products Company v. Klein
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: To determine whether corporate officers are personally liable for a corporation's direct infringement under the Patent Act requires invocation of the general principles relating to piercing the corporate veil. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: PATENTS  Consumer Goods. Individual could not be held personally liable for his corporation's alleged direct infringement of patent covering wall-of-head assemblies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: California Expanded Metal Products Company v. Klein
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Under Washington law, individual could not be held personally liable for his corporation's alleged direct infringement of patents covering head-of-wall assemblies used in commercial construction to prevent the spread of smoke and fire; although he was corporation's sole owner and officer, individual did not commingle personal and corporate funds, did not use corporation as shell for another corporation, and did not under capitalize the corporation.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Consumer Goods. Individual could not be held personally liable for his corporation's alleged direct infringement of patent covering wall-of-head assemblies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: British Telecommunications PLC v. IAC/InteractiveCorp
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Patent infringement plaintiff plausibly pleaded agency relationship between parent company and subsidiary software companies, as required to state claim against parent company under agency theory of vicarious liability; as alleged, parent company represented to public that subsidiaries' software products fell under its proprietary brands, provided technology and network systems that allowed such software to operate in violation of patents, directly hired and fired officers of its subsidiaries, shared officers and directors and shuffled officers throughout its subsidiaries, and relied on system in which persons responsible for overseeing subsidiaries reported directly to parent company's chief executive officer, rather than reporting to their own companies' boards of directors.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Computers and Electronics. Parent company could be liable for patent infringement by subsidiaries under agency theory of vicarious liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: British Telecommunications PLC v. IAC/InteractiveCorp
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Patent infringement plaintiff plausibly pleaded agency relationship between holding company and sub-subsidiary software companies, as required to state claim against holding company under agency theory of vicarious liability; as alleged, holding company used language "we" in annual reports when referring to software products, and promulgated software products which infringed patents.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Computers and Electronics. Parent company could be liable for patent infringement by subsidiaries under agency theory of vicarious liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Daimler AG v. A-Z Wheels LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Luxury automobile manufacturer's allegation that "the facts" support its argument was insufficient to maintain claim that wheel sellers' owner had such a unity of interest and ownership in sellers that, under California law and the alter ego doctrine, piercing the corporate veil would be appropriate in trademark and patent infringement action. Cal. Civ. Code § 3528.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Name or Likeness. Internet automobile wheel and rim sellers infringed on trademarks and patents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Luxottica Group, S.p.A. v. Airport Mini Mall, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was not required to conclude that individual owners and managers of discount shopping mall were liable under Lanham Act for contributory trademark infringement, based on sales of counterfeit luxury merchandise by mall tenants; individual liability standard applicable to owners and managers individually did not ask whether they participated in some infringing act, but instead whether they participated in decision to engage in infringing acts, or otherwise caused infringement as a whole to occur. Lanham Trade-Mark Act, § 1 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 1051 et seq.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Counterfeit Goods. Whether owners of shopping mall knew tenants were selling counterfeit merchandise was question for jury in contributory trademark infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Luxottica Group, S.p.A. v. Airport Mini Mall, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Corporate officers can be held personally liable for contributory trademark infringement under Lanham Act without piercing the corporate veil. Lanham Trade-Mark Act, § 1 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 1051 et seq.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Counterfeit Goods. Whether owners of shopping mall knew tenants were selling counterfeit merchandise was question for jury in contributory trademark infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Cohen v. Schroeder
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Small, privately-held insolvent corporation did not operate as a single economic entity with one of its owners, a trained lawyer acting as corporation's president, in pursuing corporation's interest in intellectual property litigation, as required to support veil piercing claim under Delaware law to hold owner personally liable for judgment against corporation, although owner failed to follow numerous basic corporate formalities; owner was not carrying on corporation's business for purely personal ends, owner entered an arm's length agreement with two of corporation's other co-founders to share any proceeds from litigation pro rata, there was no evidence corporation was set up for financial failure, and owner had never siphoned any assets belonging to corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on majority owner in small, privately-held Delaware corporation was unwarranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Cohen v. Schroeder
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Any abuse of corporate form of small, privately-held Delaware corporation by one owner in pursuing litigation relating to corporation's interest in intellectual property did not cause injustice or unfairness to wealthy corporate insider, who had served as corporation's director, chief executive officer, and chairman of board, sufficient to warrant veil piercing under Delaware's alter-ego test to hold owner personally liable for judgment obtained against corporation and in favor of insider; favorable verdict in related litigation would have inured to benefit of shareholders, there was nothing unjust in owner's decision to allege that he owned intellectual property and alternatively that intellectual property belonged to corporate entity, and corporation was not deliberately kept undercapitalized.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on majority owner in small, privately-held Delaware corporation was unwarranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Perfect 10, Inc. v. Giganews, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Online bulletin board service providers did not demonstrate that an injustice would result, as would be required for alter ego liability under California law, if sole shareholder of corporate owner of copyrighted adult entertainment images was not added as judgment debtor with respect to attorney fee award to service providers as prevailing party in copyright infringement action; corporation had always been able to satisfy judgments in its nearly 20 years of operation, and it retained $1.7 million in net assets and equity when it sued service providers.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS  Attorney Fees. Infringer's sole shareholder was not liable for attorney fees under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Gust, Inc. v. AlphaCap Ventures, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under California law, patent holder was not alter ego of its principal, and, thus, principal was not jointly liable for alleged infringer's attorney fees under statute authorizing attorney fees in exceptional patent cases, although principal allegedly caused holder to settle its nine other lawsuits solely for purpose of safeguarding his employment, where holder did not cease to exist as separate entity, and there was no abuse of corporate form. 35 U.S.C.A. § 285.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Computers and Electronics. Computer-implemented method claims were directed to patent-ineligible abstract idea of managing information used to facilitate crowdfunding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Adtile Technologies Inc. v. Perion Network Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Allegations of developer of multi-sensor advertising technology and services for smartphones and tablets that corporate officer and another employee listed both Israeli parent corporation and its subsidiary as their place of employment on social media website were insufficient to support an agency or alter ego theory, and were thus insufficient for district court to pierce corporate veil and attribute subsidiary's alleged actions to parent corporation, on developer's breach of contract and trademark infringement action against parent corporation and subsidiary; parent corporation and its subsidiaries maintained separate books, records, and accounts.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal or general jurisdiction over Israeli corporation that did not advertise in forum state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Astornet Technologies Inc. v. BAE Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: District court's focus on facts that would justify piercing corporate veil of corporate subsidiary was too narrow to support dismissal of patent infringement action brought by licensee of patent for airport gate entry system against parent corporation for allegedly inducing infringement by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) by virtue of TSA's use of airport equipment supplied by the subsidiary; although focus on veil-piercing facts was appropriate for considering parent corporation's indirect liability for infringement committed by subsidiary, veil-piercing standards did not govern issues of direct liability, and district court's analysis should have included examination of whether parent corporation affirmatively encouraged TSA to enter into contract with subsidiary to engage in infringement. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(b).
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - United States. Patent licensee's exclusive remedy for alleged infringement by government contractors was suit against United States in Court of Federal Claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Baby Phat Holding Co., LLC v. Kellwood Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Purchaser of certain trademarks, copyrights, and contractual rights stated a breach of contract claim against seller's parent company, based upon an alter-ego theory, where purchaser alleged that parent company dominated and controlled negotiations on behalf of seller and actually provided erroneous information which persuaded purchaser to enter into the agreement, that purchaser paid full purchase price directly to parent company and not seller, and that parent company perpetrated a wrong or injustice against purchaser, thus warranting intervention by a court of equity, through its domination of seller, misrepresentation of value of assets sold, and causing seller to become judgment proof.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Purchaser stated a breach of contract claim against seller's parent company, based upon an alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: A.V.E.L.A., Inc. v. Estate of Monroe
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In action against estate of film actress by company that licensed artwork featuring pop culture figures, seeking declaratory judgment that products company licensed did not infringe on estate's intellectual property, in which estate counter-sued company and its owner for unfair competition and trademark infringement, estate's proposed counterclaim adding three corporations as counter-defendants sufficiently alleged that the corporations were alter egos of company's owner, as required to state claim under New York law for piercing corporate veil; counterclaim alleged that corporations were undercapitalized, that owner was sole shareholder, officer, and employee, and co-mingled corporate funds and his personal finances, and that disregard of corporate form was used to evade liability for infringement.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Neither undue delay, undue prejudice, nor futility precluded granting of a motion to amend a counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Radiancy, Inc. v. Viatek Consumer Products Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Claims that a skincare products manufacturer was completely controlled by its parent company, that both entities shared the same chief executive officer (CEO), and that parent company was the real owner of patents asserted by manufacturer as infringed, failed to allege that parent company was the alter ego of manufacturer, as required to pierce the corporate veil and hold parent company liable for any harms committed by manufacturer under Delaware law.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Declaratory Judgment. District Court lacked authority to issue declaratory judgment on validity or infringement of a patent, in absence of a patent controversy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Jackson v. Odenat
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In hip-hop artist's action against, inter alia, website owner alleging unauthorized use of artist's likeness and intellectual property on the website, artist presented no evidence to show that website owner was insolvent or that he had unreasonably small capital because of transfers to other business entities formed by owner after artist's complaint was filed against owner, as required to support summary judgment on artist's fraudulent transfer and veil piercing claims under New York law. N.Y.McKinney's Debtor and Creditor Law §§ 273–275.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Judgment. Fact issue remained as to whether use of hip-hop artist's persona and G-Unit mark on website mastheads was likely to cause confusion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: RMS Titanic, Inc. v. Zaller
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine under Georgia law could not be used to apply owner's United States citizenship to Singapore corporation, so as to support exercise of subject-matter jurisdiction over the corporation in Lanham Act action, absent allegations supporting a claim that the owner used the corporation's corporate form for fraudulent or improper purposes, sufficient to ignore it as an entity. Lanham Act, § 1 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 1051 et seq.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Trade Dress. Plaintiffs involved in staging of museum quality exhibition stated plausible trade dress infringement claim under Lanham Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: UMG Recordings, Inc. v. BCD Music Group, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: District Court did not clearly err in determining that music distributor was an alter ego of music label, for purposes of amending a judgment against label for copyright infringement to include distributor, regardless of whether the copyright infringement was done in the name of label or distributor, where label and distributor had the same ownership, shared an address, shared directors, shared a managing director, operated in a similar industry with identical clients, label was unlikely to pay judgment debt absent corporate veil piercing, and distributor had the ability to control label's defense to the claims of copyright infringement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District Court did not clearly err in determining that music distributor was an alter ego of music label.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Desmond v. Chicago Boxed Beef Distributors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, a special showing is made, for purposes of holding corporate officer or owner individually liable for corporation's infringing activity, where individual acts willfully and knowingly, that is, when he personally participates in the manufacture or sale of the infringing article, or when he uses the corporation as an instrument to carry out his own willful and deliberate infringements, or when he knowingly uses an irresponsible corporation with the purpose of avoiding personal liability.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Counterfeit Goods. Complaint stated claim for trademark infringement against meat supplier.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Optigen, LLC v. International Genetics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, competitors' shareholder was not individually liable to patentee under theory of piercing the corporate veil, even if he dominated every aspect of both competitors, where there was no evidence that shareholder's alleged domination was used to further his personal business or that his alleged domination perpetuated a wrong or injustice against patentee.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Competitors' shareholder was not individually liable to patentee under theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Carotek, Inc. v. Kobayashi Ventures, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Plaintiffs failed to show requisite domination and control to warrant piercing corporate veil, under alter–ego theory of Delaware law, to hold individual personally liable for alleged torts of two companies; plaintiffs asserted only that individual was involved in both companies and was plaintiffs' main contact, that individual's name was on letters in which companies asserted their patent rights and warned of potential litigation with plaintiffs, and that individual was co–owner of one company, manager of other company, and authorized letters to be sent, but companies had other members, investors, and directors, purchased, owned, and managed patents and entered license agreements, and both filed and paid taxes.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Priority. Though invalid upon issuance, patent effectively claimed priority to prior patent upon issuance of certificate of correction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: MSA Products, Inc. v. Nifty Home Products, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In patent actions where a court has jurisdiction over a corporation, district court may pierce the corporate veil to exercise personal jurisdiction over a shareholder who is the mere alter ego of that corporation.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Design. Three-drawer versions of accused products did not infringe design patents for countertop coffee pod drawers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: B. Merrick Rd., LLC v. Chriso Food Services, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold shareholder personally liable for misuse of trade name, where use of trade name had been based upon acknowledged contractual right, corporate formalities had not been lacking, funds had not been commingled, shareholder did not exercise complete domination of corporation, fraud or wrong against plaintiffs had not been committed even if complete domination had occurred, and shareholder did not engage in self-dealing with regard to corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold shareholder personally liable for misuse of trade name.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Pandaw America, Inc. v. Pandaw Cruises India Pvt. Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: In a trademark infringement case, the court does not undertake the traditional veil piercing analysis; rather, a claim for trademark infringement may be asserted against a stockholder or officer of a corporation who is responsible for his corporation's infringing activities.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Jurisdiction. Alleged trademark infringers did not have sufficient minimum contacts with Colorado to subject them to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Mercado-Salinas v. Bart Enterprises Intern., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Florida law, trademark assignor pled sufficient facts to pierce the corporate veil of assignors so as to establish personal liability on the part of assignors' director, where assignor alleged that the corporate assignees were alter egos of director, the relationship between director and assignees was completely personalized, director managed all of the assignees' activities and used the corporate names at his pleasure, and no corporate formalities were being followed by any of the assignees.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Trademark assignor pled sufficient facts to pierce corporate veil of assignors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Newport News Holdings Corp. v. Virtual City Vision, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: District court made sufficient factual findings to establish personal jurisdiction over owner of corporation as part of district court's determination that it was appropriate to pierce the corporate veil under Virginia law and hold owner personally liable in competitor's action against corporation alleging violation of Anticybersquatting Consumer Protection Act (ACPA); district court found both unity of interest and an intent by owner to commit an injustice using corporation, based on findings that corporation had no separate identity from owner, that owner was president, sole employee, and only participating member of corporation's board of directors, that owner conducted corporation's business out of his home, and that owner was solely responsible for corporation's actions. Anticybersquatting Consumer Protection Act, § 1000(a), 15 U.S.C.A. § 1125(d)(1)(A), (d)(1)(B)(i); Lanham Act, § 33(b)(4), 15 U.S.C.A. § 1115(b)(4).
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE - Internet. Owner lacked bona fide noncommercial or fair use of newportnews.com internet domain name.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Las Vegas Sands Corp. v. Ace Gaming, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, parent company did not exhibit corporate dominance over its subsidiary, a licensee of trademark for hotel, and thus, piercing of licensee's corporate veil to hold parent company liable for licensee's purported breach of licensing agreement was not appropriate; there was no evidence that subsidiary was undercapitalized when it was formed, or evidence as to level of capitalization required to operate casino and hotel such as one in Atlantic City, New Jersey, such that court could come to any conclusion as to adequacy or inadequacy of subsidiary's capitalization, there was not requisite day-to-day involvement of parent company's directors or officers in subsidiary's operations, and funds of parent company and subsidiary were not commingled.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Marks and Logos. Licensor had authority to terminate licensing agreement when licensee shut down hotel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Las Vegas Sands Corp. v. Ace Gaming, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, parent company did not abuse privilege of incorporation by using its subsidiary, a licensee of trademark for hotel, to perpetuate fraud or injustice, and thus, piercing of licensee's corporate veil to hold parent company liable for licensee's purported breach of licensing agreement was not appropriate; even if subsidiary lacked sufficient funds to pay any judgment, there was no evidence that subsidiary's financial state resulted from abuse of corporate form.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Marks and Logos. Licensor had authority to terminate licensing agreement when licensee shut down hotel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Las Vegas Sands Corp. v. Ace Gaming, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, subsidiary, a licensee of trademark for hotel, was not acting as its parent company's agent when it signed licensing agreement with licensor, absent evidence that parent company agreed to have subsidiary act on its behalf when subsidiary entered into agreement.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Marks and Logos. Licensor had authority to terminate licensing agreement when licensee shut down hotel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Grice Engineering, Inc. v. JG Innovations, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Corporate officers can be held personally liable for infringement or other tortious acts of their corporation if there is reason to disregard the corporate form, such as evidence that the corporation was merely the alter ego of its officers.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Deceptive Trade Practices. Manufacturer failed to allege that it was induced to act by competitor, as required to state claim for deceptive trade practices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Biopolymer Engineering, Inc. v. ImmuDyne, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Nutraceutical company was not required to pierce corporate veil of corporation to which inventor had disputed assigned patents, before company applied for a turnover order against inventor in company's action against inventor for violating Rule 11 agreement in prior derivative action regarding company's ownership of disputed patents. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 31.002(a)(1).
Document Preview: PATENTS - Biotechnology. Purchaser of patents from inventor's corporation was not entitled to bona fide purchaser defense.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Biopolymer Engineering, Inc. v. ImmuDyne, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish that corporation was organized and operated as a mere tool or conduit for inventor, in action by nutraceutical company against assignees and purchaser of patents seeking declaration it was the sole owner and exclusive licensee of disputed patents; there was evidence that corporation was organized in a foreign country, inventor acted as its United States agent, inventor directed that all checks payable to corporation be sent to him in Texas, and, after nutraceutical company obtained turnover order in action against inventor to enforce a prior judgment on the patents, inventor directed corporate service to draw up a power of attorney allowing him to buy, sell, trade, reassign or barter any assets and patents owned by corporation.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Biotechnology. Purchaser of patents from inventor's corporation was not entitled to bona fide purchaser defense.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: R.F.M.A.S., Inc. v. Mimi So
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, competitors which had produced allegedly infringing line of jewelry were not alter egos of other competitors which had invested in their business and which had previously entered into negotiations to invest in copyright owner's jewelry business, as would be required to find investing competitor had directly infringed copyright owned by jewelry maker in violation of Copyright Act; jewelry-producing competitor was separately incorporated entity, and only two out of five members of its board of directors were appointed by investing competitor, investing competitor held only minority interest in jewelry-producing competitor when it invested in competitor, and there would be no injustice or unfairness if competitors' corporate structure would be respected, as owners have alleged vicarious and contributory infringement against investing competitor, which would hold them liable for acts of jewelry-producing competitor without piercing corporate veils of competitors. 17 U.S.C.A. §§ 106, 501.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Competitors did not directly infringe owner's copyright to pieces of jewelry.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: R.F.M.A.S., Inc. v. Mimi So
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, competitor which had distributed, sold, and advertised allegedly infringing line of jewelry in Japan was not alter ego of other separately incorporated competitors which previously entered into negotiations to invest in copyright owner's jewelry business, as would be required to find potential investing competitor had directly infringed copyright owned by jewelry maker in violation of Copyright Act; purchase of infringing products did not constitute infringement under Copyright Act, and sale of infringing products outside United States did not violate Copyright Act. 17 U.S.C.A. §§ 106, 501.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Competitors did not directly infringe owner's copyright to pieces of jewelry.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Johnson & Johnson Consumer Companies, Inc. v. Aini
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: President, sole shareholder, and only full-time employee of corporation was moving, active, conscious force behind corporation's activities and conduct, as required to hold that person liable under Lanham Act for corporation's trademark infringement. Lanham Act, § 32(a)(1), 15 U.S.C.A. § 1114(a)(1).
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Counterfeit Goods. Competitor's alleged prior version of trademark owner's skin cream had to be deemed counterfeit under Lanham Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: TIP Systems, LLC v. SBC Operations, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of holding company so as to hold it liable for allegedly infringing acts committed by its subsidiary was not warranted, absent showing that finances, record-keeping, and daily operations of the two corporations were not kept separate, that subsidiary's business came only from holding company, that subsidiary operated with grossly inadequate capital, that holding company used subsidiary's property as its own, or that holding company totally dominated and controlled subsidiary so that it was operated as holding company's business conduit or agent. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of parent so as to hold it liable for allegedly infringing acts of subsidiary was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Smith v. NBC Universal
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil had to be pierced in order to hold corporate parent liable under California law for activities of its partly owned subsidiary, where subsidiary admitted that it was responsible for copyright violation and parent did not have direct relationship with violator.
Document Preview: TORTS - Publicity. Commercial value of publication containing orca attack on victim was not enhanced by victim's likeness or identity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Mere fact that individual was the sole shareholder, director, and officer of patent owner's competitor was not sufficient basis, under California law, for disregarding corporate entity of competitor and to treat it as individual's alter ego, in action alleging infringement of patent for portable device for feeding animals.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Damages. Award of lost profit damages to patent owner was not supported by substantial evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, competitor's corporate officer was not competitor's alter ego for infringement of patent for portable device for feeding animals for having held himself out as liable for competitor's debts; even if officer offered to personally indemnify competitor's customers, such an indemnification would make him liable for customers' debts, not competitor's.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Damages. Award of lost profit damages to patent owner was not supported by substantial evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Flentye v. Kathrein
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: A plaintiff can pursue a trademark infringement claim under a veil-piercing theory. Lanham Act, § 33(b), 15 U.S.C.A. § 1115(b).
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE - Internet. Apartment managers sufficiently alleged claim under Anti-Cybersquatting Consumer Protection Act (ACPA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Iridex Corp. v. Synergetics USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced, under Missouri law, to allow for patent infringement action against parent of subsidiary allegedly violating patent for fiber optic connector system used with medical lasers; parent was not even formed until one month before suit, when it was created as part of reverse triangular merger, parent had legitimate business purpose of running acquired company, and subsidiary had not been drained of resources to pay any damages that might result from infringement suit.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced in patent infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Big East Entertainment, Inc. v. Zomba Enterprises, Inc
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Record distribution corporation, as parent company, could not pierce the corporate veil to advance copyright infringements claims of its subsidiaries, under New York law, based on shareholder's personal ownership of parent and subsidiaries.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Limitations. Record distribution corporation's copyright ownership and infringement claims were time-barred.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Jacobs Vehicle Systems, Inc. v. Pacific Diesel Brake Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, engine brake manufacturer's parent company did not so dominate manufacturer as to warrant piercing corporate veil in connection with patent infringement claim against manufacturer, even though manufacturer's president regularly reported to parent's board of directors, where parent did not control manufacturer's day-to-day operations, manufacturer was adequately capitalized, and there was no evidence that parent was hiding behind manufacturer in order to perpetuate fraud or other wrong.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Transportation. Parent did not so dominate manufacturer as to warrant piercing corporate veil in connection with patent infringement claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Perfect 10, Inc. v. CCBill, LLC
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Provider of age verification services for adult content websites could not be held liable for direct copyright infringement by client websites, under alter ego theory, even though websites were owned by employees of separate company that was also owned by provider's president; there was no evidence of unity of interest between separate company and its employees.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Internet. ISP came within DMCA safe harbor for providers who merely link users to infringing websites.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: DeWitt v. Hutchins
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, president of closely-held corporation was not individually liable for corporation's alleged violation of patent law and breach of contract, even though she was dominant shareholder and was exclusively responsible for management and marketing of corporation's products, where contracting party was aware that president was acting on behalf of corporation, and there was no evidence that corporation operated as mere instrumentality or alter ego of president.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President was not individually liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California, Western Division.
Headnote: Under California law, holding sole shareholder and president of patent infringement defendant personally liable for defendant's conduct was not warranted; though judgment might remain unsatisfied if corporate veil was not pierced, defendant had not disregarded corporate formalities, defendant's use of shareholder's name and photograph to advertise its products did not establish unity of interest, and adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would not sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Personal Liability. Sole shareholder was not personally liable for company's patent infringement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Playboy Enterprises, Inc. v. Welles
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced, under California law, to impute to model, who controlled corporation, obligation of corporation not to use magazine's designation of model as "Playmate of the Year 1981" without magazine's consent; although magazine advanced sufficient evidence to establish unity of interest, there was no indication that adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Computers and Online Services. Model's use of PMOY 81, on her wallpaper, or background, of her website was not nominative use.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Thomas v. Lytle
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Under both Tennessee and Missouri law, corporate veil could be pierced in to hold president and sole shareholder of two corporations personally liable for corporations' breach of contract in failing to make required royalty payments to plaintiff recording artists, in light of president's clear domination and control over his companies' financial operations, such as by exercising complete control over whatever information was given to accountant that prepared companies' books and records, of president's failure to maintain arms-length relationships among his various entities, and of president's use of companies to avoid his obligations.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Entertainment. Royalty payments had to be calculated based on income to sublicensee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Al-Site Corp. v. VSI Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Personal liability of officer for corporation's acts of patent infringement requires sufficient evidence to justify piercing the corporate veil; the corporate entity deserves respect and legal recognition unless specific, unusual circumstances justify disregarding the corporate structure. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: Assignee of patents claiming hangers for displaying non-prescription eyeglasses brought action against competitor and competitor's chairman, alleging patent, trademark, and trade dress infringement. After granting assignee's motion for summary judgment on competitor's defense of inequitable conduct, 1997 WL 579201, and then conducting jury trial, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, C. Clyde Atkins, Senior Judge, entered judgment upon jury verdict finding literal infringement of one patent, infringement of remaining patents under doctrine of equivalents, trademark and trade dress infringement, and unfair competition. The jury also imposed personal liability on competitor's chairman, making him jointly and severally liable for the damage award. Parties appealed. The Court of Appeals, Rader, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) one patent was literally infringed; (2) remaining patents were also infringed; (3) patents were not invalid for obviousness; (4)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Al-Site Corp. v. VSI Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate officer's act of making sole decision to continue using accused hanger tags after corporation received cease and desist letters from patent assignee was not sufficient to impose personal liability on officer for patent infringement; officer acted within and according to strictures of corporate structure, record showed no instance of the corporation operating as officer's alter ego, and officer acted upon advice of counsel. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).

After granting assignee's motion for summary judgment on competitor's defense of inequitable conduct, 1997 WL 579201, and then conducting jury trial, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, C.
