Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Hair Associates, Inc. v. National Hair Replacement Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil and holding corporation's two shareholders individually liable on trademark infringement and unfair competition claims brought against corporation was not warranted, where there was no meaningful or regular disregard for corporate formalities. Lanham Trade-Mark Act, §§ 32(1)(a), 43(a), 15 U.S.C.A. §§ 1114(1)(a), 1125(a).
Document Preview: Hair replacement franchisor brought trademark infringement action against its former franchisee, alleging infringement of its Hair Replacement Systems mark. The District Court, Brenneman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) former franchisee's use of letter mark nHRS and related logo for its hair replacement studio was likely to confuse consumers; (2) former franchisee's national Hair Replacement Services mark was not likely to cause consumer confusion; (3) former franchisee's president was jointly and severally liable; (4) injunctive relief was warranted; (5) revenues from surgical hair transplant segment of former franchisee's business were not properly included in profits analysis; (6) salary of former franchisee's president would be allocated equally between former franchisee's hair replacement studio and its hair transplant clinic in determining franchisee's profits; (7)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Pacamor Bearings, Inc. v. Minebea Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Corporation that purchased ball bearing manufacturer's assets after manufacturer was liquidated in bankruptcy proceeding was neither alter ego nor successor corporation to manufacturer, and its financial records were irrelevant to manufacturer's damages in Lanham Act false advertising action. Lanham Trade-Mark Act, § 43(a), 15 U.S.C.A. § 1125(a).
Document Preview: Ball bearing manufacturer brought action against competitors, alleging false advertising in violation of Lanham Act, violations of New Hampshire Consumer Protection Act, and state law unfair competition.  On cross motions for partial summary judgment, objections to magistrate judge's discovery ruling and twelve motions in limine, the District Court, Devine, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) Lanham Act false advertising claim was cognizable in First Circuit; (2) New Hampshire Consumer Protection Act could be applied to business competitors; (3) manufacturer stated unfair competition claim under New Hampshire law; (4) evidence concerning competitors' test performed upon their bearings following initiation of lawsuit was irrelevant; (5) determination of International Trade Commission (ITC) that defendants imported and sold ball bearings at less than fair value was irrelevant; (6) conduct occurring outside New Hampshire was relevant...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: International Controls and Measurements Corp. v. Watsco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: In patent cases, as in state corporation cases, it is fundamental that the corporate entity should be recognized and upheld, unless specific, unusual circumstances call for exception.
Document Preview: Holder of patent for air-conditioning system lock-out timer brought action against alleged infringer.  On holder's motion to hold alleged infringer in contempt for allegedly failing to comply with injunction against marketing timers, the District Court, Scullin, J., held that: (1) no agency relationship existed between alleged infringer and its subsidiary, for purposes of determining whether subsidiary was subject to injunction; (2) alleged infringer did not violate injunction against marketing lock-out timer when it honored preexisting warranty and shipped a single unit to its customer to replace a part; and (3) alleged infringer was not entitled to attorney's fees. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Bingham v. Zolt
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Singer's estate could claim as damages royalties that were owed to corporations which allegedly were diverted from estate by singer's former legal and financial advisors; disregarding distinction between corporations and their owner, the estate, was necessary to prevent fraud and achieve equity.
Document Preview: Estate of singer brought action against singer's former legal and financial advisors under Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO).  The District Court, Conboy, J., held that: (1) estate's RICO claims were not barred by statute of limitations, despite fact that advisors' wrongful acts and estate's awareness of wrongful acts occurred more than four years before estate brought suit, and (2) estate's request for attorney fees and disbursements in amount of 3,564,033.48 would be reduced by 15%. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Kinetic Instruments, Inc. v. Lares
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Federal court in New York could not assert jurisdiction over nonresident corporate officer by piercing alleged infringer's corporate veil; complaint did not contain any allegations concerning inadequate capitalization of corporation, intermingling of corporate finances with those of officer, or lack of corporate formalities, and corporation was incorporated well before patent was issued or infringing product first manufactured or sold.
Document Preview: Holder of patent for dental handpiece brought infringement action against officer of competitor corporation alleging that officer was personally liable for competitor's acts of infringement.  Officer moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue.  The District Court, Sand, J., held that: (1) complaint alleged sufficient facts to enable New York to assert jurisdiction over officer, and (2) complaint made adequate prima facie showing that venue was proper. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: In re Vermont Toy Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Vermont.
Headnote: Debtor-corporation's failure to have patent evaluated by independent appraiser prior to its sale to sole shareholder did not warrant piercing of corporate veil so as to expose sole shareholder's personal assets; bankruptcy court had precise remedy to cure any monetary injury if patent was improperly sold for less than market value. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 548.
Document Preview: Involuntary Chapter 7 bankruptcy proceeding was filed.  Secured creditor moved for declaratory judgment requesting determination that collateral it repossessed from debtor prepetition was not property of estate and could be sold, or, in alternative, for relief from automatic stay and approval of repossession.  Petitioning creditor, on behalf of Chapter 7 trustee, petitioned to marshal assets.  The Bankruptcy Court, 82 B.R. 258, ruled that inequitable conduct of sole shareholder of debtor was sufficient to warrant piercing of corporate veil, application of marshaling of assets doctrine, and equitable subordination of shareholder's guaranty relationship with secured creditor.  Secured creditor appealed.  The District Court, Gagliardi, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) petitioning creditor, on behalf of Chapter 7 trustee, had authority to invoke marshaling of assets doctrine; (2) failure to join as parties entities holding funds to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Engineering Dynamics, Inc. v. Structural Software, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced to impose personal liability upon 80% owner of company that was found to have infringed upon copyright in computer software manual, even though the 80% owner personally designed and marketed program upon which infringing manual was based.
Document Preview: Computer software creator brought action against competitor, alleging copyright infringement, trade dress infringement, and unfair competition regarding structural engineering software and accompanying manuals.  The District Court, Beer, J., held that: (1) protectable copyright interest existed in text, pictures, diagrams, illustrative examples, and flow charts depicted in software manuals, but not in input and output formats; (2) evidence was sufficient to establish copying; (3) amount of damages for infringement would be reduced by amount reflecting competitor's innovative developments in the program; (4) protectable trade dress was not found in input protocols, output reports, manuals, or look and feel of creator's program; (5) competitor was not liable for unfair competition; (6) creator's actual damages reflected costs of converting creator's program to be competitive with infringer's program; (7) distribution of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Manville Sales Corp. v. Paramount Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: For officers of corporation which allegedly infringed patent to be personally liable for infringement, evidence must justify piercing the corporate veil. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: Holder of patent for iris guide arms for self-centering luminaire assembly designed to be used on lighting poles brought action against another corporation and its corporate officers, alleging infringement.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, James McGirr Kelly, J., awarded damages for infringement, and corporation determined to have infringed patents and its corporate officers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Michel, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported determination that use of invention on one pole at one site in Wyoming was experimental, for purposes of on sale and public use bars of patent; (2) patent holder was obligated to disclose experimental uses upon application for patent, but finding no duty to disclose was harmless error; and (3) corporate officers were not personally liable for direct infringement or for actively inducing corporation to infringe patent. Affirmed in part;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Manville Sales Corp. v. Paramount Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Acts of officers of corporation found to have infringed patent were within scope of officers' employment and thus protected by corporate veil, so liability for direct infringement of patent could not be imposed on officers personally; although officers took actions which assisted copying of patent holder's design, corporation was found not to be the alter ego of the officers, and corporation was found not to have known of patent prior to lawsuit and to have continued subsequent infringing activity because of good-faith belief, based on advice of counsel, that activity was not infringing. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: Holder of patent for iris guide arms for self-centering luminaire assembly designed to be used on lighting poles brought action against another corporation and its corporate officers, alleging infringement.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, James McGirr Kelly, J., awarded damages for infringement, and corporation determined to have infringed patents and its corporate officers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Michel, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) evidence supported determination that use of invention on one pole at one site in Wyoming was experimental, for purposes of on sale and public use bars of patent; (2) patent holder was obligated to disclose experimental uses upon application for patent, but finding no duty to disclose was harmless error; and (3) corporate officers were not personally liable for direct infringement or for actively inducing corporation to infringe patent. Affirmed in part;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation, all of stock of which was held by its parent, certain debts of which were guaranteed by the parent, which shared common offices and directors with parent, for which no separate minutes were kept nor agendas prepared for board of directors' meetings, and which continued to use parent's name on its advertising and stationery even after its name was changed to distinguish it from the parent, was not "alter ego" of the parent for purposes of holding parent liable for subsidiary's alleged patent infringement in absence of any showing of fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under federal, Delaware, or Oklahoma common law, fraud or something like it is required to hold parent corporation liable for patent infringement of its subsidiary under alter ego theory.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for patent infringement of its subsidiary under agency theory of domination and control; that theory was akin to alter ego theory of liability, which had been rejected for absence of proof of fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Requiring patent holder to enforce its patent rights against alleged infringer in a different forum from that in which it brought suit was not kind of injustice warranting piercing corporate veil of the allegedly infringing subsidiary so as to hold its corporate parent liable.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against, among others, parent corporation of subsidiary which manufactured allegedly infringing product. Parent moved for summary judgment and patent holder moved to substitute subsidiary for parent as party defendant.  The District Court, Latchum, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) parent was not liable for any direct infringement; (2) parent could not be held liable under alter ego theory for infringement of its subsidiary; (3) parent could not be held liable under pure agency theory for infringement of its subsidiary; and (4) subsidiary could not be substituted for parent. Parent's motion granted and patent holder's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Moore v. American Barmag Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division..
Headnote: Senior official of corporation could not be held personally liable for alleged patent infringement by corporation, absent evidence that official acted other than in capacity as corporate officer and absent evidence that official was alter ego of corporation.
Document Preview: Employee brought patent infringement action against employer.  The District Court, 693 F.Supp. 399, denied motion for summary judgment. Additional motions were filed.  The District Court, Robert D. Potter, Chief Judge, held that: (1) fact issues precluded summary judgment on employer's claim to shop right in employee's patent; (2) senior official of employer could not be held personally liable for alleged patent infringement by employer, absent proof that official acted other than in capacity as officer of employer and absent proof that official was alter ego of employer; (3) allegation that employee's deposition testimony was taken under duress did not entitle employee to ruling limiting use of the deposition; and (4) claim for misappropriation of trade secret rights in violation of North Carolina Trade Secrets Protection Act was sufficient to withstand motion for summary judgment dismissing claim. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Jobete Music Co., Inc. v. Media Broadcasting Corp.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina, , Winston–Salem Division. .
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, corporate veil of radio station owner could be pierced so as to hold holding company that was sole shareholder of owner jointly and severally liable for station's copyright infringement; president of both entities was same person and holding company exercised actual control over owner and operated it as mere instrumentality.
Document Preview: Copyright licensing body brought infringement action against holding company that was sole shareholder of radio station owner and individual who was president of both owner and holding company.  On motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Bullock, J., held that: (1) station's playing of copyrighted songs without license to do so constituted willful infringement, and (2) appropriate remedy was permanent injunction, statutory damages in amount of $2,500 per infringement, and costs and attorney fees. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: SI Handling Systems, Inc. v. Heisley
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Subsidiary and its parent were essentially the same entity for purposes of ownership of alleged trade secrets.
Document Preview: In action alleging misappropriation and wrongful use of plaintiff's proprietary information, including trade secrets, to build a competitive business, defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Troutman, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) jury questions were presented as to claims of misappropriation of trade secrets, breach of contract, interference with contract, conspiracy, antitrust violations and violations of Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, and (2) plaintiff pointed to nothing suggesting that it would be able to support its allegations as to two defendants. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Coleman v. Corning Glass Works
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Facts that parent corporation owned all shares of subsidiary, paid salary of subsidiary's chief executive officer, and may have referred to subsidiary as division were inadequate to establish degree of domination necessary to disregard subsidiary's separate corporate identity and hold parent liable for subsidiary's alleged patent infringement.
Document Preview: Patent holder brought patent infringement action, and alleged infringer moved to dismiss principally on ground that several causes of action were barred by delay in bringing suit.  The District Court, Telesca, J., held that: (1) inability to find attorney to prosecute action, or to raise necessary funds for litigation were insufficient to rebut presumption that delay of more than six years in bringing suit was unreasonably long; (2) alleged infringer's sale of rights to infringing device was sufficient prejudice to assert defense of laches; (3) parent corporation could not be held liable for subsidiary's alleged infringing activities; and (4) district court would decline to exercise its pendent jurisdiction over state law claims. Dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Coleman v. Corning Glass Works
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Even if parent received indirect, unjust profit from its ownership of subsidiary, that was not enough to meet requirement so as to pierce corporate veil and render parent liable for alleged patent infringement of subsidiary that parent used separate corporate existence of subsidiary to perpetrate frauds.
Document Preview: Patent holder brought patent infringement action, and alleged infringer moved to dismiss principally on ground that several causes of action were barred by delay in bringing suit.  The District Court, Telesca, J., held that: (1) inability to find attorney to prosecute action, or to raise necessary funds for litigation were insufficient to rebut presumption that delay of more than six years in bringing suit was unreasonably long; (2) alleged infringer's sale of rights to infringing device was sufficient prejudice to assert defense of laches; (3) parent corporation could not be held liable for subsidiary's alleged infringing activities; and (4) district court would decline to exercise its pendent jurisdiction over state law claims. Dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Dania Jai-Alai Palace, Inc. v. Sykes
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Because the instrumentality rule is essentially equitable in character, the provisions under which a corporate entity may be disregarded so as to hold parent corporation liable for torts committed by employee of wholly owned subsidiary vary, depending upon circumstances in each case, and it is inappropriate to attempt to apply any verbalization of test in a mechanical manner.
Document Preview: Action was instituted to recover against three corporations for injuries sustained by plaintiff when crushed between two automobiles in parking lot.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, James F. Minnet, J., entered judgment on verdict for plaintiff, and defendants appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Hurley, J., held that: (1) parking attendant employed by second corporation was negligent when, though trying to apply brakes on plaintiff's vehicle, he hit accelerator and caused plaintiff, then in front of vehicle, to be propelled forward and crushed between cars; (2) whether plaintiff was contributorily negligent, however, was a question which should have been submitted to jury instead of being determined on motion for directed verdict; (3) first corporation could be held liable for negligence of parking attendant employed by second corporation where both corporations held themselves out as a single enterprise; and (4) whether third...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: D.L. Auld Co. v. Park Electrochemical Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation owned all of the shares of subsidiary, had directors and officers in common with it, financed operations of subsidiary, and paid salary of its president was not sufficient to warrant disregarding corporate entity of subsidiary in patent action as there is no showing that subsidiary had gross inadequate capital, that it had no business except with the parent, or that formal legal requirements of subsidiary were not observed.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action was brought against parent corporation and subsidiary. The District Court, Glasser, J., held that: (1) facts were insufficient to warrant disregarding corporate entity of subsidiary, and (2) genuine issue of material fact existed with respect to whether parent corporation, primarily through its president, played such a major role in business discussions with plaintiff in attempting to resolve patent dispute that it became an actor directly in transaction and was therefore jointly liable with subsidiary, precluding summary judgment. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Jet Spray Cooler, Inc. v. Crampton
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Middlesex.
Headnote: Where individual defendants actively participate in misappropriation of trade secrets, they may not insulate themselves from consequences of their actions by choosing corporate form by which to market their products.
Document Preview: Following remand, 361 Mass. 835, 282 N.E.2d 921, the Superior Court, Middlesex County, Dimond, J., entered judgment on issue of damages in suit by employer against former employees who entered into competing business allegedly using employer's trade secrets. On appeal, the Supreme Judicial Court, Abrams, J., held that: (1) judge properly allowed as a deduction from gross profits all bad debts incurred by defendants on sales of infringing products; (2) judge correctly allowed defendants to deduct salaries and fees paid to individual defendants by corporate defendant from gross profits of corporate defendant; (3) plaintiff did not prove lost profits due to defendants' sales to plaintiff's customers with sufficient certainty to allow plaintiff to recover damages based on lost profits; (4) joint involvement of corporate defendant and individual defendants in utilizing secrets required damages to be assessed against all, and (5) jury correctly allowed interest on judgment...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Briggs Transp. Co., Inc. v. Starr Sales Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: Officer and owner of a close corporation, who did not actively participate in corporation's business, was not individually immune from personal liability for actual damages under doctrine which permits piercing corporate veil; as a major corporate officer, she could not avoid liability by emulating three fabled monkeys, hearing, seeing and speaking no evil, nor could she ignore reality that corporation had evaded most basic aspects of corporate existence.
Document Preview: Carrier, as seller's assignee, brought action against corporation and its officer-owners, alleging that defendant corporation fraudulently breached contract for sale of goods with plaintiff's assignor, that individual defendants were individually liable for breach as principals of a sham corporation and committed fraud individually and in conspiracy, for which plaintiff sought actual and punitive damages. The Linn District Court, Louis W. Schultz, J., rendered judgment against defendant corporation and two of corporate officers, but found that third corporate officer and stockholder, who had no active part in corporate business, was not personally liable, and defendants appealed and plaintiff cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Reynoldson, J., held that: (1) there was ample evidence to support finding that individual defendant was officer, director and owner of corporation; (2) trial court was justified in piercing corporate veil to find officer personally liable; (3) because of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Edwin K. Williams & Co., Inc. v. Edwin K. Williams & Co.-East
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: In action brought by trade name licensor against licensee and corporate owner of licensee to recover, inter alia, for breach of contract and copyright and trade name infringement, trial court erred in failing to treat licensee and corporate owner of licensee as one entity, in view of fact that between licensee and corporate owner there was intermingling of transactions and employees, a disregard of formal separateness of two corporations, common stock ownership and common directors and officers, transfer of most of assets and business to later formed corporation, representations to public of single identity, and moral culpability and threat of injustice.
Document Preview: Licensor brought action against licensee and corporate owner of licensee seeking, inter alia, damages and injunctive relief for breach of agreement between parties, interference with contractual business relations, and copyright and trademark infringement, and licensee counterclaimed, alleging antitrust violations and invalidity of licensor's copyrights. The action was instituted in state court and removed to federal district court. The United States District Court for the Central District of California, David W. Williams, 377 F.Supp. 418, entered judgment for licensors, and defendants appealed and plaintiff cross-appealed. The Court of Appeals, Solomon, District Judge, held that agreement between parties created relationship of trade name licensee and licensor; that licensee could not assert lack of quality control to invalidate trade name license; that account books containing several pages of instructions were entitled to copyright protections; that licensee was guilty of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Von Brimer v. Whirlpool Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Corporate entity would not be disregarded for purposes of holding that there was no real assignment of patent by individual to the corporation on theory that the corporation was the "alter ego" of the individual, who sought to maintain suit with respect to the patent on theory that he still retained an interest therein, where there were at least three other shareholders having among them in excess of 40,000 shares of stock and where, aside from fact that it was the very person who allegedly used the corporate entity to his own personal ends who was seeking to have that entity disregarded, there appeared no injustice or fraud which would be allowed to occur in the event the entity was not disregarded.
Document Preview: Action was brought for alleged fraudulent appropriation of idea and invention, alleged malicious institution of patent interference, and alleged interference with contractual relations. Following trial on issue of plaintiffs' standing, the District Court, Renfrew, J., held that document evidencing assignment of interest to deceased would not be admitted in evidence where, inter alia, plaintiffs failed to produce such document until day before trial, in violation of discovery order, and failed to adequately explain absence of multiple originals or to show diligent effort to ascertain their location; that extrinsic evidence varying the terms of another assignment agreement would not be admitted where it was sought to be introduced by a party to that agreement; that corporate entity would not be disregarded with respect to still another assignment agreement, between deceased and a corporation; and that plaintiffs lacked standing with respect to alleged causes of action for malicious...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Superior Testers, Inc. v. Damco Testers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana, New Orleans Division.
Headnote: Where there was no evidence that any of officers, directors, and stockholders of licensor's corporate assignee, other than one, violated any duty owed licensee, and corporation had reasonable amount of capital stock and was not a mere sham, and corporation had a bona fide dispute about contractual interpretation with licensee, corporate entity would not be set aside to mulct officers, directors and stockholders for corporation's violation of licensee's exclusive patent license.
Document Preview: Action by corporate licensee for injunction on ground that licensor's corporate assignee and certain of its officers, directors and stockholders were violating licensee's exclusive patent license by making and using pipetesting equipment in Louisiana and were unfairly competing with licensee. The District Court, Rubin, J., held that where licensor and licensee executed a Bill of sale granting licensee a non-exclusive license under licensor's patents and licensee subsequently obtained from licensor a letter stating that licensee had an exclusive license in the states of Louisiana and Mississippi under the patents, licensee received an exclusive license to use invention in Louisiana and Mississippi, and since there was no reservation in agreement by licensor, the exclusiveness of the license applied to licensor's assignee as well. Decree accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Royal Industries v. St. Regis Paper Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Where parent corporation and its subsidiary were colicensors of patent and there was no showing that refusal to permit parent to disregard separate identity of its subsidiary would sanction a fraud or work injustice, subsidiary would not be treated as parent's alter ego and parent could not terminate licensing agreement on basis of alleged breach of oral condition by licensee without joinder or consent of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action against patent licensee for infringement and unfair competition on basis that the license had been terminated by plaintiff for breach by defendant of oral condition to written license, wherein defendant moved for summary judgment. The United States District Court for the Central District of California, Francis C. Whelan, J., granted defendant's motion for summary judgment and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hufstedler, Circuit Judge, held that where plaintiff parent corporation and its subsidiary were colicensors of patent and there was no showing that refusal to permit plaintiff to disregard separate identity of its subsidiary would sanction a fraud or work injustice, subsidiary would not be treated as plaintiff's alter ego and plaintiff could not terminate licensing agreement on basis of alleged breach of oral condition by licensee without joinder or consent of the subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Perbal v. Dazor Mfg. Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Where patent owners were not stockholders of licensee corporation and were not entitled to challenge corporate structure in absence of prejudice or damage to them, trial court properly refused to disregard corporate entity and hold controlling stockholder liable jointly with the corporation to full extent of its liability to plaintiff for failure to pay royalties.
Document Preview: Action by owners of patents against licensee for royalties allegedly due. The Circuit Court of the City of St. Louis, J. Casey Walsh, J., rendered judgment on counts I, III and IV in favor of owners and judgment in favor of licensee and its controlling stockholder on counts II and V. Appeals were taken by both owners and the licensee. The Supreme Court, Stockard, C., held that where patent owners accepted quarterly statements of account and payments accompanying those statements for total period of 19 years, owners had right to examine licensee's books of account where full information was available but did not do so and one of owners had desk assigned to him at licensee's place of business, owners' acceptance of statements established account stated and acceptance by owners of money established an account settled between owners and licensee. Judgment as to counts I, III and IV reversed and remanded with directions and judgment as to counts II and V...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Allstate Ins. Co. v. Allstate Inv. Corp.
Court: United States District Court W.D. Louisiana, Shreveport Division.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities of defendant investment corporation, which used plaintiff insurance company's registered mark, and insurance agency corporation which had same common stockholder as investment corporation, could not be disregarded, for purpose of establishing infringement, where it was not shown that separate corporate entities were intended for wrongful or unfair use.
Document Preview: Action by automobile insurance corporation to enjoin defendant investment corporation, which had same principal stockholder as incorporated insurance agency, from using plaintiff's registered mark in its name. The District Court, Benjamin C. Dawkins, Jr., Chief Judge, held that evidence did not establish any confusion in public mind as to source of investment corporation's services. Judgment for defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Inland Steel Products Co. v. MPH Mfg. Corp.
Court: United States District Court N. D. Illinois.
Headnote: While corporate shells have been penetrated in patent infringement suits where the facts warranted their being disregarded, they are to be respected where there is only the assertion of lack of knowledge by the pleader of subsidiaries' solvency, thereby requiring the parent's presence in the suit to stand possible substantial recovery.
Document Preview: Consolidated actions. The United States District Court, Robson, J., held that where motions for leave to file amendment and supplement to counterclaims and complaint were made nearly three and one half years after filing of original complaint and after many depositions and there was no explanation for the tardiness and no reason justifying injection of new parties into the litigation after extensive discovery and there was no showing of oversight, inadvertence or excusable neglect to account for the long delay, motion to strike the amendment and supplement would be granted. Motions to strike amendment and supplement to counterclaim and amendment and supplement to complaint granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Franks v. Markson
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Where three corporate plaintiffs sought to enjoin violation of contract made by plaintiffs and defendants with respect to use of plaintiffs' trade-name "Jim Clinton", even assuming one of defendants, which was a Maine corporation, owned and controlled a number of "Bill Benton" corporations which name allegedly was similar to trade name of "Jim Clinton", fact of ownership would not, standing alone, empower court to enter a decree against the Maine corporation which would bind the subsidiaries, since such ownership and control did not merge the corporations into one or make either the agent of the other.
Document Preview: Bill in equity to enjoin violation of a contract concerning, among other things, the right to use of a trade name. The Superior Court, Dewing, J., entered an interlocutory decree overruling demurrer and reported the case. The Supreme Judicial Court, Spalding, J., held that the name Bill Benton did not infringe the trade name Jim Clinton despite slight similarities. Interlocutory decree overruling plea in abatement and plea of forum non conveniens and denying motion to decline jurisdiction affirmed. Interlocutory decree overruling demurrer reversed. Final decree to be entered dismissing bill.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Helene Curtis Industries, Inc. v. Sales Affiliates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Where defendant's patent application was assigned to newly formed corporation and newly formed corporation issued 2,000 shares of stock to defendant in return for assignment, and defendant reserved to itself right to license when and if application should mature into patent and newly formed corporation agreed not to bring infringement action against defendant's licensees, and its only source of income was defendant's royalty payments under license, newly formed corporation was alter ego of defendant, and plaintiffs were entitled to injunction enjoining infringement actions brought by newly formed corporation against plaintiffs' customers as supplement to prior injunction enjoining defendant from bringing any action charging infringement concerning a similar patent held to be invalid.
Document Preview: Action for supplemental injunction enjoining defendant from prosecuting certain patent infringement actions against plaintiffs' customers. The District Court, Irving R. Kaufman, J., held that Patent No. 2,736,323 concerning mercaptans for waving hair was invalid for noncriticality, lack of invention over prior art, and indefiniteness in statement of claims and that plaintiffs were entitled to injunction enjoining prosecution of patent infringement actions against plaintiffs' customers. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Wolfe v. National Lead Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, Southern Division.
Headnote: On issue involving whether plaintiffs were liable for infringement and unfair competition conducted by their predecessor corporations, where plaintiffs were dominant personalities in the predecessor corporations and upon the dissolution thereof the same business continued uninterrupted with essentially the same organizational makeup as before, the corporate entities would be disregarded and plaintiffs would be liable for the wrongful acts of the corporations and must account for the corporations' profits from trade-mark infringement and unfair competition. Lanham Trade-Mark Act, § 35, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1117.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs were found guilty of trademark infringement and unfair competition and an accounting of the plaintiffs' profits and a determination of the defendant's damages was ordered. The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, Southern Division, Edward P. Murphy, J., set forth the proper method of accounting to be used in computing damages and profits and held that it should cover the entire period during which the plaintiffs and their predecessor corporations used the infringing mark and that certain deductions should be allowed or disallowed as indicated and that the defendant was entitled to reasonable attorneys' fees. Order in accordance with the opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Eastern Industries, Inc. v. Traffic Controls, Inc.
Court: United States District Court D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under circumstances presented in action against defendant-corporation for declaration of invalidity and noninfringement of a patent held by second corporation, including circumstances that second corporation acquired patent after all transactions with defendant-corporation and that defendant-corporation had no direct control of the patent, decree for preliminary injunction would not issue against defendant-corporation, even though it owned all stock of second corporation, the presidents and some directors were identical, and corporations had had financial transactions.
Document Preview: Action against defendant-corporation for declaration of patent invalidity and infringement of a patent held by second corporation. Plaintiff moved for preliminary injunction. The District Court, Rodney, J., held that under circumstances, including circumstances that second corporation acquired patent after all transactions with defendant-corporation and that defendant-corporation had no direct control of the patent, decree for preliminary injunction would not issue against defendant-corporation, even though it owned all stock of second corporation, the presidents and some directors were identical, and corporations had had financial transactions. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Wihtol v. Wells
Court: United States Court of Appeals Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Where defendant and two others formed corporation for publication of songbook which included song which infringed upon plaintiff's copyright, defendant was dominant influence in corporation and he had personally applied for copyright on infringing song in his own name, after corporation was dissolved, defendant was personally liable to plaintiff for such infringement. 17 U.S.C.A. §§ 1 et seq., 7.
Document Preview: Action for infringement of copyright protecting musical composition. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division, William J. Campbell, J., entered judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Duffy, Chief Judge, held that musical composition My God and I (music and words) which appeared in book published in 1951 by corporation formed by defendant and two others was infringement of composition of same name (music and words), copyrighted in 1935. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Academy Award Products v. Bulova Watch Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Where an individual, by means of corporation which he used as instrument of his will falsely procured registration of trademark for the purpose of harassing others who might thereafter make legitimate use of registered words in their businesses, corporate fiction would be disregarded in action by injured firm, against individual and his corporation, under statute providing for civil action by one injured by another's procurement of trademark by false or fraudulent misrepresentation. Lanham Trade-Mark Act of 1946, § 38, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1120.
Document Preview: Action for registered trade-mark infringement wherein defendant counterclaimed against corporate plaintiff and executrices of plaintiff's deceased president for damages alleged to have been sustained in consequence of procural of trade-mark by false and fraudulent declarations and representations. By stipulation plaintiff's complaint was dismissed with prejudice. On defendant's counterclaim, the District Court, Dimock, J., held, inter alia, that since plaintiff had brought action for infringement of trade-mark obtained through false registration intentionally to harm defendant, defendant was entitled to recover as damages attorneys' fees incurred in defense of action and from time such action was maintained but was not entitled to recover for attorneys' fees incurred in prosecuting counterclaim. Judgment accordingly. See also 90 F.Supp. 12.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Automatic Paper Machinery Co. v. Marcalus Mfg. Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Where assignor of patent, his wife and son, owned all the stock of corporation, and assignor admitted that he controlled the corporation, doctrine of estoppel by deed to deny validity of assigned patent extended to corporation as fully as to assignor.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the District of New Jersey; William F. Smith, Judge. Action by Automatic Paper Machinery Company, Inc., against Marcalus Manufacturing Company, Inc., and another to enjoin infringement of a patent and compel an accounting for profits. From a summary judgment for plaintiff, 54 F.Supp. 105, defendants appeal. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Culbertson v. Kem Playing Cards
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In action to recover royalties under contract relating to manufacture and sale of playing cards, partial defense that defendant corporation had granted sole and exclusive license to manufacture such cards to another corporation would be insufficient if it was found that such other corporation was either a subsidiary or assignee, but would be good if it was determined that such other corporation was a true licensee whose corporate entity could not be pierced.
Document Preview: Appeal from Supreme Court, New York County; Samuel H. Hofstadter, Justice. Action by Ely Culbertson against Kem Playing Cards, Inc., and Kem Card Sales Corporation to recover royalties under a written contract between plaintiff and first-named defendant, wherein as a seventh defense the defendants alleged that first-named defendant and last-named defendant entered into an agreement whereby last-named defendant was granted sole and exclusive license to manufacture and sell playing cards in consideration of a certain royalty, and that such agreement was fair to the plaintiff, and that plaintiff was limited in royalties to a certain percentage of the royalties paid by last-named defendant to the first-named defendant. From so much of an order of the Supreme Court, New York County, as granted plaintiff's motion to strike the second and third defenses from the answer to the amended complaint as insufficient in law, the defendants appeal, and from so much of the order as denied...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Vogt Instant Freezers v. New York Eskimo Pie Corporation
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: In patent infringement suit by assignee against assignor's subsidiary corporation, defendant's separate corporate status would be disregarded.
Document Preview: Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Eastern District of New York. In Equity.  Suit by Vogt Instant Freezers, Inc., against the New York Eskimo Pie Corporation for infringement of United States patents Nos. 1,733,740 and 1,742,171 granted to the plaintiff.  From a decree for the defendant (59 F. (2d) 99), plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Charles Broadway Rouss, Inc., v. Winchester Co.
Court: District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: The fact that a new corporation is affiliated with an older one is under the same control and has largely the same officers, where the older one is still doing business and has not assigned its good will or trade-mark rights, does not give the newer corporation the right to use the trade-mark of the older on goods which the latter has never made or dealt in.
Document Preview: In Equity. Suit by Charles Broadway Rouss, Inc., against the Winchester Company. Decree for complainant.
